summary: Paul Merson restarted his row with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was brought on with only seven minutes remaining in a 0-0 draw with Burnley, prompting Merson to sarcastically tweet about the "7 minutes" played; this followed Merson's initial criticism of Townsend's England call-up, which Townsend countered by scoring a stunning equalizer for England against Italy, leading Merson to admit he was wrong but reiterate his opinion that Townsend shouldn't have been in the squad, while Townsend hit back on Twitter referencing Merson's earlier claim he should be "nowhere near the squad".

Chelsea has made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old Japanese forward Yoshinori Muto, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane, who states the offer is unrelated to Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, making 37 appearances and scoring 16 goals, while also earning 11 international caps for Japan. If he moves to Chelsea, he would initially join their Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan. Muto, who scored 13 goals in his debut season and was named to the J-League best XI, admits he is undecided about the move but considers it an honor, with a £4 million deal mooted.

A large-scale Finnish study found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months are more likely to be overweight as toddlers, with repeated prescriptions before age two further increasing this risk, particularly affecting boys who were also slightly taller; while not proving causation, researchers suggest antibiotics may contribute to childhood obesity by altering gut bacteria that normally consume food, thereby increasing available nutrients and appetite, and they warn that such effects could play a role in the obesity epidemic, highlighting the need for judicious antibiotic use in infancy.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, an embarrassing incident caught on camera by tourist David Meadwell in front of hundreds of shocked onlookers; the guard lost his footing, knocked his bearskin, dropped his rifle, and quickly scrambled up, blushing as he realized the crowd had witnessed the fall, which may have been caused by metal protectors on his boots.

A&E, Lifetime, and History networks announced a remake of the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which will simulcast in 2016, recounting the saga of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in America. LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new version, described as "original" and "contemporary," drawing more from Alex Haley's novel and consulting scholars for authenticity. The remake aims to reach both fans of the original and a new generation of viewers, particularly young Americans unfamiliar with the story, amidst significant cultural events like Barack Obama's presidency and "12 Years a Slave" winning the Oscar, as well as ongoing racial unrest.

Former royal footman Christopher Lawler claims that in January 1978, during his first day working at Clarence House, he was pinned to a chair, groped, and subjected to sexual acts by male staff after being offered drinks and asked about his sexuality; he escaped, left the job immediately after his complaint was allegedly dismissed, and only reported the incident again last year following investigations into historical VIP abuse, though his initial complaints to the palace were ignored for months before being passed to police, who are now investigating, while a retired aide denied involvement.

Jesse and Melissa Meek of Oregon announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme song from 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,' which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube; the video features them rapping about their journey to parenthood, including initially lying about not being ready, Melissa discovering the pregnancy with a positive test, and ending with a sonogram reveal, taking five takes to film and made to inform distant relatives, with the couple considering another video after learning the baby's gender.

A gray jacket and skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills; originally slate blue-gray, it has faded to light gray with age and was worn in key scenes including encounters with Rhett Butler and the shanty town attack. The dress was part of James Tumblin's collection, acquired for $20 when it was about to be discarded, and was one of over 150 items from the film auctioned, with other top sales including Leigh's straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable's suit ($55,000), and a bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000).

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the railing, causing him to slip and fall approximately 10 to 12 feet; the parents rescued him before emergency services arrived, and the child suffered minor bumps and bruises, including a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs, which did not approach him; witnesses confirmed the child was dangled over the edge, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family while closing the exhibit.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham has been repositioned to point directly at a house; it has been inactive for over two years since all fixed devices in the West Midlands were decommissioned in March 2013 due to obsolete technology, replaced by mobile units, motorway cameras, and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the camera's unusual angle and plans to take appropriate action, potentially removing it, though it will not be included in their upcoming digital technology pilot.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, having been announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association; the six-time Olympic gold medallist stated he is fit, healthy, and ready to run, expressing happiness to be part of the team and pride in representing Jamaica, while JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure at Bolt's availability and anticipation of sprint magic, noting the full Jamaican team list will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves attended a Euro League basketball El Clasico match between Barcelona and Real Madrid, with Neymar's sister Rafaella also present; Barcelona won 85-80, but Real Madrid remains top of their division on points difference. Neymar recently captained Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates, enduring brutal challenges and an incident where Gary Medel appeared to stamp on him. Before the international break, Luis Enrique's Barcelona won their football El Clasico to move four points clear at the top of La Liga, and they now face Celta Vigo on Sunday while competing for a treble.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrant arrivals from Africa and the Middle East, with 8,480 people rescued over a recent weekend and 978 rescued in one day last week; Save the Children reports fears that 400 migrants could be missing after a boat carrying 550 capsized, though the Italian coast guard found no evidence to confirm this incident. The International Organization for Migration notes over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first quarter of 2015, primarily from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point, and at least 480 have died this year due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandoned ships.

Arsene Wenger is unsure why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool but is pleased the Chile forward joined the club instead of facing them; Sanchez had multiple elite options after Barcelona allowed him to leave and has made an immediate impact with 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges Liverpool's interest in Sanchez might have been used as leverage during negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona, though he doesn't know if the interest was genuine. The Arsenal boss praises Sanchez's qualities, efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit as top-class, noting his ability to revitalise the team. Wenger also downplays speculation linking him with Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and commends Brendan Rodgers for developing his team well after losing Suarez and Sturridge.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark), aiming to surpass the current mark of 52.491km set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February; Wiggins, who recently finished his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix, expects a sell-out crowd of 6,000 and the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with tickets priced at £49, £39, and £29 going on sale online via Sky Tickets from April 19.

Serena Williams won her singles match against Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in the Fed Cup play-off, calling it a "big eye-opener" that revealed she is not ready for the clay court season and is playing like she's on hard court; however, the US team lost the overall tie 3-2 after Williams and Alison Riske were defeated 6-0 6-3 in the doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, relegating the US to World Group II; Williams, a 19-time grand slam winner, has found the French Open her least successful major despite winning it twice; US captain Mary Joe Fernandez stated the team needs to work harder to return to the elite group next year.

River Plate is keen to sign former player Radamel Falcao, with vice president Matias Patanian stating they "dream of Falcao" and "the doors are open," though the deal is complicated; Falcao, who previously scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for River Plate from 2001-2009, is currently struggling on loan at Manchester United with only four Premier League goals this season, though he recently scored three goals in two international games to become Colombia's all-time top scorer with 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, an X Factor finalist and pop star, became the official face of Batiste's 2015 "Ready For It" dry shampoo campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The international campaign, arranged by the MILES agency, features Henderson in various hairstyles against a blurred city background and launched with a TV ad using her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement, citing her regular use of the product, while her manager Mark Hargreaves noted the natural synergy between the artist and the brand.

Aaron Siler was fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres on March 14 after arming himself during a confrontation; Torres is on leave pending an investigation. The Kenosha Professional Police Association erected a billboard featuring Torres thanking the community for support, which Siler's family and friends find disrespectful, with one stating it felt like "thank you for killing Aaron." The police association claims no offense was intended, just gratitude for support. Torres also shot Terry Knight 10 days prior, which was deemed justified, while the investigation into Siler's death continues.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants who crossed from Pakistan into Iran's Sistan-Baluchestan province near Negur; three militants were killed. The Sunni Muslim group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility, stating it aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan and has targeted Shiites. Iranian officials asked Pakistan to catch the surviving assailants, criticizing Pakistan for failing to rein in terrorists. Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism and stated its security agencies are investigating and will apprehend any militants who fled back to Pakistan. Jaish al Adal has previously attacked Iranian territory, including a 2013 attack killing 14 border guards.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs, responding to a question from lawmaker Antonio Inoki during a parliamentary session. Nakatani explained that while the ASDF scrambles jets to investigate unidentified objects that might violate airspace, these are typically birds or other non-aircraft objects, not extraterrestrial craft. Inoki, a flamboyant former wrestler and politician, had asked about scrambling jets against alien threats and research into alien visitors, and he claims to have seen a UFO himself. This exchange followed a 2007 discussion by then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba about the legal implications of defending against an extraterrestrial invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China; he had been standing on the rim to avoid sitting on it due to cleanliness concerns, causing the poorly built toilet to collapse and shatter, leaving him bleeding and requiring dozens of stitches, though he initially told police he was squatting before changing his story to sitting, and authorities confirmed the incident was an accident.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom, which police traced to him; he faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy, stemming from allegations he molested the girl from ages 9 to 13 while she slept and secretly filmed her and others, including 41 videos captured over three to four years with 34 showing victims showering, and he admitted specifically buying the camera to record the victim.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series features daughters standing still and smiling while fathers in sharp suits leap dramatically beside them, part of a book titled "Daughter and Salaryman"; the images allow fathers to express their fun side, though some older fathers appear pained, and the photos, taken at Japanese landmarks, are generating online interest despite little known about their origin.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has paved the way for Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the international set-up, as Pietersen, who was controversially axed in 2014, rejoined Surrey and took part in a team photo shoot at the KIA Oval ahead of the county championship season, showing mixed emotions but generally jovial mood while aiming to force his way back into the Test team; Surrey's campaign begins against Glamorgan on April 19.

Relegation-threatened Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week; initially fired on Wednesday after a poor run, he was reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone but was dismissed again following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday, leaving the club 16th in the standings, six points from safety; Ze Maria, a former Brazil international with 25 caps and stints at Inter Milan and Parma, had replaced Florin Marin in January as the club's third coach this season and will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar believes Radamel Falcao regrets his loan move to Manchester United despite not being happy in France, as Falcao struggled to regain his pre-injury form, scoring only four goals, making United unlikely to pay the £46million required to make the transfer permanent, and Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better staying at Monaco where he could have played in the Champions League.

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a very tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt; the offender demanded cash from the owner's daughter on Saturday, took the till and approximately $1500, and remains at large after police were called at 12.30pm.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested on Monday for allegedly having sex with a 15-year-old student in her car on consecutive nights in January; this followed her earlier arrest on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a different 15-year-old student, where she admitted kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts the previous April. The second arrest came after information from within the school led police to question a second boy, confirming the new allegations; Granado was suspended and placed on administrative leave after the first arrest, posted $50,000 bail for the second, and the school district stated it took immediate action but cannot share specifics due to privacy laws.

A large crocodile was filmed swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog wearing a red collar locked in its jaws; the video, viewed over 500,000 times, shows the croc calmly moving through the water near rocks and a footpath as crowds watch. Witnessed by New Zealander Tim Weston on holiday, the dog belonged to the local bike shop owner, who explained the crocodile likely kept the dog in its mouth for hours after the dog approached the water out of curiosity near a sanctuary located 200m upriver. While social media users reacted with horror to the video, crocodiles are common in the area due to the mangrove habitat and urbanization bringing them closer to humans.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City can avoid Premier League relegation despite their 2-0 defeat to Southampton, which leaves them with just six wins and only two points above the drop zone with six difficult fixtures remaining; he attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players like Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass, while the Southampton match saw James Ward-Prowse score a penalty and Graziano Pelle add a late goal, and manager Ronald Koeman addressed a team rules breach when Sadio Mane attempted to take the penalty.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after allowing pupils to change their SATs exam answers after the exam session finished and also altering some answers himself; this conduct breach led to a local education authority investigation, which resulted in the Department for Education annulling all of the school's SATs results for that year, prompting Guffick to resign and admit to unacceptable professional conduct, though he claimed he only aimed to improve legibility.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper struggling for regular first-team minutes with only 19 league appearances in five seasons and now third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes, enjoys a happy personal life. He married Swedish model Misse Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year; they have been dating since 2012 and have a son together. Lindegaard frequently shares moments with Beqiri on Instagram, where she regularly posts modeling photos, and he recently posted a message about enjoying a day off with her in Cheshire.

The 13 glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite being estimated at $300,000-$600,000, as the only bid came from a Sotheby's employee at $260,000; owned by Reggie Jackson, who purchased them after the stadium's final game in 2008, he hoped a new generation would own the icon, which had been installed in 1976 and removed in 2008; Jackson joked about their size and promised to visit the US-based buyer, while a New York Mets bullpen car auctioned alongside sold for $112,500, far exceeding its $20,000-$30,000 estimate.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers spoke to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after incidents involving nitrous oxide and shisha pipes, but did not discipline them and wants to draw a line under the matter; Steven Gerrard is available for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after serving a suspension, and Rodgers believes Liverpool is ready to progress after previous near-misses in the title race and Capital One Cup.

Mesut Ozil returned to London after international duty, posting a picture relaxing with his dog captioned "Home Sweet Home," and impressed in Germany's 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifier win over Georgia; he missed Arsenal's previous game against Newcastle due to illness, with manager Arsene Wenger dismissing rumors of him being in a Berlin nightclub, and is expected to start against Liverpool; the playmaker, signed for £42.5m from Real Madrid in 2013, has been in fine form since returning from injury this year, scoring three goals and providing four assists, and feels he is adjusting perfectly to English football's demanding schedule.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu insists the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, stating they are "very happy" with his performance; Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal, is only six games away from winning the title and has impressed despite speculation, with his contract running until 2016 and Barcelona capable of winning three trophies.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract with Liverpool, running until 2020, worth approximately £100,000-a-week, after negotiations that began this season; the 24-year-old midfielder, signed in 2011, has excelled under Brendan Rodgers with 13 assists and seven goals this season and is expected to replace Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard departs this summer, making him the third key player to extend his deal after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho.

Filipe Luis wants to remain at Chelsea until his three-year contract expires despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him, as he is happy at the club and has struggled to secure the left-back position; after playing for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile, his focus is now on the Premier League title run-in, where manager Jose Mourinho demands constant focus and winning every remaining difficult game.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after his knee accidentally collided with George North's head while North scored for Northampton, leaving the Welsh winger unconscious and requiring a stretcher; this was North's third concussion in two months, forcing him to take at least a month off. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final defeat to Toulon while awaiting the appeal, which was upheld after new evidence showed no foul play occurred, allowing him to return to action immediately, though he is unlikely to play until April 26.

Fiery red sunsets observed in Washington, Oregon, British Columbia, and Seattle were caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia, which started when farmers burned grass but spread uncontrollably due to strong winds on April 14, destroying dozens of villages; the smoke was carried across the Pacific Ocean by atmospheric winds, and the intense red color resulted from smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelengths of light like greens, blues, yellows, and purples, allowing reds and oranges to dominate, especially during sunrises and sunsets when light travels through more atmosphere, though these sunsets will diminish as the smoke dissipates.

Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her St. Louis driveway shortly after purchase; it was found after a tip from Mick Sexton and returned with red spray-painted rims, red detailing, and orange steering wheel accents. Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for the modifications but noted the car had a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana, requiring professional cleaning. She is creating a smoothie called "The Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant to honor Sexton, and friends describe her as vibrant, happy, and loving to make people laugh.

Manchester City players risk losing £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League, with the total squad bonus pool amounting to around £12 million; this affects key players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, who are on incentivised contracts to comply with financial fairplay rules. Currently in fourth place, City are only four points ahead of Liverpool after losing the Manchester derby, and the top three qualify automatically for the Champions League, while fourth place requires winning a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admits the team's season has disintegrated since starting 2015 joint-top with Chelsea, citing seven losses including early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League, and they face crucial remaining fixtures against West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, QPR, Swansea, and Southampton. Louis van Gaal notes Manchester United's four-point advantage and confidence in signing top-class players like Paul Pogba.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a "mini-derby" played at Altrincham's Moss Lane with free entry and around 1,000 spectators; 13 of the 22 players were English, including 10 Mancunians, and Callum Gribbin scored the winner with a delightful free-kick after being fouled, while Marcus Rashford missed chances for United and City had opportunities through Marcus Wood and Javairo Dilrosun; the result left United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, and the match showcased talented young players on both sides deserving future first-team chances.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" and an inspiration after Buffon earned his 147th cap against England, while Hart himself reached a significant milestone of 50 caps for his country. Hart, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, expressed admiration for Buffon's longevity and professionalism at 37 years old, stating he is still learning from the veteran and looks up to him. Hart also conveyed pride in achieving his 50th cap and expressed a strong desire to continue playing well for both his club and country to add to his international tally.

Chipotle has partnered with Postmates to offer food delivery in 67 cities, adding a 9% service charge and delivery fees starting at $5, marking their first collaboration with a third-party delivery service after previous refusals; Postmates uses independent contractors like Uber, and other chains including Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also entering the lucrative delivery market, while political figures like Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio have recently been spotted at Chipotle locations.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Bill and Denise Richard, are publicly urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty as a sentencing option for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges related to the attacks. While acknowledging the heinousness of the crimes and the murder of their 8-year-old son and severe injury to their 7-year-old daughter, they argue that pursuing the death penalty would prolong their family's anguish through years of appeals. Instead, they support Tsarnaev spending the rest of his life in prison without possibility of release and waiving all appeal rights, hoping to end the painful reminders for their children and allow Boston and the country to move forward.

A custom-built Boeing 747-8, costing £400 million after three years of modification, has been transformed into a luxury home for a billionaire, replacing its usual 600-passenger capacity with space for one owner and dozens of guests. The interior features multiple lounges, a master bedroom with a large bed and seating, an aeroloft with eight beds, a dining room connected to a kitchen, a conference room, and an office/guest bedroom with porthole windows, all designed with a luxury hotel ambiance instead of traditional airline seating.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station from Cape Canaveral, Florida, though the attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge failed as it landed too hard and tipped over; SpaceX founder Elon Musk stated the rocket landed but was not survivable, and the company aims to master sea landings to eventually reuse rockets and drastically cut space access costs. The Dragon spacecraft successfully delivered over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker, to the ISS, where the crew will spend about five weeks unpacking it before loading it with over 3,000 pounds of experiments, trash, and other items for return to Earth via splashdown in the Pacific Ocean.

Priscilla Presley is launching a contest with NBC's Today show for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the "ultimate wedding" at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas, where she will serve as a witness at the first wedding on April 23; the winning couple, announced next Monday, will receive a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience show, while Priscilla emphasized the event is not a joke and no impersonators are allowed, and the chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, requiring couples to submit videos or photos explaining why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side could catch Manchester City in the Premier League despite being four points behind, following a 2-0 win over Newcastle United where Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game, equalling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues this season. Henderson stated that after disappointing results against Manchester United and Arsenal, the win was vital and that Liverpool must keep winning games to pile pressure on City, who have recently faltered. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring with a fine skill in the ninth minute, and Joe Allen capitalised on a defensive mistake to score his first Anfield goal with 20 minutes remaining, securing the win. Allen described the goal as important after recent defeats and commented on a strong penalty appeal for Newcastle that wasn't given.

Roma ended their four-month home winless streak by defeating Napoli 1-0 in Serie A, with Miralem Pjanic scoring in the 25th minute from a counter-attack; goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several crucial saves in the second half to secure the win. This victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio in the race for Champions League places, while Napoli extended their winless streak to five matches and remained fifth. The match featured tight security measures due to past incidents, with residents of Campania barred from buying tickets and 1,000 police officers deployed, though no problems were reported. Roma was missing injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, and Napoli forward Lorenzo Insigne made his return from a knee injury late in the game.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played a goalless draw in a League One match at Keepmoat Stadium, a dull encounter reflecting Doncaster's uninspired season and Fleetwood's faded play-off hopes; the media team struggled to compile highlights, resulting in a very short 27-second video featuring only the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux interacts with his pet blood parrot cichlid by dipping his hand into the tank to stroke and massage the fish, which relaxes in his hand, swims away briefly, and then returns for more; he removed other fish from the tank as they were bullying his pet, and after hand-feeding it frozen blood worms, the fish became more sociable and enjoys daily interaction, becoming frustrated if neglected, with Giroux spending at least 15 minutes daily playing with it.

Ben Stokes has a fiery reputation in the England cricket team, exemplified by incidents like breaking his wrist by punching a locker after being dismissed and clashing with Marlon Samuels, which led to a productive conversation with coach Peter Moores. England values his natural exuberance and desire to compete, believing it can lead to runs and wickets, but requires careful management to control his aggression and prevent him from being pigeon-holed as merely feisty. The team aims to play Stokes as much as possible to help him reach his full potential, prioritizing his development over tactical selections like a second spinner, and believes he will only improve with experience.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium is a 33,000 sell-out, driven by high demand following Wales' 3-0 win over Israel which lifted them to second in Group B, tied on 11 points with Belgium (who lead on goal difference). The Football Association of Wales confirmed the sell-out due to overwhelming interest, and Wales prefers the Cardiff City Stadium over the Millennium Stadium, where UEFA rules prevent a venue change within 120 days of the match.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the defending champions, who qualified with a 100% record, are drawn in Group D alongside Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, opening against Italy on May 7. The squad features talented young players from Premier League clubs including Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock (first call-up) and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool's recalled pair Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold, with the full list of goalkeepers, defenders, midfielders, and forwards provided. England's other group matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City is pursuing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, regarded as one of the club's best youth talents, who has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona; Patoulidis previously rejected Barcelona's La Masia at age 12 to prioritize his studies, and City has discussed a compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to sign him for the future.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican national and transgender escort, was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March; a 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but bailed pending further questioning, while police appeal for anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death to come forward, noting she worked in London, Paris, and Miami as an escort and had recently moved from Mexico to London.

Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show accusing her friend Jamie of stealing £207 set aside for a £500 gravestone for her buried son Daniel James; a lie detector test confirmed Jamie took the money, and he later sent a Facebook message confessing but blaming his girlfriend Carol, leaving Dawn feeling devastated and betrayed.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women, children, the ill, and the elderly, with counts differing between 217 and 228; Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, though the motivation was unclear. The freed individuals were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil. This release follows ISIS's brutal campaign last summer against Yazidis, including mass killings, enslavement, and displacing hundreds of thousands, particularly after conquering Sinjar and causing a major humanitarian crisis. An international coalition responded with aid drops, rescues, and airstrikes. Yazidis, a pre-Islamic religious minority of Kurdish descent long persecuted and comprising less than 1% of Iraq's population, have suffered extraordinary cruelty from ISIS.

Harry Kane, having broken into Tottenham's first team and Roy Hodgson's England side during a remarkable season, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards; he features in a Copa90 animation video using layered still photographs to showcase his best goals and celebrations, including strikes against Chelsea, Arsenal, and his England debut, and he competes against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize at the upcoming awards ceremony.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers remaining Liverpool manager despite a third consecutive trophyless season and likely top-four finish, arguing Rodgers' future shouldn't hinge on one game and that new players haven't fully settled; Carragher believes Rodgers must identify squad improvements and make the right signings next season to achieve success, while also noting his own community work through the 23 Foundation in deprived Merseyside areas.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after security staff, who described it as resembling a prohibited item, frisked him and demanded its handover; his father criticized the action as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous," but the family proceeded without arguing to avoid missing their flight to Lanzarote; upon returning, James was bought a replacement toy, and the airport apologized while defending the confiscation under government regulations prohibiting items resembling prohibited items like replica guns.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted a detailed advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife, outlining specific requirements including being a non-drinker, non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good at household chores, cooking, and intimacy, while also enjoying the outdoors and being "a princess when need to be"; he offers benefits like free gym membership, phone, laptop, accommodation, and a company car, describes himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, successful, wealthy, independent, and willing to spend money on his partner, states former partners need not apply, and mentions the Daily Mail Australia unsuccessfully attempted to contact him.

FA chairman Greg Dyke proposes increasing the minimum home-grown players in club squads from eight to twelve and changing the "home-grown" definition to require training in England before age 18 instead of 21, facing opposition from the Premier League. Five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—support Dyke, warning that blocking the proposals risks England falling behind other nations and makes winning the World Cup harder, citing the shrinking pool of top-level English talent (only 36.8% of Premier League starters were England-eligible) despite promising youngsters like Barkley, Sterling, and Kane emerging, who lack opportunity.

Demelza Poldark gives birth to a baby daughter within ten minutes of the episode starting, with Ross Poldark gazing lovingly at her; the pregnancy timeline is criticized as unrealistic, jumping from announcement to Demelza being eight months pregnant and giving birth without showing time passing, mirroring a previous storyline with Elizabeth and prompting fan comments on the fast pregnancies in the show.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to remain focused on their own games during the Premier League relegation run-in, ignoring rivals and predictions, after back-to-back wins including Jamie Vardy's injury-time winner at West Brom lifted them three points from safety but left them bottom of the table; Pearson warns against over-optimism and emphasizes that their future is in their own hands if they maintain their own run-in.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale, set a new mammal migration record by swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Mexico's Baja Peninsula, surpassing the previous humpback whale record of 10,190 miles. Lead researcher Bruce Mate found it surprising that Varvara visited three major eastern gray whale breeding areas during her journey, suggesting she might actually be an eastern gray rather than an endangered western gray whale, which could impact population estimates and require a closer look at genetic differentiation.

Residents on Hokkaido Island's Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu were surprised to find 1,000 feet of seabed had risen 30-50 feet above sea level overnight, exposing the ocean floor; geologists attribute this to a landslide where melting ice and snow caused land to drop, pivoting the underwater area upwards. The new landmass, measuring 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide with marine organisms still attached, appeared silently without tremors or sounds, and authorities do not expect further expansion, confirming it is unrelated to the recent Nepal earthquake.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain, stating he is genuinely happy at the club, loves the city and his teammates, and wants to sign a new contract, despite a recent falling out with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea; he insists he is ready to play when called upon, though PSG's reported interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves could impact his future.

Carlos Tevez has informed Juventus he wishes to leave this summer despite his contract running until 2016, with Boca Juniors close to completing his return but requiring him to terminate his contract with the Serie A champions first; Juventus, reluctant to lose their top scorer, have accepted his desire to leave and are seeking replacements, while Tevez, who began his career at Boca Juniors in 1996, has always intended to finish there, and his international manager Tata Martino states the move won't affect his Argentina future as both clubs are strong.

Bay Munich defeated Porto 6-1 in the Champions League, advancing to the semi-finals despite Porto's two-goal lead from the first leg; Pep Guardiola ripped his left trouser leg during the match, exposing his underwear and joking about needing new ones for the next game, while goals came from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon, resulting in three vehicles colliding; two patients, a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain, were flown to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain; six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment; one person was trapped and freed by Queensland Fire and Rescue using hydraulic gear; the highway was closed for a few hours with diversions south of Fernvale.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch, expressed excitement about it on Instagram comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider, and is expected to start against league leaders Chelsea on Sunday, with Arsenal trailing by 10 points. Jack Wilshere returned from injury to the bench after five months out, but club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere's fitness record, similar to Abou Diaby's, is the main factor holding back his potential as a quality player for the club's future.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford, despite having sent off three players from both teams this season, including City captain Vincent Kompany during an international match; Clattenburg has faced accusations of favoring United but has only shown two red cards this season, both to United players (Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw), and is generally regarded as one of the Premier League's leading referees, with the derby holding significant importance for league standings as United currently lead City by a point.

Federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of assuming Billy Gordon would resign after he was accused of domestic violence and admitted to a criminal past, calling him "a little black puppet on a string"; Gordon remained in parliament as an independent, causing government chaos. Katter, of Lebanese descent, defended his statement by referencing his personal experiences with racism and comparing Gordon to federal independents he claimed became government puppets, sparking social media criticism over his terminology.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, creates dancing videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others, countering the perception that her disability limits her abilities; she has faced bullying and staring but emphasizes she is "pretty much just the same as everyone else," hoping people will look past her disability and see her as "just one of us," and despite initial medical warnings she might never walk, she now dances, drives, attends college, and has begun motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City, an MLS side with a large Latin-American fanbase, are interested in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who endured a frustrating loan at Real Madrid; Hernandez would be a commercial draw for Orlando, but eight European clubs including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan are also keen, with United willing to sell for around £8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who previously rejected an opening offer, and clubs like PSG, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord are interested if he doesn't agree to new terms.

At least three suspects attempted to carjack a man pumping gas at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday; when he fled, they poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger and set it on fire while two passengers were inside, resulting in no injuries but the car being completely destroyed, and the Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson using surveillance video while the suspects remain at large.

Charles Manuel, a Lamoni, Iowa chiropractor, surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients; he signed an agreement pledging not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years, which also requires proving the circumstances no longer exist before resuming practice, despite receiving perfect five-star patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com based on three survey responses.

A Russian SU-27 jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, with the U.S. deeming the Russian pilot's actions "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers at high speed; Russia claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder off, which the U.S. denied, and both sides plan to file diplomatic complaints; this follows a similar dangerous incident over the Sea of Okhotsk a year ago.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a car parked overnight in the Salt Lake City Marriott Springhill Suites parking lot just days before President Obama's Utah visit; the rifle was inside a hard case secured with padlocks and chains, but thieves broke the rear window, used a rope and another vehicle's momentum to rip the case free, also stealing a gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools; police found skid marks, rope fragments, and the broken case handle, recovered some stolen items at a nearby hotel, but the rifle remains missing, its serial number entered into a national database, and the Secret Service was notified, though it's unclear if security increased or if the car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times in the dining room of his home on Mugga Way, Red Hill, Canberra. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa after the attack and found evidence of his declining mental state, believing dementia and alcohol abuse compromised his brain, leading to a confused state where he wouldn't understand his actions or the consequences. Mullen pointed to fluctuating mood during triple 0 calls and a trail of faeces as indicators of confusion, though prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa might be feigning memory issues; Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack is critical to the case, as proving it could lead to a not guilty verdict.

In Everton's 1-0 win against Burnley, Ross Barkley took a 10th-minute penalty instead of the usual taker Leighton Baines, who has scored 15 of 16 Premier League penalties; Barkley's well-struck effort was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, but it didn't cost Everton as Kevin Mirallas scored the winner. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's decision, stating he allows multiple players to take penalties based on who feels confident at the moment, and praised Barkley for taking responsibility, noting Baines was happy to let him take it.

Two passengers found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico appear to have died in a murder-suicide according to Holland America Line; the cabin was secured and authorities, including the FBI, were notified and are investigating; the ship, on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise from Tampa, was discovered by cleaning staff who found the deceased after knocking on the door.

Former Holland forward and assistant coach Patrick Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, has guided the Caribbean island team to the second qualifying round of the 2018 World Cup in CONCACAF. Curacao advanced with a 4-3 aggregate victory over Montserrat, winning 2-1 at home and drawing 2-2 away, where substitute Charlton Vicento scored a crucial 87th-minute goal to avoid extra time. Kluivert's team will now face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, a World Cup losing semi-finalist as a player in 1998 and assistant to Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup, made a winning start as Curacao's coach.

Esteban Cambiasso, despite winning numerous major trophies including the Champions League and multiple league titles with Inter Milan and Real Madrid, views helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League as equally significant, comparing it to winning a cup. Leicester, seven points from safety with eight games left, face a difficult situation, but Cambiasso remains confident they can survive, emphasizing his daily observation of teammates convinces him it's possible. Having signed a one-year deal after ten years in Italy, the Argentinian midfielder has established himself as key at Leicester and is happy in the East Midlands, potentially staying beyond his current contract.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two young children, faces being banned from seeing them by her own mother, Debbie, because Gemma refuses to stop drinking, partying, and using the legal high MKat; Debbie also suspects Gemma of stealing an iPad from one child to fund her lifestyle, though Gemma denies this specific theft but admits past stealing from her mother. Debbie, who has raised the children alone since Gemma handed them over at four months old, considers Gemma unfit to care for them, stating Gemma doesn't care about her children and prefers her party lifestyle over motherhood and work.

Eden Hazard scored to give Chelsea a 1-0 lead against Manchester United after John Terry's strong challenge from behind on Radamel Falcao near the halfway line resulted in a loose ball; Cesc Fabregas collected it, played it to Oscar, whose back-heel found Hazard to slot home. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness unanimously agreed Terry's tackle was a foul that should have stopped play, with Souness calling it a "decent forearm smash" involving an elbow to Falcao's head, Henry stating he would have wanted a foul as a striker, and Redknapp conceding it was still a foul despite Falcao possibly needing to be stronger.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway Thursday morning after a rear tire blew out, but everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, was safely evacuated; Michael Barnett captured dramatic video of the incident, and Scott posted on Instagram noting their safety and that only her Bible survived in the charred back lounge, while the band's other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus, and the group is still scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing space lasers that would orbit Earth covered in mirrors to harvest sunlight, convert it into laser light using semi-conductors, and beam the energy down to power homes, potentially making solar viable in places like Scotland or aiding disaster recovery; these lasers are significantly less powerful than fictional versions and not capable of being weapons, though Dr. Quarterman acknowledges potential concerns about who controls the satellites.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile described as having a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, has gone missing after vanishing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, at 6.15pm on Tuesday. He was detained under the Mental Health Act following his conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus, an offence he denied but for which he was sentenced last August after also admitting ten unrelated counts of possessing indecent images of children. Munden, about 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, with dark hair, may have shaved his beard and police have released images of him with and without facial hair. He suffers from learning difficulties and autism, and police have launched an urgent manhunt, stressing the need to find him due to his condition and the nature of his offences.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to pay back more than $2.6 million in gifts to Donald Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, who sued Stiviano, claiming she targeted wealthy older men and that Sterling used the couple's money to buy her luxury cars and a duplex. Stiviano countered that there was nothing wrong with the gifts and she never took advantage of Sterling. The lawsuit followed Sterling's downfall due to racist remarks caught on tape where he objected to Stiviano associating with African-Americans like Magic Johnson, leading to NBA Commissioner Adam Silver banning Sterling, fining him $2.5 million, and terminating his ownership rights.

Thierry Henry criticised Arsenal's recent transfer dealings, urging the club to sign four top players—a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker—if they are to win the Premier League title, questioning whether Olivier Giroud can lead them to glory despite scoring 14 league goals, and comparing their situation to Chelsea's successful signings of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa last season.

Maurice Van Ryn, the Bega Cheese boss, pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child, and a young victim testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of years of abuse she endured, stating she kept it secret until learning he was caught, is scared for future relationships and feels her right to share her body was stolen, didn't understand it was wrong as a child, attempted suicide after speaking up, suffers from depression and self-harm, and worries about his potential release and how it will affect her relationships with men.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering well from a serious knee injury that has sidelined him since March 2014, having recently played 90 minutes for the club's Under-21s against Reading; he feels "better and better" and is over his injury worries, looking forward to the next game after impressing for the first team before his injury.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, fell 70 feet to his death after running from a taxi in Penarth, South Wales, to avoid paying the fare; he had jumped over a fence in the dark while being chased by the driver after a night out with friends who also lacked the money to pay. His body was discovered the next morning on a rocky beach at the base of the cliff by a dog walker, and an inquest recorded a verdict of accidental death, noting he likely became disorientated in the dark and was unaware of the sheer drop immediately beyond the fence.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delays received no compensation, despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit during the chaos and managers receiving bonuses up to £3,500; ministers refused blanket refunds, even to those who missed trips, and only 2,191 compensation applications were approved between April last year and January this year, totaling £203,066 with an average payout of £92.68, while specific cases like Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham, who lost nearly £1,500 on a Morocco trip due to delayed passports despite applying early and paying for upgrades, were refused compensation.

A semi-detached house in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged since the 1930s, is for sale with original features including stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black bathroom with original tiles, a dated kitchen with original cupboards and sink, a wood-panelled hallway, and vintage tins of produce like Cadbury's Marvel milk and Tate and Lyle sugar on a shelf; the three-bedroom property has a guide price of £200,000-£250,000 and will be auctioned on April 30, though auctioneers note renovation costs might deter developers despite some upgrades like double glazing.

Mogadishu, also known locally as Hamar or Muqdisho, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, and it hosts many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut extended play (EP) titled Broken, which was released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The 2007 film Shooter stars Mark Wahlberg as Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit. The TV series Shooter stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is coaxed back into action after learning of a plot to kill the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, running from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

In 1971, Charles Manson was convicted of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, carried out by his group at his instruction; he also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea; after being charged, recordings of his songs were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began his career in television with a 1974 episode of Little House on the Prairie and debuted in film with Taps (1981). He gained critical attention in the 1980s with roles in Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993), becoming a prominent leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), which earned him his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received two more Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001) before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor for Mystic River (2003) and a second for Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman (1908-2001), known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time, and after retiring, he maintained a prominent position in cricket for three decades as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has served as the chairman and CEO of Epic Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment, the president and CEO of Arista Records, and the chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, he plays in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, running for 34 episodes over two seasons; CBS canceled the show on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas, serving from 1991 to 1995 as a Democrat; she first gained national attention as Texas state treasurer by delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, was the second female governor of Texas, was known for her outspoken feminism and one-liners, and was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states independent of Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined region in the western part of the North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships are reported to have vanished under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the San Francisco 49ers' starting quarterback in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. He remained the starter for the rest of that season, leading the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, though they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as starter in 2013, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an audio or visual marketing communication using openly sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote or sell products, services, or ideas, differentiated from personal selling by its nonpersonal nature, and is communicated through various mass media including traditional outlets like newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as new media such as search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners play written by Noël Coward and was adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 – 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice, around 384-322 BC. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at seventeen or eighteen and remained there until he was thirty-seven, around 347 BC. Following Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and, at the request of Philip II of Macedon, began tutoring Alexander the Great in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur who invented the guitar pedal drum machine BeatBuddy and is currently the CEO of music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning championships in high school and college before being selected first overall in the 1979 NBA draft; he won a championship and Finals MVP in his rookie season and four more championships during the 1980s, retired and returned multiple times including in 1996 at age 36 for 32 games, and was named one of America's most influential black businessmen in 2009 with numerous business interests and Lakers ownership.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles, California in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass; they have released three albums—Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012)—and first gained popularity in 1997 through their television series and by supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I ruled Scotland as James VI from 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from 1603, maintaining the kingdoms as separate sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws under his personal union. He strongly advocated for a single parliament for both kingdoms, achieving most of his aims in Scotland but facing significant difficulties in England, including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 and repeated conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality television series Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Morgan Bentley, born 4 October 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist, most famous for narrating the UK version of Big Brother since its inception in 2000. He also did continuity announcements for Channel 4 until leaving in July 2011 to continue narrating the revived Big Brother on Channel 5, and his voice-over work and Geordie accent have made him one of Britain's most recognised voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state of Germany, bordering Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic; it is the tenth largest German state by area (18,413 km²) and the sixth most populous (4 million people), with a history spanning over a millennium. Additionally, Saxony is a German wine region, one of the northernmost in Europe and one of only two wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park was a major league baseball park located in the East End neighborhood of Cincinnati in the United States, and "In the End" is a song by American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown began her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah, with Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar in supporting roles. Released on 1 July 1994, it became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally, Divya Bharti was considered for the female lead and completed some scenes before her death, leading to Raveena Tandon replacing her. The film is also remembered for its chartbuster songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by British electronic duo Disclosure and is also singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor, recognized for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and for his directorial debut with the film Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.

Papua is Indonesia's largest and easternmost province, covering most of western New Guinea, and was previously known as Irian Jaya, and before that as West Irian or Irian Barat, encompassing all of Indonesian New Guinea.

Jennifer Lopez debuted in music in 1999 with her album On the 6 and the hit single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number-one album (J.Lo) and film (The Wedding Planner) simultaneously. Her relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her 2002 album This Is Me...Then, while her film Gigli (2003) was a failure. She then married Marc Anthony and found success with Shall We Dance? Working animals are domesticated animals trained by humans to perform tasks, which can include being family members like assistance dogs, providing tractive force such as draft horses or logging elephants, or performing jobs like milking and herding that require training for cooperation. Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, and formerly stylized as Ke $ ha, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper.
On May 5, 2017, two versions of "Despacito" were released: an electronic version produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW), initially broadcast via closed-circuit television and later via pay-per-view television. In 1987, following the WWF's Survivor Series demanding exclusivity, Starrcade became the first NWA event broadcast on pay-per-view. The WWE Network later included all Starrcades (1983-2000) in its pay-per-view section, rating the entire series TV-MA due to the violence in matches, particularly the "I Quit" match from 1985. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual pay-per-view event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director who works in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for a streaming service and the first new Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise concluded in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the National Football League (NFL) for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also played in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

The passage identifies "Excuse My French" as both the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, which is based on Salama's own experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. It also introduces Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew (born 22 October 1983), known as Plan B or Ben Drew, as a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer.
A floppy disk is a type of disk storage composed of a thin and flexible magnetic storage medium sealed within a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century, followed by a bloody civil war between 1960 and 1996 fought between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military perpetrated genocidal massacres against the Maya population.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects, and outside of medicine, they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after concluding its sixth season as cable's highest rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard is the fictional protagonist of the ABC television series Lost, portrayed by Matthew Fox; Lost is an American drama that aired on ABC from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons and 121 episodes, with the first season averaging approximately 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey, born November 4, 1969, is an American actor who has preferred dramatic roles since 2011, appearing in films such as The Lincoln Lawyer (2011), Bernie (2011), Killer Joe (2011), The Paperboy (2012), Mud (2012), Magic Mike (2012), The Wolf of Wall Street (2013), Dallas Buyers Club (2013), Interstellar (2014), The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones (both 2016); the film Mud (2012) stars McConaughey alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was best known for his books including Deep Blues, his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone magazine, his work producing blues recordings and the soundtrack for the film Deep Blues, and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912-1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after the death of his father, Gutzon Borglum, the project's original leader in 1941. Gutzon Borglum had created the sculpture's design and led the project from 1927 to 1941 with Lincoln's assistance, and upon Gutzon's death in March 1941, Lincoln took over as the construction project's leader.

The film "Underdog" was directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice talents provided by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The series follows a group of teenagers, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha, who are among the first people to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse, having come from a space habitat called "The Ark"; the narrative also centers on Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke's mother), Marcus Kane (a council member on the Ark), and Thelonious Jaha (the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father).

The Concert for Bangladesh, despite facing financial problems due to its pioneering nature, is recognized as a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid project that generated significant awareness and funds, while also providing valuable lessons and inspiration for subsequent projects like Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is cited by the media as one of India's influential filmmakers and is widely credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and altering the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate in Freeport, Illinois, on August 27, 1858; these debates were a series of seven contests between Republican Abraham Lincoln and Democratic incumbent Stephen Douglas for the U.S. Senate seat from Illinois, and the debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton drew large crowds from neighboring states due to the monumental national importance of the slavery issue.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her professional writing career with the 1976 publication of Interview with the Vampire in California and wrote sequels to the novel in the 1980s. While her early works received mixed reactions, she gained greater popularity with critics and readers during the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years, from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at age 60.

Camden is a city located in Camden County, New Jersey, and was the 12th most populous municipality in the state with a population of 77,344 at the 2010 United States Census; at the beginning of the twentieth century, its population consisted mostly of European immigrants, and a city is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.

Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film The Canyons, which was directed by Paul Schrader and was an original work; Ellis's screenplay was critically derided.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates held in seven towns across Illinois between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate.

Homer is the name ancient Greeks ascribed to the author of the Iliad and Odyssey, the central works of ancient Greek literature, while The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh on February 2, 2013, at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece band featuring Soundgarden's Chris Cornell on lead vocals and rhythm guitar, and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello on lead guitar, Tim Commerford on bass and backing vocals, and Brad Wilk on drums. Brad Wilk, the drummer, is known for his roles in Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07), starting with Greta in 1990 and co-founding Rage with Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991; as of 2016, he plays in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, consists of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, which is a concept album sequel to her first EP and was released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin and published in 1983.

The series Flaked was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, with the premiere scheduled for June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served two terms in the New York State Assembly (1784-1785 and 1798-1799), was appointed New York State Attorney General (1789-1791), served as a U.S. Senator from New York (1791-1797), and reached the peak of his career as Vice President.

Soyuz is both a rocket and a spacecraft series designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s for the Soviet space program, succeeding Voskhod and originally built for the Soviet manned lunar programs; the Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft, beginning with 8 unmanned test flights followed by 19 manned launches, and the name "Soyuz" means "Union" as in "Soviet Union," with the system remaining in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine disbanded after Zack de la Rocha quit due to growing tensions; de la Rocha pursued a solo career while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007; the same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited, performing at Coachella in April 2007 after a seven-year hiatus; their fourth studio album, Renegades, was released on December 5, 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, where it is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, as well as on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, making it the world's 14th-most-populous country and the ninth-most-populous Asian country. It borders China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast.
