Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced some of the world's highest economic growth rates, achieving the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies in 2011. Vietnam remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose two dramatic violent acts against the British in India and execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement, and he became popular as a folk hero after his death.

Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," which was directed by Nitesh Tiwari and features Aamir Khan; the title "Dangal" translates to "Wrestling competition."

James VI and I reigned as King of Scotland from 1567 and as King of England and Ireland from 1603, ruling the separate sovereign kingdoms of Scotland and England in personal union despite each having its own parliament, judiciary, and laws. He strongly advocated for a single parliament for both kingdoms but faced significant difficulties with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack, born December 26, 1970, is a New Zealand stage and screen actress known for her roles as Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, Shota in Legend of the Seeker, Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor, and Bea Smith in the Foxtel series Wentworth, where she starred for four years before leaving in 2016; she was also part of the original core cast of the soap opera Shortland Street and appeared in the film Separation City and the Australian series Rake.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred in films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2; Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed reviews from music critics but achieved commercial success, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, becoming Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the United States, and selling 757,000 copies total; it was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 with 2.3 million copies worldwide.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, which was also the band's last album to feature him; Frusciante confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister and implemented policies known as Thatcherism; she remains a controversial figure, celebrated as one of Britain's greatest and most influential politicians while debates over Thatcherism continue.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who has also established himself as a writer, contributing weekly columns on diverse topics to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who has performed acting roles and has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with approximately 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative centre. It is also Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community is an autonomous community of Spain, and its capital, Valencia, is the third largest city and metropolitan area in the country.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The TV series "Make It or Break It" was announced as ending on April 26, 2012, with its third season confirmed as the final season, and the series finale subsequently aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary field combining linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering that develops methods and technologies enabling computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text; its applications include voice user interfaces like voice dialing and call routing, domotic appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft control; significant advances are evidenced by worldwide industry adoption of deep learning methods by major companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC, who have publicized deep learning as the core technology in their systems.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 – January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman beginning in 1970; the convention was founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group of San Diegans including Alf, Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and was later renamed the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which featured Bruce Lee in the lead role.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par after Dubuisson shot a 67, while Rory McIlroy carded a third consecutive 67 to reach 15 under par alongside Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat; McIlroy, a four-time major winner, felt he played within himself and believes a low round is possible tomorrow, despite dropping shots on holes 3 and 10 and throwing his putter, before recovering with a birdie on 11th and an eagle on 13th; McIlroy ruptured a ligament in his left ankle in July, missed tournaments, returned unsuccessfully for the US PGA, played in FedEx Cup events, tied 26th at Frys.com Open, leads the Race to Dubai by 271 points over Danny Willett with three events remaining, and England's Chris Wood (-13) and Richard Bland (-12) are fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of al-Wefaq, emphasized that meaningful national dialogue requires the government to offer concrete solutions and a royal family representative, viewing Crown Prince Salman as a reformist amidst court divisions, though hardliners like the long-serving Prime Minister oppose dialogue fearing concessions; Salman insisted dialogue is necessary despite young protesters' distrust of the monarchy and opposition parties, recalling a failed seven-point agreement with the crown prince before GCC troops intervened; he criticized US policy for lacking clarity and direct pressure on human rights, urging the UK to abandon private urging in favor of public condemnation, and reiterated al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations despite bans, stressing that dialogue will fail without the release of 13 imprisoned opposition leaders convicted under torture.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge following a prolonged illness, with a private funeral and future memorial service announced; he was a highly influential conductor and leading figure in the early-music movement, founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directing it for 30 years across six continents, where the ensemble made over 200 CDs including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments and his acclaimed 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah; Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and with renowned teachers, held positions including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell; colleagues remembered him as a generous ambassador for historically informed music, a natural academic with a genial spirit, and a mentor to many leading musicians.

In 2015-16, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, a decrease of five from the previous year and the lowest figure since 1976, half the number from nine years prior; only one case remained unresolved. Sharp instruments were the most common method, accounting for 51% of homicides (29 cases), with nearly all involving knives. While the majority of accused had unknown substance status, 31% (20 people) were identified as under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson noted the continued decline in homicide and violent crime, emphasizing the need for sustained efforts across public services to challenge alcohol misuse and casual violence, support at-risk communities, and invest in projects for young people, while ensuring law enforcement has necessary resources. Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker welcomed the downward trend but cautioned about potential revisions, citing last year's figures increasing from 59 to 62 after reclassification, and highlighted a 45-year high in sexual crime and a 27% rise in attempted murder and serious assault.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, becoming the first Premier League team beaten by the Black Cats this season; Dan Gosling gave them the lead, their first goal in three games, but Sunderland equalized through Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty, and despite playing against 10 men after Steven Pienaar's dismissal, Bournemouth couldn't find an equalizer; manager Eddie Howe stated they had enough chances to win multiple games and emphasized the need to move on from the frustrating result.

Tony Abbott stated that preventing migrant deaths at sea requires stopping the boats, a policy involving detention in offshore processing camps; The New York Times criticized this as "brutal," "inhumane," and "dubious legality," urging Europe not to adopt it, while Abbott defended it as stopping drownings and referenced the tragic death of Alan Kurdi; Abbott also sparked controversy by comparing ISIS to Nazis, claiming ISIS boasts of evil unlike Nazis, drawing criticism from Australian Jewish groups who deemed the comparison "injudicious" and noted fundamental differences, though Abbott stood by his comments while stating he doesn't rank evil.

The United States suspended bilateral talks with Russia over Syria, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks on civilians in Aleppo, including targeting hospitals and hindering aid, after the collapse of last month's truce; Russia denied responsibility for incidents like the aid convoy strike and accused the US of failing to meet its own agreements and shifting blame, while heavy bombardment in Aleppo has killed hundreds and trapped 250,000 people, though both sides agreed to continue counter-terrorism discussions.

The think tank Policy Exchange proposes selling high-value social housing properties when vacant, arguing this could raise £4.5bn annually to build 80,000-170,000 new social homes, potentially reducing the 1.8 million waiting list by 500,000 and creating the largest social housing program since the 1970s. The government supports councils using existing powers to sell such stock efficiently, while Labour opposes the plan, warning it would displace hard-working low-income families, break up mixed communities, and worsen the housing crisis, advocating instead for a bank bonus tax to fund affordable homes. Critics argue the move would segregate communities, pushing the least well-off into new ghettos, though the think tank claims 73% support, including social tenants, and defines expensive housing as worth more than the regional average (21.8% of stock, 816,000 properties, potentially raising £159bn).

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea during a measles epidemic that has reached 942 cases, though an examination could not confirm measles as the main cause of death, prompting an inquest and further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment; Mr Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital and developed a rash (not on his arms) after discharge, seeing an out-of-hours GP on 17 April before being found dead the next morning. Laboratory tests confirmed a measles diagnosis, but the cause of death remains undetermined, and the family is puzzled as no close family member, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, has measles.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence against a boy under the age of 16, which reportedly occurred in 2001, and is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley played to a 1-1 draw in the National League; Guiseley took the lead through Jake Lawlor after a throw-in found James Hurst, who set him up, while Gateshead equalized when Wes York curled in a shot after Derek Asamoah's defensive error. The result meant Neil Aspin's promotion-chasing Gateshead extended their unbeaten run to nine matches, and Adam Lockwood's Guiseley maintained their five-game unbeaten streak.

Bristol Sport Ltd, owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to the delayed Ashton Vale new stadium proposal, which has been held up by a town green application; majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the plan at a shareholder meeting, following Bristol City Council's November approval, stating they will sign a section 106 agreement soon and then wait six weeks for a judicial review period, with work starting in May if no review occurs by March.

Cuadrilla suspended fracking operations in Lancashire after a second small earthquake (1.5 magnitude) occurred near the Preese Hall site, following a similar 2.3 magnitude tremor in April; the British Geological Survey (BGS) confirmed both events shared a similar location and mechanism, occurring approximately 2km deep near the drill site, and noted that injecting pressurized water during fracking can cause rock fracturing and earthquakes. The company stated it would analyze BGS data and consult authorities before deciding whether to resume, a process expected to take weeks. While fracking involves shattering shale rocks to release gas and has faced environmental controversy in the US, a UK Commons committee argued it could be safely regulated in the UK, and the BGS is monitoring the process as a precaution.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool busker who played bagpipes for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud but cleared of two others after displaying a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015; he claimed he was simply busking and the banner was a tribute to victims, while the campaign chairman stated he had permission for the banner but not for fundraising, and Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0 with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney (after a QPR keeper error), and Tom Lawrence; Ipswich dominated despite previously struggling to score, while QPR offered little attack and hit the post late. Manager Mick McCarthy praised Varney's effort and took the win, acknowledging their poor form, while QPR's Ian Holloway blamed a calamitous second goal and called for his team to be mentally tougher, with the win lifting Ipswich to 14th and dropping QPR to 15th.

Wells, 23, impressed in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66, and expressed excitement about the club's direction and the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, fifth in National Two South, defeated third-placed Chinnor 29-12 for their second consecutive win, with coach Churcher crediting Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams for leading the team and highlighting the front row and front five making over 70 tackles; the Reds face seven teams below them and league leaders Old Elthamians in their next eight games, and Churcher believes they still have significant room for improvement, calling the performance emotionally dogged but not complete and stressing the need to build on it.

Police allege 28-year-old Bangladeshi citizen Nazrul, also called Nazu, raped a 74-year-old nun; he was arrested at a Kolkata railway station after returning from Bangladesh, acting on a tip-off he was due back by train. This is the sixth arrest in the case, with eight suspects identified and two still untraced; five previously arrested accused named Nazrul as the rapist. Earlier in May, Milon Sarkar was arrested as the gang leader, though his specific role remained unclear. The attack occurred on 14 March in Ranaghat, where money was stolen from the convent school, the building ransacked, and the nun raped inside the convent.

Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, explains in an interactive video why consumers change their purchases, highlighting the impact of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports on UK shopping trends; the video also explores changing ownership and rankings of major UK brands.

Two recent scams involved callers claiming to be from BT technical support tricking victims into granting remote access to their computers, resulting in substantial financial losses: a 71-year-old woman in Sandyhills was targeted on 15 September, and another woman in Stranraer was targeted a week later. Police warn that scammers easily gain access to victims' computers and emphasize that people should never provide banking details or account numbers over the phone, as legitimate businesses never request such information.

Duffy, 37, has joined third-placed Championship side Featherstone Rovers on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions, where he has been replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler. The Scotland assistant coach will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse and the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy as a fantastic coach who did a remarkable job at Swinton under difficult circumstances. Duffy had a 16-year playing career with Leigh, Widnes, and Salford.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday to treat an unconscious rider with head injuries who was very cold from lying on wet sand; she was treated before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries decided to dedicate a radio frequency for a global satellite-based flight tracking system, replacing the current ground-radar-based system which leaves 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. This decision, prompted by the disappearance of MH370 in 2014 with 239 people on board, will allow satellites to receive aircraft ADS-B transmissions, enabling real-time tracking anywhere in the world. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new guidelines requiring aircraft to send their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, was found at 18 living with his father Bobby Hernandez in Cleveland; Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and jailed in Ohio after the FBI received a tip in October regarding the boy's college application issues, leading to identity confirmation with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children; the mother has been notified, and the father faces charges for tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012, held on $250,000 bail; authorities had suspected the father from the time of the disappearance, and a database shows he claimed to take his son to preschool in August 2002 but then fled.

A fire on 2 March at a Duncan Street site operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited (run by Asset and Land Group) disrupted train services and caused travel delays, requiring firefighters to spend several days at the scene; the Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste after the fire, though the fire service stated the operators were "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, having visited the site nine times in the last 12 months; the fire service had raised concerns to the EA in February about potential impacts, leading to joint visits and the EA's decision to revoke the environmental permit, effective 7 August subject to appeal, requiring the company to remove all waste, while the cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia introduced two bills linked to Ukraine's crisis, one allowing Russia to absorb territories like Crimea without treaties if residents express a clear will to join, bypassing existing laws requiring neighboring state agreements, and another streamlining Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians by eliminating fees, residency requirements, financial proof, and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship, enabling faster acquisition within two months instead of a year, with the stated aim of supporting Russian-speaking Ukrainians against a perceived "brown threat."

McLaren, a historically dominant F1 team with 182 wins, 12 drivers' titles, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a significant slump, aiming only for the fourth row of the grid and decent points, despite having two world champions like Fernando Alonso. Their decline began in 2013 with chassis design issues, though they now have a competitive car hampered by Honda engine problems, a stark contrast to their past successes like the 1988 season with Senna and Prost winning 15 of 16 races, and the 1998-1999 titles with Hakkinen. Past near-misses include the 2007 championship where Alonso and Hamilton tied but lost the title, followed by scandals involving Ferrari information and misleading stewards ("lie-gate"). While victories continued until 2012, titles dried up after Hamilton's 2008 win, and now wins have ceased. McLaren's history shows cycles of triumph and decline, with Ron Dennis rebuilding after founder Bruce McLaren's death and leading periods of dominance; his current return aims to arrest the slide, believing the car is strong and Honda will improve, with Dennis confident McLaren will break Mercedes' hegemony and win future titles, a hope Alonso shares for his third championship.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old from Everton, was found badly injured with gunshot wounds to the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on 27 January and later died in hospital; three Liverpool men, aged 29, 29, and 32, were arrested and remain in custody for questioning, with police believing the shooters waited outside Phoenix Gym at the market for about an hour before shooting Baker as he got into his car; detectives are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene via Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road, and are appealing to people captured on CCTV near the market to come forward with potentially key information.

The passage describes five modern ways to experience Christmas online: Everyday Church Online offers virtual services with global participation, including Star Wars-themed sermons; Guardians of Ancora is a Bible-themed game for children where players find the birth of Jesus; nativity videos like "The Digital Story of Nativity" use social media formats; Manga Messiah presents the nativity story in Japanese comic style, reaching refugees; and churches use platforms like Twitter to share spiritual thoughts, with Jesus compared to a great communicator.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take 250 hectares of common land, with backers offering 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts provided conflicting accounts, with Natural Resources Wales finding it "difficult to conclude" the replacement land was of equal value but not opposing the development overall, while developers claimed a "net gain" in biodiversity through habitat enhancement, a position disputed by the Gwent wildlife trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation before Welsh government ministers decide on the plans.

Following a 1 April report by Novaya Gazeta detailing the detention of over 100 suspected gay men and at least three killings in Chechnya, Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April, issuing a resolution threatening "retribution" against the report's "instigators," which the paper interpreted as a call for reprisals against journalists. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report, alleging detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings near Grozny. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, calling them "lies" and claiming no gay people exist in Chechnya. The paper's editor defended the reporting and urged dialogue. The LGBT Network is helping victims flee and threatens to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to act.

Investing Solutions receives housing benefit payments by finding properties for single homeless men, often referred by Fresh Start Housing, a charity founded by the same person, Samir Patel; while both operate legally, their relationship is criticized as "a new low" by homeless groups, as Investing Solutions profits by charging higher benefits than the rent paid to landlords, resulting in significant annual profits per property; the company focuses on men over 35 to access higher private accommodation rates, but tenants report poor living conditions like lack of heating and pests; Wandsworth Council is a major funder, and both organizations deny wrongdoing, stating the bulk of rent goes to private landlords and Fresh Start is independent.

Great Britain, led by Andrew Lawrence's 14 points and Ben Gordon's 13 points including three consecutive threes in the third quarter, held a lead for most of the first three quarters against the Netherlands in a pre-Eurobasket qualifying match. The Dutch, paced by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, overtook GB in the final 10 minutes, scoring the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to lead 71-60, and held on for a 71-60 victory despite a late GB comeback. Coach Joe Prunty emphasized the need for consistent effort throughout the qualifiers, noting GB lost some intensity at times, and praised Gordon's strong showing, particularly his third-quarter stretch.

Former five-weight world champion McGregor submitted a necessary waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) before the deadline regarding glove weight for his bout with Mayweather, who had previously stated he would wear 8oz gloves but had not submitted the required paperwork at that time. The NAC, which sanctioned the fight, will debate the glove weight issue on August 16, as rules typically require 10oz gloves for 154lbs bouts, though lighter gloves are permitted with waivers and justification, with fighter safety being the primary concern. NAC executive director Bob Bennett approved the fight after reviewing McGregor's background, including his UFC career, his knockout victory over Nate Diaz, his age and physical advantages over Mayweather, and his granite-like chin, despite criticism from boxing figures. Bennett also advised hiring boxing referee Joe Cortez, who oversaw an "out of control" sparring session between McGregor and Paulie Malignaggi, leading to Malignaggi's departure from the camp.

Fleet Street, historically synonymous with British journalism since the first daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published there in 1702, reached its peak as the "Street of Shame" where nearly every national paper had offices, serving as the primary source of information for the public before TV and social media; its vibrant era featured smoke-filled newsrooms, typewriters, journalists socializing and working in pubs like El Vino, and notable figures like Robin Esser and Liz Hodgkinson recalling its importance and culture; however, the decline began with Rupert Murdoch's move to Wapping in 1986, leading to other newspapers adopting computerised printing and relocating, transforming the area; the recent departure of the last journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith from the Sunday Post, marks the definitive end of this infamous era.

J.K. Rowling stated that abusive comments reminded her of the world's size and the prevalence of decent people, having previously vowed to stand up to bullies after her "personal line was crossed" by abuse; she faced criticism after donating £1 million to the Scottish independence No campaign and £1 million to Labour in 2008, being called a "traitor" and blocking abusive SNP supporters, though she clarified she responded positively to other SNP supporters and shared political common ground, joking about bringing marshmallows when someone suggested burning her books, following the SNP's election win of 56 out of 59 Scottish seats, making them the UK's third-largest party.

A University of Edinburgh study tracking 4,300 Edinburgh youth since 1998 found children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action than better-off children for the same crime, and household poverty increased offending likelihood even after accounting for other risk factors; poorer young people were five times more likely to be on statutory supervision and had a higher chance of not being in education, employment, or training by 18 due to prior police contact, while extreme poverty correlated with both being victims and perpetrators of crime; boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violence, and girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely to be involved in violent crime than affluent girls; the study highlighted a destructive dynamic where poverty increases violence risk and justice contact increases poverty risk, and despite overall crime reduction in Scotland, crime remained highly concentrated in the most deprived communities with high chronic health problems and unemployment, leading researchers to question if inequality is being adequately tackled, though the Scottish government claimed Scotland is becoming safer and is investing to protect the vulnerable.

Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in the back during a fight in the Marian estate in Kilkee early Sunday morning; Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody, while two other arrested men were released without charge; the incident involved three people entering the estate looking for Haugh, leading to a fight with weapons where others joined, resulting in Haugh's death after being taken to hospital; police recovered knives and golf clubs at the scene, including a bloodied knife blade and handle, and tension in the area was noted by a judge who remanded Walsh until 14 August.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, tweeted in May 2014 suggesting Tom Elliott harassed and shot people while serving in the UDR, where Elliott served from 1982-1992 and is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. The High Court heard Elliott has a clear MoD record and was alerted to the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster; Flanagan deleted it within an hour. Flanagan must post an apology admitting the tweet was "untrue and wholly without foundation" before the end of Friday. The court reserved judgment on compensation, and Flanagan's insurance refused coverage, which he is challenging separately. Elliott stated he was vindicated and disappointed at the delay.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff and dating back to 1874, was acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year and has increased sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 weekly to meet surging demand driven by better-than-expected sales of its new January-branded range and growth in its private label business supplying customers across Europe, the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan; Mr Hartop attributes this success to dedicated staff and expresses confidence in the company's future.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School; Wright, who claims he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot recall the traffic light color, admitted hitting her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, as his VW Golf failed to stop for a red light while she was escorting a woman and child across the road, and the trial continues with Wright expressing remorse for the incident.

NATO is conducting anti-submarine warfare exercises like "Dynamic Mongoose" in response to increased Russian submarine patrols near European coasts, highlighting a significant gap in Britain's defenses, particularly its lack of maritime patrol aircraft; the exercise simulates hunting a German U-boat (U33) acting as an unseen enemy, demonstrating the extreme difficulty of detecting submarines, which Russia now possesses a technologically advanced and quiet fleet of around 60 submarines, including newly launched vessels; while NATO employs warships, helicopters, and underwater drones to track submarines, Britain's reliance on allies for aerial surveillance exposes a key vulnerability where a Russian submarine could potentially monitor the UK's nuclear deterrent.

Since violence erupted in Juba in July 2016 and spread to South Sudan's Equatoria states, 340,000 people have fled to Uganda, making it the largest refugee flow globally that year, with 2,500 new refugees arriving daily. The violence involves killing, rape, and the targeting of civilians along ethnic lines, particularly Equatorians, as described by fleeing civilians who recount horrific experiences including being hacked to death or raped. Uganda, hosting nearly a million refugees, has generously allocated land and shelter but is now struggling with resource strains like water shortages. The UN warns the situation could constitute genocide and ethnic cleansing, calling for international pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop the massacre of civilians.

McKenzie, 38, will challenge Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. He turned professional in 2013 after quitting football two years earlier, having previously played for Norwich and Peterborough. His boxing record stands at eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The coalition's £330m NHS investment includes £33m for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital, replacing the cramped and outdated 1813 building; the new facility will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners, with the remaining funding from NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust; Matron Sue Taylor and Dr Donal Hynes highlight the need for modern facilities to improve patient well-being and care delivery, with construction planned for Bowers Lane pending planning permission and aiming for completion by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre, at approximately 13:35 GMT; he was found with a gunshot wound to his chest after being shot either in or near a black Mercedes car he was driving. The victim, described as a member of a local family, was taken to Northern General Hospital but died from his injuries; relatives had been gathering for a family celebration at the time of the attack. While recent shootings have occurred in Sheffield's Shiregreen, Southey Green, and High Green areas, this incident marks the first in the Upperthorpe vicinity.

The passage describes cyber warfare groups involved in the Ukraine conflict, including the Ukrainian Cyber Troops led by Yevhen Dokukin, who conduct DDoS attacks, hack servers and CCTV systems, disrupt rebel funding, and hijack printers; Cyber Berkut, a pro-Russian group that hacks Ukrainian government websites, disrupts elections, leaks defense data, and claims to have hacked devices during Joe Biden's visit; and Anonymous International (b0ltai/Shaltay Boltay), a Russian-linked group that publishes leaked Kremlin documents and material on Ukraine. Ukrainian officials deny using hacker data for military targeting.

Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional during farewell speeches from Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond, who emphasized Scotland's diversity and consensus on greater self-governance while joking about the Cheltenham Festival and wishing election candidates luck; McNeil warned Holyrood needed to learn from Westminster's committee system for accountability, while Annabel Goldie humorously noted she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney's faux indignation as she also stepped down.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is calling on pensioners, their friends, and families to share their experiences of residential care to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies as part of her review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. The review will examine factors including physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, and will also involve speaking to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight both good care and the impact of poor care, ensuring those accountable understand the realities of residential care to drive necessary improvements. However, Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but expresses disappointment that no provider expert with lived or professional experience in care homes is included on the main advisory panel, missing an opportunity for partnership working.

Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group increased pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to June 2016, despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m, driven by international sales growth in Europe and new markets; the Turriff-based company manufactures animal feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland selling rural products, and while acknowledging challenging agricultural times and uncertainty over Brexit, the board is confident the group is well-positioned for future challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, on Saturday afternoon, and an 80-year-old man was taken to hospital; police are treating the death as murder and urgently want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), who is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair, average build, and was believed to be wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar; police have warned people not to approach him and are conducting additional patrols in the area.

David Lipton, the IMF's second-in-command, highlighted significant economic risks in a Washington speech, stating the IMF's latest assessment shows a "weakening baseline" and the world is at a "delicate juncture," following China's trade figures revealing a 25% year-on-year plunge in exports. The IMF is expected to downgrade its current 3.4% global growth forecast when it updates its predictions in April, and this bleak outlook has ongoing consequences for businesses and industries invested in China's growth.

The council leader announced free crossings at Cowes until 2 July due to problems and to gather feedback, and ordered an audit review of the ferry project, calling its start frustrating and disappointing. Since launching on 14 May, the chain ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended by authorities for training issues, and damaged vehicles. A local business owner expressed uncertainty about survival due to lost trade and asked about compensation for businesses like for damaged cars. A transport councillor stated compensation was under discussion, downplayed the issues as teething problems for a prototype, noted electrical fixes, and mentioned ramp extensions and resolved seamanship issues.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at approximately 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man at the scene; police arrested a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention, and the road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, a London temp agency advertising for "beautiful and talented people", faced criticism for job adverts specifying physical attributes like "classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" for a personal assistant and a "sexy female driver" position; the Equality and Human Rights Commission condemned these as "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women" and demanded clarification, while women's equality campaigners called them outdated and illegal; the agency's founder defended the practice, stating clients value looks, and cited specific client requests like a "Jackie O" look for an outfit and a preference for blonde, blue-eyed women; employment lawyers confirmed the adverts were unlawful and discriminatory, potentially leading to unlimited compensation claims; despite this, the agency claimed first impressions matter and listed high-profile clients including MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Coca-Cola.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where the alleged gunman, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head and injured another student, Sirisha, who is now out of danger; Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and remanded until 12 April, and gun crimes at schools in India are very rare.

GLAAD's analysis of TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017 counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender representation increasing from seven to 16, though over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. GLAAD president Sarah Kate Ellis acknowledged progress as heartening but emphasized that numbers are only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will not seek re-election, following reports that millions of pounds in public money loaned to Northampton Town FC under his leadership as council leader have vanished, with £10.25m missing and a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities underway; the football stand remains unfinished, Mackintosh denies wrongdoing, and a majority of his local party executive had planned to deselect him, though he previously intended to stand again.

Roy Oliver, a police officer, fired his rifle into a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards; the incident occurred during a response to underage drinking reports, and footage contradicted initial police claims about the car's movement. Oliver was subsequently fired for policy violations, faces a murder charge carrying a potential 5-99 year prison sentence, and four counts of aggravated assault for the other teenagers in the car. He is currently free on bail, and if convicted, would be the first Dallas police officer convicted of murder since 1973; the victim was described positively by his coach, and the family lawyer expressed caution about the conviction likelihood.

Melania Trump plans to move to Washington with Barron after he finishes school, sparking criticism about the First Family's symbolic residence in the White House, though some support her decision as responsible parenting; historically, only Martha Washington and Anna Harrison did not live there, and historian William Seale notes keeping children in school mid-year is common, citing examples like Frances Cleveland and the Obamas who moved early; Melania may not take on a full-time first lady role like predecessors, with only cyber-bullying mentioned as a potential priority, and precedents exist for family members like Chelsea Clinton assisting in duties, while families like the Clintons and Obamas maintained normalcy by prioritizing family time and requesting privacy for children.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October, and the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) to investigate the initial police response to his call; Police Scotland is fully engaging with the investigation, and a report of Pirc's findings will be submitted to COPFS.

A yellow wind warning was issued for Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys, with gusts up to 75mph expected locally, particularly west of mountains, and the unusual easterly direction adding to the impact; forecasters warned of likely disruption to road and sea travel, and a tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road for most of Monday to allow clean-up work.

The Giants took an early lead through Derrick Walser's short-handed goal, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers; Mike Forney's powerplay breakaway made it 2-1 before Andy Bohmback tied the game again. Mike Radja scored from an acute angle and James Desmarais put the Giants up 4-2, though Nottingham's David Ling replied. The teams will meet again on Saturday night in their second game, with Nottingham leading the league on 28 points, Sheffield Steelers on 27, and Belfast on 25.

Hamilton started from the back after a broken front wing and five pit stops, facing a 36-point deficit, while Vettel finished second despite colliding with Raikkonen on lap one; Raikkonen recovered to fifth after the incident. Ricciardo briefly led after passing pole-sitter Rosberg but suffered a puncture on lap three, allowing Rosberg to win comfortably after Mercedes chose not to pit him under the safety car. The race featured multiple first-lap collisions triggering the safety car, with Hamilton's car damaged in an incident with Nasr, significantly hampering his recovery. Vettel confronted Kvyat over the first-lap incident, and Mercedes confirmed Hamilton's car lost substantial aerodynamic performance.

Thomas Hitzlsperger became the most prominent footballer to publicly reveal his homosexuality, aiming to advance discussion of an ignored topic in German football, and received widespread support from teammates like Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, football administrators including Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball, figures like Gary Lineker and Joey Barton, Bayern Munich, German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman Steffen Seibert, and openly gay politician Volker Beck, who hoped it would break the taboo; his announcement is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, which has struggled with homophobia, with Zwanziger expressing optimism that sexual orientations will soon not be an issue in football at all.

Sidwell, 34, made 32 Championship appearances this season to help Brighton achieve promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years, with his contract expiring at the end of the campaign and him hoping to sign a new deal; Brighton confirmed promotion with a win over Wigan and hold a four-point lead over second-placed Newcastle, aiming to wrap up the league title; Sidwell previously played on loan from Stoke in 2015-16 before signing a one-year deal in June 2016 and has Premier League experience with several clubs, believing he deserves another top-level opportunity after performing well and impacting the team more than expected.

Blackpool took the lead through Jamille Matt after Nathan Delfouneso's assist, but Colchester United equalized via Kurtis Guthrie from a corner. Both teams missed chances, including Guthrie hitting the post, and Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle. The match ended 1-1.

A 29-year-old player made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One; he has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, and could make his debut for Colchester United in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa, following Colchester's 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer prompted the UK Police Memorial Trust to appeal for £1.5m towards a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff who have died in the line of duty over the past 250 years. Sir Hugh Orde emphasized the need for a place for national remembrance and personal tributes, while Home Secretary Amber Rudd noted the government's commitment of £1m towards the £4m total cost. The memorial, expected to be completed by 2019, will feature a brass screen with leaf-shaped cutouts given to families as personal memorials.

Manchester United extended their lead to 15 points at the top of the table with eight games remaining after a 1-0 win at Sunderland, where Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized focusing on upcoming games like the Manchester City derby and the FA Cup replay against Chelsea, highlighting the team's record of 25 wins in the first 30 matches and 50 points from the last 18 Premier League games while pursuing Chelsea's 95-point record; Ferguson confirmed injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea at Sunderland, noted Wayne Rooney's fatigue, and stated changes would be made for the Chelsea match with Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez available, crediting Sunderland's effort but praising United's determined defending and courage for securing the win.

Google chairman Eric Schmidt stated the company pays legally required taxes, having paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, and argued it is up to the government to change its tax system if it wants companies to pay more. He emphasized compliance with existing laws and called for international tax reform, suggesting corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity occurs. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge proposed a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, potentially hearing evidence in secret. Google, criticized for routing most UK sales through Ireland to minimize UK tax payments, was noted as one of the multinationals under scrutiny. Last week, EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through automatic information exchange between tax authorities.

NHS Improvement reported that the NHS spent £3.6bn on agency staff last year but aims to reduce this by £1bn by the end of the current financial year; a 55% cap on shift rates (excluding senior managers) introduced in October has saved £600m, though progress is still 10% short of the target, and it remains unclear if spending elsewhere in the pay bill has increased; the regulator plans to publish league tables of trust performance and data on the highest-earning agency staff, citing examples of hospitals exceeding the cap, and stated that while progress is promising, much more needs to be done as the NHS cannot afford the high costs.

Longford Town Centre, originally intended as a commercial hub, now symbolizes Ireland's economic crash, but local traders like Matt O'Brien report a modest business recovery after diversifying into childrenswear and dress hire, though he advocates for free parking to attract more customers. The opposition Fianna Fáil criticizes the government for prioritizing water meters over broadband investment and accuses the Industrial Development Authority of neglecting Longford, while the government highlights the planned Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon, expected to create 1,000 jobs pending planning permission, as evidence of its commitment to the region. Despite these developments, the message remains that economic recovery is beginning but requires further support.

The tournament concludes on 29 May with eight teams playing each other twice, with the top four qualifying for the play-offs; key statistics include leading run-scorers Warner (294), Kohli (267), De Villiers (249), most sixes Warner and De Villiers (12 each), highest innings scores De Kock (108), Warner (90*), Gambhir (90*), and top wicket-takers McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), Rahman (7); four England players are involved: Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Billings (Delhi Daredevils), Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants); fixtures run from 25 April to 29 May, including playoffs and the final, with most matches at 15:30 BST unless stated.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, which often cannot be recycled and end up in landfills and rivers, causing significant environmental harm. To address this, England will introduce a 5p charge for plastic bags from October to encourage reuse; similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have already reduced bag usage, and campaigners hope this measure will decrease waste and help the environment.

Severe winds across Wales, following a yellow warning, caused a school roof to be ripped off in Rhosgadfan, power cuts to hundreds of homes, train delays and speed restrictions (especially on the Llandudno Junction to Holyhead line), ferry cancellations (Irish Ferries), bridge restrictions (A55 Britannia and M48 Severn), and the closure of National Trust properties (Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle); winds eased by evening lifting some restrictions, but Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed to Tuesday 27 December.

Michael Jordan expressed excitement about joining the Black Panther film, wanting to put a different spin on his role and reunite with director Ryan Coogler from Creed, and he anticipates working with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman; Nyong'o won an Oscar for 12 Years a Slave and Boseman plays Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War, while Jordan previously starred in Fantastic Four and Nyong'o appeared in Star Wars: The Force Awakens, with Black Panther set for release in February 2018.

The theatre, founded in 1875 and intended for performances, cinema, comedy, and music, aims to reopen in 2018 after repairs and refurbishment as part of a larger east wing restoration project transforming Alexandra Palace into a cultural destination; this includes repairing BBC studios, converting the glazed east court for public use and exhibitions, and funding of £26.6m total (£18.8m from Heritage Lottery Fund, £6.8m from Haringey Council, and £1m to be raised by the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust by summer 2017); the theatre, unused for decades, retains original decor and stage machinery and was originally created for opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned 61 senior England caps after debuting in 2009, featuring in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016. He holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46, starting in 2004, and scored his only international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. Milner stated his retirement decision was based on common sense and wished Sam Allardyce, players, staff, and supporters future success.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped their Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, house after it was engulfed in flames, discovered by her son David who was awake on FaceTime; the fire, started by rubbish burned in the wood stove, destroyed the house and killed their pets, the alarm failed to sound, and the family fled in pajamas but received community support like clothes and a bike, with Marcy crediting David for saving their lives as he woke them just seconds before the flames engulfed the kitchen.

West Ham United has been linked with a reported £200m takeover offer from an energy drinks company, while Sullivan and Gold, who purchased a majority stake in 2010 valuing the club at £105m, now own over 85% and have faced takeover interest from Qatari and Chinese groups since the move to London Stadium; Sullivan indicated a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts but stated their intention is for ownership to pass to their children.

The 22nd annual MTV Movie Awards featured fan-voted categories like best kiss and best shirtless performance (won by Zac Efron), with The Fault in Our Stars taking best movie and Shailene Woodley winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep won best villain for Into the Woods. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne; Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his kids, and Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award presented by Avengers co-stars. Clips promoting summer blockbusters like Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Avengers: Age of Ultron were shown.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 international, was loaned from Dundee United to St Mirren in July and has scored five goals this season; he previously made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and scored four times in 89 appearances for them. St Mirren manager Jack Ross described the move as a "brilliant acquisition," praising Smith as a "good, mature boy" who will provide another attacking option, as the Championship bottom side St Mirren prepare to host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council, citing warm weather, will use Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months, while extra staff repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland discovered they had been exposed to alpha radiation, specifically NORM, while removing pipework during shutdown activities; EnQuest confirmed the exposure was below 1% of the reportable threshold but advised the HSE, and both companies stated they took additional precautionary steps and conducted investigations, while the workers, including Steve Innes, expressed fears about potential health risks and alleged failures in EnQuest's duty of care, though the HSE noted the incident wasn't reportable under RIDDOR and no investigation was carried out.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007; the dealer's manager later admitted selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this piece, which was allegedly stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. Following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the ACM decided to return the sculpture based on the dealer's confession, despite lacking conclusive proof of the theft. The sculpture was one of 30 objects bought from the dealer, though only this one is suspected of being stolen, and the ASI was allowed to view the others. The museum stated it will pursue legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km, felt as far as Milan and Florence, with no immediate reports of injuries or damage; aftershocks occurred, causing phone line outages and power cuts in Garfagnana, leading to school evacuations as a precaution. Italy is prone to earthquakes, as evidenced by the 2009 L'Aquila quake that killed almost 300 people, and scientists involved in that disaster were later convicted of manslaughter for providing falsely reassuring information about the seismic risk.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, had previously doubted South Yorkshire's climate suitability for growing fruit, but has now seen results as the fruit remains attached to the plant and is not yet ripe enough to eat, causing him to express great joy.

Rockstar has delayed the game's release from 27 January to 24 March, citing the need for extra testing and polish to ensure quality; the company stated this decision was made in the best interests of the game and its fans. While waiting, online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC version, and Rockstar has released PC screenshots showcasing enhanced detail, with Los Santos and Blaine County visible at 1080p/60fps, supporting up to 4K resolution and triple monitor setups. Minimum PC specifications have also been published, and the passage notes that Grand Theft Auto V previously became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1bn in revenue within three days of its 17 September 2013 release.

76-year-old artist Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery, his first win after being shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times; the judges called the painting "quite extraordinary" but difficult to look at, depicting a leper squint from medieval churches, which Simpson explained allowed undesirables to view services; he chose the relatively small piece (7ft tall) as he was familiar with it, and plans to spend the prize money on art materials; the judge also praised its technical subtlety and emotional depth, calling it "a little bit like a tone poem"; the biennial prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

Masked assailants attacked the offices of pro-government newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit simultaneously early Thursday morning, shattering windows and leaving numerous spent bullet casings at both scenes; firefighters quickly extinguished the resulting blaze with no casualties reported, police cordoned off the areas, and are now hunting the attackers, though no group has claimed responsibility, following a similar attack on Hurriyet last September.

The 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, is joining the Mariners on a free transfer after Marcus Bignot's side reached an agreement; he spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances, and is an ex-Burton player who will officially join on 1 January, becoming Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Arsène Wenger commented that Gareth Southgate, who succeeded Sam Allardyce as England manager, has accumulated experience and is a good observer, adding that Southgate must prove his decisions are right to counter questions about his experience; Wenger dismissed his own links to the England job, stating he focuses on his current role. Southgate has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to persuade the FA to give him the job permanently. Wenger also confirmed that Arsenal defender Hector Bellerin, linked with moves to Barcelona and Manchester City, will be offered a new contract as his long-term future is at the club, and midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in August.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday; Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint investigation, and the company is fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the long-running dispute over seafarers' pay on the freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink, after the RMT union claimed some crew were paid less than £4 an hour; the new arrangement, effective next month subject to final details, will see the services return to Serco Northlink operation, ensuring all crew members receive at least the national minimum wage, ending the issue where Seatruck had argued the minimum wage did not apply to non-UK residents despite Serco Northlink's offers to bridge the pay gap.

Ken Dickie died in hospital six days after an incident at Rockley Park where Jamie Mitchell admitted intervening in an argument between Dickie and Mitchell's mother, Samantha; the couple had been in a relationship experiencing a "down phase" when Mitchell visited on 7 May, and after both men got drunk at the park bar, a confrontation occurred outside; Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault, and both Mitchell and his mother pleaded guilty to attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying about the events before Mitchell later claimed he tried to separate them causing a "tragic accident"; they will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the British songwriter nicknamed "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, died in London at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Born in Cleethorpes, his musical roots were influenced by his father playing Radio Luxembourg. After working in a frozen food factory, he joined disco band Heatwave in the 1970s, writing hits like "Boogie Nights" and "Always & Forever." His work caught Quincy Jones's attention, leading him to write three songs for Michael Jackson's breakthrough album "Off The Wall" ("Off The Wall," "Rock With You," "Burn This Disco Out") and three more for "Thriller" ("Thriller," "Baby Be Mine," "The Lady in My Life"), helping make it the best-selling US album ever. Temperton also wrote for artists like Anita Baker and Donna Summer, won a Grammy in 1990, and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. He is survived by his family and was mourned by tributes from figures including Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan, and Gilles Peterson.

Researchers including Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott discovered over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" in Acre state, Brazil, dating back possibly 2,000 years, revealed by modern deforestation after centuries of concealment by bamboo rainforest. The multi-university team found these ditched enclosures are unlikely villages or defensive structures due to few artifacts and non-defensive layouts, suggesting they were sporadically used ritual gathering places, though their purpose remains unclear. Dr Loader's analysis of soil samples, phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon isotopes indicates the geoglyphs were constructed among taller vegetation, making them likely invisible above the forest canopy, unlike other ritual sites. This research challenges the notion of pristine pre-European Amazonian forests, revealing evidence of human influence over 6,000 years where people concentrated on economically valuable trees like palms instead of large-scale burning, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products, with tantalizing evidence that some remaining forests retain a legacy of these ancient agroforestry practices.

Nick Kyrgios defeated Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of the Shanghai Masters, ranked a career-high 12th and coming off a Japan Open title win; he attributed his subdued performance to feeling tired and bored, citing fatigue from travel, poor sleep, and a long commute to the courts, while also referencing a past incident at the same tournament where he was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst.

Scientists and charities advocate for expanding the HPV vaccination programme in Wales to include boys, arguing it will protect against increasing head and neck cancer cases, particularly affecting younger non-smoking men, while the current programme only vaccinates girls aged 12-13 against cervical cancer; organisations like Tenovus Cancer Care and medical groups are urging the Welsh government to act now, though the government states it is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering changes.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil, died from gamma delta T-cell lymphoma after being diagnosed the previous August. He documented his journey and treatment on the Facebook page "Jak's Journey," which gained over 28,000 likes and highlighted his positive attitude, love for Rangers FC, meetings with players, and visits from other sports teams and celebrities. He briefly attended a school prom held in his honor but had to leave due to feeling unwell; at the event, his family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. In January, his cancer spread throughout his body, leading doctors to stop treatment, and Jak wrote about fighting the pain without knowing his prognosis. His family encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, and before his death, he enjoyed experiences like visiting the Kelpies and going on a supercar ride; a charity football match was planned for after his passing.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 with Abdallah El Said scoring in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah, after Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside earlier. This win means Egypt plays Ghana for top spot in Group D, while Uganda are eliminated from their first tournament since 1978; Ghana secured their quarter-final place with a 1-0 victory over Mali earlier that day.

Lancashire County Council is considering land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College, both currently unused, for a new railway station following a Network Rail comparative study; Skelmersdale lost its passenger station in 1956 and is one of the largest northwest towns without one. The council plans two direct trains per hour to Liverpool in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, with Councillor John Fillis calling it an "exciting step forward" and noting the preferred site allows future expansion with good highway access. The council will now acquire the relevant land.
Police discovered plants during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, describing the setup as an "elaborate grow house," and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old unidentified woman was found seriously injured on a pavement in Hamelin after being dragged by the neck through several streets; she underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner, a German citizen of Kurdish origin from nearby Bad Muender, later handed himself in and is now in custody. Both the victim and suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin, and police have secured the area and are seeking witnesses, though the motive for the attack remains unclear.

Research by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found that women ask for pay rises as often as men, but are 25% less likely to receive one when they do ask, based on a study of 4,600 workers comparing full-time males with full-time females and part-time males with part-time females. The study, using 2013-14 Australian workplace relations data, found no support for the "reticent female" theory or the idea that women avoid asking due to concerns about stereotypes or upsetting bosses, controlling for employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications. Professor Andrew Oswald expressed surprise at the findings, suggesting possible discrimination, while noting that under-40 women and men had similar success rates, indicating potential generational change in negotiation behavior.

Oxford City Council has spent money on ground investigations for new burial sites but found no suitable locations, with the Wolvercote and Botley cemeteries expected to be full by 2018 and 2021 respectively; the council continues exploring options but faces challenges like insufficient land size, poor ground conditions, high water tables, and site covenants, and after these cemeteries fill, only reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and ash interment will be possible, as the last increase in burial space was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, featuring acts including The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean; visitors can use an app to trigger online information like videos and band interviews from signs and posters on their phones and tablets, allowing both attendees and people worldwide to access content, buy tickets, and experience the festival atmosphere.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day; veterinary staff pronounced him dead, and the British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," noting such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Although Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia symptoms causing overheating and wobbling, he showed no such symptoms on the day of his death, and the report concluded he was the victim of a rarely seen haemorrhage.

Davina Ayrton, now 34, denied the charge of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004; she will be sentenced on 4 March after being remanded into custody, likely at a male prison in Winchester due to concerns about self-harm and failing to attend court. The court heard that Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, changed her name in 2012, discussed her sexuality during the trial, and had not undergone physical changes or taken medication; she confessed to the attack to a care home worker in Fordingbridge, Hampshire, in 2014. The victim, who had consumed alcohol, recalled shouting at Ayrton to stop the attack while her friends slept nearby. Judge Ian Pearson described the case as unusual and difficult.

Novak Djokovic and his Serbian partner lost a doubles match 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, occurring a day after Djokovic was defeated in singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro; this followed Djokovic's surprise third-round Wimbledon loss to American Sam Querrey in July, after which he won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

Saturday's event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, will feature over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US, who must use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and people shapes; last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, is returning to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old capped 16 times by Wales, has not played since suffering a serious foot injury in September during a World Cup warm-up with Italy. He is close to returning, undergoing a pre-season stage of recovery, and aims to be fit before the Six Nations, potentially a couple of weeks earlier than the early February target discussed with physios. Wales begins their Six Nations campaign against Ireland in Dublin on 7 February. Webb has renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region where he debuted in 2007, as he wants to be in the best position to play for his country.

US border agents near Sumas, Washington, interrupted an MDMA smuggling attempt from Canada on Tuesday morning, arresting Jeffrey Laviolette immediately after one suspect fired at agents and fled; authorities later found 58lb of ecstasy in the backpacks, including a fake ID, and arrested Nathan Hall in Canada. US officials also arrested Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, allegedly involved in transporting the drugs to San Francisco, with all defendants facing conspiracy and drug charges in a known smuggling area.

Childline counselled over 4,500 children about online abuse in the past year, a significant increase from 2,400 in 2011-12, though the actual number suffering is likely far higher; some victims as young as seven reported torment, abuse, and fear of school, with online trolls causing misery and humiliation. Dame Esther Rantzen emphasized that cyberbullying follows children home and worsens without intervention, requiring adults, parents, and teachers to protect them and schools to take the problem seriously, while children must seek help; the report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance which is working with parents, schools, and organizations to combat the issue.

The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution declaring Israeli settlements illegal and a major obstacle to peace, infuriating Prime Minister Netanyahu who accused the White House of drafting and pushing the resolution, a claim the US denied; Israel responded by recalling ambassadors, cutting aid, and cancelling a visit, while the Jerusalem Planning Committee postponed a vote on 492 new settlement homes at the request of Netanyahu's office to avoid further straining relations with Washington ahead of Secretary of State Kerry's speech, which is expected to address critiques of the Obama administration; Palestinian President Abbas welcomed the resolution as paving the way for a peace conference in France.

Prince William praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch in a BBC interview on the eve of her 90th birthday, while a picture of the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George was released for commemorative stamps. The Queen visited Windsor's Royal Mail office, marking the postal service's 500th anniversary, and later attended a bandstand opening where children sang Happy Birthday; political leaders like David Cameron and Jeremy Corbyn also wished her a happy birthday. Her actual birthday events included unveiling The Queen's Walkway plaque and lighting a beacon, triggering over 900 worldwide beacons, followed by lunch with the Obamas. Republican group Republic criticized the BBC's coverage as unbalanced and celebratory.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup, with Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scoring before half-time; Cheltenham had chances via Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header but failed to score, while West Ham made seven changes and could have won by a larger margin; Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the competition.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, failed to spot him while turning his VW Transporter right; Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years, with the victim's family accepting it was a momentary lapse and seeing no value in jail time, while Werner expressed remorse and offered no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, London, joined the Islamic State-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed in Syria after leaving the UK in January, posting propaganda videos and gruesome content, including one where he held a severed head; he later tried to sneak back into the UK by faking his death online and was arrested at Dover with the help of his cousin Tahir Bhatti, who pleaded guilty to assisting an offender; Khawaja faces possible life imprisonment for terrorism-related offences and admitted four charges, while an additional charge of soliciting to murder lies on file.
