Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season as they finished eighth; he is Barnsley's third signing for next season, preceding their League One play-off final at Wembley, and caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised his pace and attacking style, noting he fits their play, while Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham.

Sealed bottles of "Vanish" detergent have been washing up on Cornish beaches like Poldhu Cove, with National Trust volunteers clearing them due to wildlife risks, as some have leaked; while a container from the MV Blue Ocean ship went overboard near Land's End in May during storms, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency states there is no direct evidence linking these bottles to that container, only circumstantial evidence; Cornwall Wildlife Trust is highly concerned about the impact on marine life, Cornwall Council advises keeping children and dogs away from the bottles and partners are monitoring beaches, and the National Trust believes the bottles came from a container lost in stormy seas.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at approximately 14:00, resulting in minor injuries for several people; the road was closed and diversions were implemented via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, while Police Scotland stated inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season to help Bolton Wanderers secure promotion to the Championship by finishing second in League One; having joined from Charlton in 2014, he has made 83 appearances in all competitions, and manager Phil Parkinson noted he was a "forgotten man" who made an "excellent contribution" towards the end of the campaign; Dervite has signed a new contract with Bolton, following the promotion and similar moves by David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being prepared to "concede everything" on Brexit, while Labour's Baroness Smith countered that the Lib Dems were giving people "false hope"; the parties had previously allied to defeat the government on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but this cooperation collapsed when MPs rejected those amendments, with Lib Dems insisting on them and Labour deferring to the Commons. A Labour source dismissed the Lib Dem stance as "grandstanding" for campaign leaflets, building false hope when MPs were ready to support the government, while Lib Dem Baroness Ludford accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and enabling a hard Brexit. Despite a history of working together on issues like higher education and housing, both sides acknowledged current tensions, with Labour predicting "residual tensions" and Lib Dems remaining open to future cooperation on shared issues.

Defense is a low electoral priority for most UK parties, ranking far behind issues like the economy and NHS, despite growing global instability and threats. Significant military cuts have reduced the Army to 82,000 personnel, the Royal Navy to 19 warships, and the RAF to seven frontline jet squadrons, creating capability gaps like the lack of Maritime Patrol Aircraft. UK defense spending is projected to fall below NATO's 2% GDP target, potentially to 1.5-1.7% by the end of the decade, damaging credibility with allies like the US. Future cuts are likely as major parties promise deficit reduction without protecting the defense budget, though commitments like Trident renewal (supported by Conservatives and UKIP, with Labour considering reducing submarines and SNP/Greens opposing it) and aircraft carrier plans constrain savings. Concerns persist about under-resourced forces, such as the carriers lacking sufficient crew and planned F-35 jets.

Barcelona insists they committed no offense regarding Neymar's transfer, stating they paid £48.6m initially but his parents received £34m, with the total cost including wages and fees reaching £106.8m; former president Sandro Rosell resigned over misappropriation allegations and is under investigation, while a judge ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer; Barcelona denies any tax crime and made a complimentary tax payment of €13.5m to defend their reputation, though the case's status is unresolved; Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches.

Michael Luciw, 27, died when the van he was a passenger in was hit by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died; Luciw's family, including his mother Andrea Shelton and brother Simon, advocated for regular driving tests for older drivers, citing slowed reactions and the need to prevent such incidents, while his colleague Andy Harrington, who was driving and seriously injured, also supported mandatory medical exams for retired drivers; currently, UK drivers over 70 only complete a self-assessment form every three years without a medical or driving test, and the DVLA maintains there's no evidence older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents, with Age UK arguing it's vital older people can drive safely for as long as possible to maintain independence.

The independent review of transvaginal mesh implants concluded procedures should not be offered routinely for pelvic organ prolapse, recommending patients receive multiple treatment options and information for informed choices, and mandatory reporting of adverse events; however, two patients quit the review group in protest, claiming the report was watered-down, and Professor Alison Britton will now examine the review process; the health secretary confirmed the recommendations would be implemented despite calls for a ban, stating the power to ban lies with the UK regulatory agency; the review chairwoman apologized for failing to achieve consensus, noting strongly held differences existed from the start, and over 20,000 women in Scotland have had implants, with more than 400 currently taking legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5K record by 14 seconds, running 14:49.12 at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow; McColgan initially questioned if the record would be ratified due to concerns about the mixed race format and potential lack of drug testing, but British Athletics confirmed the time was expected to be official. McColgan praised Muir's world-class potential, noting she could run faster, and compared the race to her own record-breaking run, adding it was a bonus that a fellow Scot broke her record; Muir has also broken her own British 1500m record and reached the Olympic final.

Jung won the gold medal aboard Sam, a late replacement after Fischertakinou contracted an infection in July; France's Astier Nicolas earned silver and American Phillip Dutton took bronze, while Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th despite competing just 10 months after being placed in an induced coma following a fall, having led after dressage but dropping to 21st after cross-country time penalties, and Ireland's Jonty Evans placed ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in two hours and 39 minutes, clinching the match point at 20:57 BST to reach the last 16 for the 11th time, despite Fognini having five set points in the fourth set which Murray overcame by winning five consecutive games; Murray will next play Benoit Paire, while fellow Briton Johanna Konta also reached the second week with a win; Murray described the match as tense and up-and-down, expressing relief to finish in four sets before darkness required the roof, and noted he felt okay but needed to improve his movement for the next round.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, where police found people still present and till receipts showed alcohol served until 04:49 BST; the judge ordered the bar's closure for three months, and license holder Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, with a defense solicitor noting lax adherence to licensing laws; the judge criticized O'Neill's "appalling record" and inability to impose a custodial sentence, fining her £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt launched his party's manifesto with the statement "domination doesn't work, partnership does," aiming to make the election a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle, though his comments about preferring to enter government with the SDLP over Sinn Féin shifted focus; he dismissed regret, reaffirmed his position after colleague Danny Kennedy distanced himself, emphasized confidence in his stance and candidates' differing vote transfer positions, highlighted the £85,000 daily cost of the current DUP/Sinn Féin government, and detailed manifesto priorities including tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritising the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, guaranteeing no Brexit-related group is worse off, and cleaning up Stormont by addressing incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion will go before the Northern Ireland Assembly to pardon men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales under "Turing's Law". This motion, expected to contain the same provisions, will allow both posthumous pardons and enable living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons, aiming to ensure equal treatment and right past wrongs as soon as possible.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish 1500m record of 4:19.12 by finishing second to Faith Kipyegon, breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and moving her to second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57; Muir expressed pleasure at achieving the record, noting it was her first race of the season over the distance and that she holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records, with her husband's wife congratulating her, while Muir aims to secure an Olympics place at the British trials in Birmingham, started her season with an 800m win in France, and fits her training around her veterinary studies where she recently completed her fourth year.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC concluded that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, suggesting the Russian state sponsored the plot with reasons to wish him dead; Litvinenko was poisoned with polonium-210 in tea during a 2006 meeting with the suspects, dying nearly three weeks later, and Horwell stated the polonium evidence indicates Russian state participation, though not necessarily direct involvement by President Putin, with possible motives including Litvinenko's defection and criticism of Putin; Horwell also noted Litvinenko was poisoned twice, the public health risk from polonium exposure in London is unknown, the suspects left a polonium trail with no credible defense, extradition attempts failed, and they remain in Russia.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed Australia's Test captain on an ongoing basis following Michael Clarke's retirement after the Ashes defeat, with David Warner, 28, named as vice-captain; selectors praise Smith's extraordinary talent and regard him as Clarke's natural successor despite the big shoes to fill, noting his prior Test captaincy experience and impressive record of 2,952 runs in 32 matches at 54.66, while Warner earns the vice-captaincy due to his maturity and development despite past disciplinary issues, and both will lead the team in limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

Mr. Farron refused to directly answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, stating instead that "we are all sinners," but emphasized his passion for LGBT-plus rights and that defending equal marriage would be a top priority. He also expressed a desire to extend marital rights for transgender people, specifically addressing the "spousal veto" issue. Regarding his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill, he explained it was due to concerns about "protection of individual liberties" when an amendment was defeated, though he did not specify those concerns, while reaffirming his absolute support for equal access under the law for all people regardless of sexuality.

Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses, but Accord Healthcare is now using the plant for pharmaceutical production, hoping to rehire many former Sanofi staff; a spokesman expressed confidence in the investment's "extremely positive" impact on the area, and Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes called the announcement "fantastic news" that strengthens the region's science and healthcare reputation, noting Accord is a global player developing, manufacturing, and distributing over 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries.

Richard Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract on Friday, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme; Stephen Flynn, SNP opposition leader, stated these departures indicate the council's difficulty retaining senior staff and predicted more departures soon; Mr. Ellis was the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, Mr. Monaghan heads the chief executive's office, and Mr. Sutherland heads human resources and customer services; council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants detonated explosives at a hospital gate and opened fire, killing staff and patients; commandos killed all four attackers after hours of fighting. The Islamic State (IS) claimed responsibility, while the Taliban denied involvement; over 50 people were wounded, and President Ghani condemned the attack as violating human values. This marks IS's first direct engagement with security forces in the capital, using tactics more typical of the Taliban, suggesting increased resources and training. IS, active in Afghanistan since 2015, has previously targeted civilians and government sites like the Supreme Court, while the Taliban has also carried out attacks.

Martin has quit road racing on Hondas for the remainder of the year following a disastrous TT experience plagued by mechanical problems with the Firebike, where he felt he was primarily acting as a test rider; he clarified he hasn't given up racing entirely but will focus on classics and "oddball stuff" instead. He did not race at the North West 200 after his team-mate's practice crash and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix, a decision he accepted as the team withdrew him based on the bike's lack of competitiveness confirmed during testing at Cadwell.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 declared governor posts, marking a historic defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Adamawa, though it retained Rivers State and won eight governorships mostly in the south-east; elections were not held in seven states, with Taraba still outstanding and Imo declared inconclusive due to spoiled ballots exceeding the victory margin; the APC also retained Lagos state, a first for the president's party since 1999; while elections saw some violence, particularly in southern states, they were more peaceful than previous years; the PDP's decline was attributed to its 16-year rule, corruption allegations, failure to address the Boko Haram insurgency, and voter fatigue, leaving it as a regional party concentrated in the south-east and Niger Delta.

Mighty, a US environmental group, accused Singapore-based Olam and its majority shareholder Temasek of unsustainable palm oil practices contributing to Southeast Asian haze, alleging Olam sourced from rogue companies and created a secretive market; both companies rejected the claims, with Olam stating it has a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and Temasek asserting it doesn't direct Olam's operations. The passage highlights the global palm oil industry's troubled environmental record and challenges in policing suppliers, while also mentioning Mighty's allegations that Olam bulldozes rainforests in Gabon for plantations, which Olam countered as responsible and transparent development.
On 27 August 2016, a restaurant began serving puppy platters following the introduction of a new law permitting dogs to eat in restaurants, provided they were outdoors.

Forward Fernando Forestieri (knee) is a doubt after playing only from the bench in the last two games, while Derby County striker David Nugent (groin) could return after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield hopes for a recall after coming off the bench to score a late equaliser against the Terriers.

Pakistan's telecom regulator lifted the YouTube ban after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version, directing all ISPs to restore access; Google provided an online process for the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to request blocking of offending material, though YouTube clarified such requests would be reviewed against community guidelines and not automatically granted, with removals recorded in their Transparency Report, while activists demanded transparency about the deal terms; the original 2012 Supreme Court ban followed protests over the blasphemous film "Innocence of Muslims," and Google also announced local versions for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, shares nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino, leading LFA boss Musa Bility to demand Scala's withdrawal by Thursday, citing Article 7.4 barring conflicts of interest; Scala voluntarily stepped aside in 2015 due to nationality with incumbent Blatter, but his spokesman argues no conflict exists now as there is no incumbent president among the five candidates, though Bility threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala doesn't resign, emphasizing the need for fairness after FIFA's turmoil, with the election to replace Blatter occurring in 18 days in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a flashover explosion caused by a buildup of toxic fumes and ignition in a paint-spraying area at Harford Attachments, which makes buckets for diggers, shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday; their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon, and significant progress has been made with forensic inquiries and witness statements, while the Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to Caf after lodging complaints about a controversial refereeing decision during their 2015 quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea, which they disputed but did not accuse Caf or the referee of corruption. Morocco, banned from the 2017 qualifying draw after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, had their ban overturned and fine reduced by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Both teams are now participating in the qualifiers, with Tunisia drawn in Group A and Morocco in Group F, and Tunisia noted that qualifying would set a record of thirteen consecutive Nations Cup appearances.

Chelsea won 3-1 at Etihad Stadium after a mass fracas in the 95th minute; Manchester City's Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for a high challenge on David Luiz, and Fernandinho got a three-match ban for clashing with Cesc Fabregas, who faces no further action; City manager Pep Guardiola apologized, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales has some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world, leading to a pilot plan in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd targeting patients whose GPs suspect cancer but show no urgent signs or symptoms, inspired by successful Danish diagnostic systems. Concerns exist that patients without clear symptoms face long waits for diagnosis due to inefficient referral pathways, potentially delaying treatment until cancer is advanced. The pilot involves GPs potentially referring patients to Royal Glamorgan Hospital within seven days for coordinated tests, aiming to see about six patients weekly, with a similar clinic planned for Neath Port Talbot. Currently, only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms in the Cwm Taf area receive a diagnosis, and the goal is to reach patients with less obvious symptoms sooner. If the six-month Cwm Cynon pilot succeeds, other health boards will implement the service.

England won the second Test against Pakistan by a large margin at Old Trafford to level the series, scoring 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared. Joe Root was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with his bowling contributions. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's play, while coach Trevor Bayliss noted his improvement after poor shots at Lord's. Former players Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott highlighted England's dominance and Pakistan's broken spirit. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment, citing poor shot selection and a lack of confidence, but noted the team's mental strength. Pakistan play a two-day tour game against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August.

Warren Gatland leads the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with Rob Howley on his backroom team, while McBryde assumes head coach responsibilities for Wales tours for the third time, expressing honor and excitement about the opportunity; the Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour and is in advanced discussions to finalize the management team, with chairman Gareth Davies believing the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team and invigorate players through the challenging New Zealand tour.

Hull City defeated Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game league losing streak but remaining in the bottom three. Charlie Austin gave Southampton an early lead with a sixth-minute penalty after Hull lost both starting strikers, Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, to first-half injuries. Robert Snodgrass, introduced as a substitute, scored Hull's equalizer in the 61st minute and then assisted Michael Dawson's header two minutes later to complete a turnaround. David Marshall made several crucial saves for Hull, and Sam Clucas produced a remarkable goalline clearance in stoppage time to preserve the win.

A fatal motorcycle crash occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 road near Thornton, close to Woodhall Spa, resulting in the death of a local motorcyclist whose details were not further released; the tractor driver involved was uninjured, and Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses. The B1191 road was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power revealed by covert recordings to end "agony" before June elections, claiming to defend national interests, but this move was condemned as illegal by opposition leader Zaev and as violating the rule of law by EU Commissioner Hahn, who warned it endangered Macedonia's EU membership ambitions; the crisis stems from recordings released since 2015 by Zaev, which allegedly show ministers plotting vote-rigging and cover-ups, and accuse the government of widespread corruption, wiretapping, and mismanagement, accusations the government denies while counter-accusing Zaev of destabilization.

Curtis and Paul Williams will temporarily manage Swansea after Bob Bradley's sacking, with Paul Clement the preferred new manager appointment; Swansea fears relegation to the stronger Championship, making a swift return difficult, especially without retaining top players like Newcastle; the club rose from near-bankruptcy and relegation threats to Premier League promotion in 2011 under managers like Martinez, Rodgers, and Laudrup, but Curtis believes the club has lost its way and the "Swansea Way" since Laudrup left in 2014, despite having a squad good enough to stay up, which Curtis reminds new players about using the documentary "Jack to a King" to emphasize the club's history and importance to the area.

Dagenham & Redbridge needed victory to avoid relegation but lost 3-2 to Leyton Orient, who scored through Jay Simpson and a winner from Armand Gnanduillet after Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona pulled Daggers level; this relegated Daggers to the National League despite their 2010 League One promotion under manager John Still, who now faces the challenge of gaining promotion next season, while Orient remain in play-off contention under interim manager Andy Hessenthaler, who emphasized professionalism and the need to win games, and Still criticized his team's lack of organization and discipline.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, 36, is returning to the club as a youth coach in February, his first job since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. He made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and left in 2015, having won the Champions League, Uefa Cup, FA Cup, and League Cup multiple times. Manager Jürgen Klopp described the appointment as "wonderful news," noting Gerrard wants to be a manager in the future and is ready to learn the role, combining his playing experience with his ongoing work towards the required Uefa A coaching licence. Gerrard had previously been linked with the MK Dons job but felt that opportunity came "too soon."

McManus scored early to open the scoring, followed quickly by Ross Forbes' deflected strike, giving Morton a two-goal lead; Kyle McAusland pulled a goal back for Alloa before half-time, but McManus and Denny Johnstone added late goals to secure a comfortable win for the hosts.

Of inspectors found children taught in squalid conditions in three closed Birmingham places, with operators facing up to 51 weeks in jail; ministers consult on regulating places teaching 6-8+ hours weekly, while Sir Michael Wilshaw expressed shock and concern abuse or radicalization risks, calling the cases the "tip of the iceberg"; 18 unregulated schools (mainly Muslim communities) were investigated, three closed with owners under investigation; places teaching >20 hours must register, though some "flexi schools" operate legally, but Ofsted suspects others abuse home education laws; Sir Michael criticized officials for slow action and confusing advice; government funded six inspectors to investigate, applying to all religious groups; the education secretary intends prosecution requiring her consent, and the consultation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin operates from the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, preceding proposals for the region's first whisky distillery since 1837; lead distiller Kate Macinnes notes their small-scale production in a cowshed, using local Teviot valley botanicals to capture the Borders 'terroir', while John Henderson of Born in the Borders highlights it as a natural companion to the existing brewery and praises the local sourcing ethos; the gin is named after the legendary heroine Lilliard of the Battle of Ancrum Moor fought nearby, reflecting the landscape and the female production team.

Gary Green, over twice the legal drink limit after consuming the equivalent of 13 pints of beer, reversed a vehicle into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm in August 2013, causing his death. Green, who had previously admitted failing to ensure safety, was prosecuted under health and safety legislation for the incident on private land and jailed for 16 months and two weeks. Harry's mother described the family as "changed forever," emphasizing that drunk driving is unacceptable anywhere, and expressed the family's ongoing grief and hope to remember Harry beyond the accident. The Health and Safety Executive investigation found Green's behavior "reckless" in the "extremely tragic" case.

Luis Suarez's appeal to CAS against his FIFA ban was partially successful; while the nine-match ban was generally confirmed, CAS ruled preventing him from all football-related activities was excessive, allowing him to train and play in friendly matches, attend games, and participate in promotional activities, though he must still serve the remaining eight competitive international games and his competitive Barcelona debut is likely against Real Madrid on 26 October; the CAS ruling emphasized proportionality, with reactions from FIFA, FIFPRO, and legal experts noting the sanctions were maintained but training was permitted, and Suarez's legal team argued FIFA misapplied rules and the sanction was disproportionate, while the passage also details Suarez's history of biting incidents and other disciplinary offenses.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania, who carried his wife Neringa, after training for a week on an athletics track; the challenging 380-metre course involved hurdles over haystacks, scrambling up a steep slope, and dodging water pistols, and while not requiring marriage, saw various competitor combinations including men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman; as winners, Rich and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond reassured Mike Hedges that while the scrapping of the paper car tax disc in October 2014 and the introduction of an electronic payment system via direct debit will likely reduce refund processing and necessitate changes to job roles at the DVLA, any resulting staff reductions will be managed through redeployment to other areas of the business rather than redundancies, which Hedges welcomed as providing comfort to concerned employees despite his disappointment about fewer job opportunities.

Hungary's foreign minister rejects EU interference in domestic issues, stating Hungary won't backtrack on laws concerning asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education, with Poland pledging to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary; the EU objects to these laws, particularly the Higher Education Law threatening the Central European University and draft NGO legislation, while thousands protest and the EU warns of potential action.

Emma Watson stars as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast and Luke Evans as Gaston; Josh Gad plays Gaston's sidekick LeFou, Kevin Kline is cast as Maurice, and an unnamed star will portray Mrs. Potts. Bill Condon directs the film, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and is set for a US release on 17 March 2017.

Adrian Gill, a journalist described as a giant among journalists and the heart and soul of the Sunday Times where he worked since 1993, died after battling cancer, which he humorously termed the "full English" of cancers. Despite his illness, he felt lucky and stoical, and his final column about coming to terms with his diagnosis was published posthumously. Colleagues praised his incomparable wit, dazzling and fearless writing, intelligence, compassion, and unique style, noting he never produced a boring sentence. Gill was known for dictating copy due to dyslexia and was a controversialist whose articles often caused outrage, such as comments about the Welsh, Rhyl, Norfolk, the Isle of Man, and Clare Balding, leading to censure. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, he overcame dyslexia to become a writer, starting with art reviews before joining Tatler and the Sunday Times. He was married to author Cressida Connolly (1983) and former Home Secretary Amber Rudd (1991, divorced, two children), and later engaged to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, with whom he had twins.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, performing in Ulan Bator, was allegedly hit over the head with a bottle and kicked in the face, resulting in serious brain injuries and a 10-day coma; he was wearing a traditional Mongolian deel embroidered with a swastika, a symbol his father and lawyer emphasized is traditional in Mongolia and not a hate symbol, contrary to Nazi associations, while denying reports he shouted "Heil Hitler"; the Russian embassy is investigating the assault but called press reports "distorted," particularly regarding details; the suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been arrested as the injury is deemed not serious, not due to diplomatic immunity, and the case remains under investigation by police.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against airport expansion on Monday by entering the northern runway at 03:30 BST; they face charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area and are due in court on 19 August, prompting police to review airport security.

Nick Selman scored a crucial century for Glamorgan after a form slump, while seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in cloudy conditions, limiting Glamorgan to 220; Gloucestershire then struggled in their innings, with the day ending evenly balanced as Glamorgan, led by Michael Hogan in place of the injured Jacques Rudolph, scrambled a bonus point.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after contacting the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee regarding a planned murder bid involving ambushing police officers on the Dee Estuary by making false reports; Hughes admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court, stating he planned to lure officers to shoot them while drunk on two occasions, and was remanded in custody pending sentencing next week, having a previous firearms conviction from 2009 and being on bail for other firearms offences at the time.

Surrey scored 255-7, powered by a 130-run stand between Davies and Foakes (90), after Yorkshire reduced them to 8-2. Yorkshire's chase faltered due to a three-wicket burst from Meaker, dismissing Bairstow and Ballance, despite Bresnan making 68; they were all out for 236. Yorkshire, hoping to reach Lord's after a T20 Blast semi-final loss, started well by dismissing Sibley and Sangakkara early but missed chances by dropping Davies and Foakes. Meaker's late wickets proved decisive, and Yorkshire fell short despite efforts from Bresnan and Waite.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST reporting that its pump could not handle incoming water; the RNLI lifeboat crew responded by placing a pump on board and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir will miss next year's Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine exams in April, prioritizing her degree over the event; the 24-year-old finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m, and is targeting the World Indoor Championships in March while believing she has at least two to three more Olympics ahead.

Liverpool are struggling to repeat last season's title challenge, currently far from the required level and needing significant improvement just to secure a top-four finish; key issues include the loss of Suarez and Sturridge's goals, ineffective replacements like Balotelli and Lambert leading to reduced pressing intensity and fewer first-half goals, and inconsistent defense despite heavy investment. Steven Gerrard faces physical and mental challenges regarding his future, with his famous slip against Chelsea still affecting him, while Liverpool are predicted to lose to Chelsea, who are currently on a different level to other Premier League teams.

East Ayrshire Council plans to build a £45 million educational facility at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre, and intends to name the campus after renowned local writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock and was passionate about education; McIlvanney was an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975, gained immediate recognition with his first novel "Remedy Is None," earned the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for works including the Laidlaw trilogy and Glasgow-based novels like "Docherty" and "The Big Man," and was also an influential poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributor to Scottish political and sporting life, dying at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon after a British sea mine, dating from the 1940s or 1950s, was spotted on Monday; residents in three streets were evacuated, while those within 500m were advised to open windows, stay indoors near walls, and avoid going outside, with exclusion zones established on the river and at sea (half-mile radius) preventing small boat sailing and causing ferry service disruptions from Gourock and Rothesay; authorities stressed the evacuation was a precautionary measure with no immediate danger, but due to the mine's deterioration, it must be moved to a safer place before disposal.

UK Sport has allocated £345m to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, £2m less than for Rio, setting medal targets of 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals; cycling funding was cut by over £4m, while archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby also missed out, and badminton had all funding withdrawn despite winning bronze in Rio, with officials expressing shock and calling it catastrophic; judo had its funding slightly increased despite also winning bronze, and UK Sport stated prioritization is necessary to protect medal potential; basketball, handball, and volleyball, which lost funding earlier, criticized UK Sport for neglecting team sports; funding for new Tokyo sports like baseball/softball remains unconfirmed, with £9m still to be allocated.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (a nine-storey and seven-storey building with 122 apartments), despite strong objections from English Heritage and others who warned of "severe harm" to the conservation area and argued the buildings contribute to its historic character; however, councillors voted seven to three in favour, citing the need to preserve tourism and improve living for older people, and noting the buildings were no longer necessarily functional, though acknowledging the loss is regrettable.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier, was off-duty in Brecon when he was punched, beaten, and killed by Jake Vallely after a seven-hour drinking binge; Vallely boasted he was the "hardest man in Brecon" before attacking Boyd outside The Cellar bar, dragging his unconscious body away. Vallely's friend Aaaron Evans was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. Boyd, originally from Carrickfergus, was found dead after returning to barracks following training exercises. His family described him as a promising, loving young man whose life was cut short, creating an unbearable void, and refuted Vallely's claim, stating the community's outpouring of love showed the true strongest people in Brecon.

Andrew Travers left Barnet Council by "mutual agreement" following an election error where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names from the poll list; an independent investigation has been launched, with Travers stating he enjoyed his time and believes changes will help the borough thrive, while the council praised his valuable contribution over three and a half years; Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton will take over temporarily, the council apologized for the problems and offered emergency proxy votes, but voters questioned fairness, Travers blamed electoral registration lists, and the council's review, concluding by end of May, will examine arrangements for the EU Referendum.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1, with Josh Gillies scoring a free-kick to open the scoring before Sean Newton equalized with a set-piece for Wrexham; Ryan Bowman then scored the winning header for Gateshead. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's improved second-half play and the quality of the winning goal, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half performance despite having good chances.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses the social and economic welfare of individuals aged 60 and above across 96 countries, ranking Norway as the top performer and Afghanistan as the worst, followed by Mozambique, with the index published on 1 October 2014 at 19:45 BST.

OneWeb plans a satellite network starting with at least 600 spacecraft, potentially exceeding 2,000, to deliver global broadband, targeting schools. Airbus is revolutionizing satellite manufacturing using assembly line techniques for high volume and low cost, aiming for three units per shift under $1 million each, with lines in Toulouse and Florida. The first satellites launch in April and November 2019, followed by a massive rocket campaign using Soyuz vehicles to deploy clusters, aiming for nearly 300 satellites by late 2020/early 2021, over 600 a year later, and over 800 mid-decade. While facing competition from SpaceX, Boeing, and others, OneWeb has raised $1.7bn and believes in first-mover advantage, with significant UK economic and regulatory importance. The project commits to aggressive debris mitigation, promising de-orbit within two years and hardware for potential capture.

Mr Swinney stated the UK spending review imposes "unprecedented pressure" on Scottish public expenditure, while the UK government countered that Scottish ministers will have £390m more available next year; Swinney argued that cuts since 2010 will reduce Scotland's discretionary budget by 12.5% in real terms by 2019-20, with 4.2% of that reduction occurring between now and then, and criticized Chancellor Osborne for imposing real-terms cuts annually until 2020, with over £1bn still to come, vowing to protect schools, hospitals, and police services; the UK Scotland Office highlighted the £390m increase and £30bn block grant, and Labour's Jackie Baillie criticized Swinney for "anti-austerity posturing" without concrete plans.

Many people with severe disabilities and their carers face isolation and stress due to inadequate accessible toilets, as standard facilities cannot accommodate those needing two carers or hoists; Changing Places toilets, with extra space and features, are recommended in building standards for larger complexes like shopping centres and stadiums but are not compulsory, leading campaigners to push for mandatory regulations in new builds; while 893 such toilets exist in the UK, potentially serving over 250,000 people, financial and space barriers hinder installation in existing buildings, though positive impacts are seen when installed, such as at Arsenal Football Club.

Italian consumer groups have filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, preventing them from switching competitors due to long contracts, and leasing premises above market rates, which they claim leads to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores. McDonald's defended its approach, stating it shares risks and rewards with licensees and has created successful business opportunities. The SEIU and European unions support the complaint, alleging McDonald's abuses its dominant market position, while the European Commission will study the submission and may investigate. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, generating $9.27 billion in worldwide revenues for the company in 2014.

13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve instead of undergoing an appendix operation, leading his family at Bangor Elim Church to start the #prayforjosh hashtag on social media, which went viral globally, received over 79,000 views, and inspired a mystery donor to erect a billboard in Holywood, while his classmates and people worldwide continue to support him.

The UK government is closing Brecon Barracks as part of a military reorganization, prompting condemnation from local MP Chris Davies who cites its 1805 history and role in conflicts, launches a petition, and expresses concerns about unemployment and military tourism in Brecon; Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon confirms the closure and announces a specialist light infantry centre will be created at St Athan, while Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supports restructuring but warns of livelihood impacts and uncertainty; nearby Sennybridge and Dering Lines are unaffected, and jobs at Brecon Barracks are not thought to be at risk.

The House of Lords warns that the UK fishing industry, which voted heavily for Brexit to regain control of waters and become a leading exporter like Norway, risks being marginalized in wider negotiations despite its small economic contribution (0.5% of GDP, 12,000 jobs). The report highlights that shared fish stocks with EU nations complicate matters, as continued market access for UK exports to the EU may require allowing EU boats into UK waters, creating a trade-off. It stresses retaining elements of the Common Fisheries Policy like scientific-based quotas and international cooperation, while warning that leaving the EU could lead to four separate fisheries management regimes across the UK. Despite these risks, many in the industry remain optimistic, citing recent EU quota increases as a positive sign for the future, and the government states Brexit offers an opportunity to review fisheries management for fairness and sustainability.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks exposing US surveillance programs, which he found horrifying; the US government, led by Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, deemed the leaks extremely damaging to national security. The National Security Agency (NSA) accessed vast amounts of individual data including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking information, and confirmed requesting millions of phone records from Verizon, including call duration, location, and numbers. Documents revealed the Prism program enabled "backdoor" access to servers of nine major tech companies (Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube, Apple) for private posts, chats, and searches, though all companies denied involvement and the program's mechanics remain unclear. NSA Director Keith Alexander defended the operations as essential for security, citing the need to protect methods from terrorists, while experts like Peter Sommer suggested access might be more limited, akin to a "catflap" requiring court orders. Data protection laws vary by country but typically regulate company practices rather than government activity, and company privacy policies often include clauses allowing information sharing when legally obliged. User data is frequently stored outside the user's country (e.g., in the US via cloud computing), subject to US laws like the Patriot Act and FISA, which allow authorities easy access to non-US data with little transparency. UK Foreign Secretary Hague refused to confirm British involvement via GCHQ, and the EU expressed concern and sought details. Hague stated law-abiding citizens need not worry, but Privacy International warned that using major US-based services risks privacy violations under Prism, with Snowden stating he acted to avoid living in a society where everything is recorded.

OpenAI, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to advance digital intelligence for positive human impact without financial obligations, though scientists like Musk and Hawking warn AI poses an existential threat by potentially outpacing human evolution, while other experts deem the risk remote; OpenAI's statement emphasizes benefiting humanity broadly and distributing AI safely as an extension of human will, with only a small fraction of the pledged $1 billion to be spent in the near term.

L/Bdr Parkinson, seriously injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June, walking for nearly half an hour with assistance; despite his brain injury affecting his speech initially, he now speaks unaided and remains determined, witty, and caring. He spends 12 hours daily in the gym and rehab, supports military charities as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits, and has received thousands of Facebook friend requests, exceeding the platform's 5,000 limit, alongside overwhelming public support, increased mail and email traffic, and hundreds of torch-related visit requests. His mother described the response as phenomenal, and Facebook suggested he create a public page or use subscribe options due to his public figure status; the torch journey involves 8,000 bearers covering 8,000 miles over 70 days to the London opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011, the US poverty rate remained flat at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans after three years of increases, while real median household income decreased by 1.5%; the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021, income inequality measured by the Gini index rose by 1.6% for the first annual increase since 1993, and the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%, following a record high poverty rate of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, moved from Somerset to Lancashire (the Red Rose) in 2013 and has signed a new contract extending his stay until 2019; he holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan last year, and cricket director Ashley Giles praised him as one of the game's most talented players, highlighting his positive impact on the dressing room and squad experience; Buttler, who was playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, was returning to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, Campbeltown, Chatham, and Cornwall) are moored in Portsmouth Harbour; bidders had until 23 January to register interest, with no preservation proposals submitted, viewings scheduled for late February/March, and a final decision expected in spring. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess industry capacity, while MP Penny Mordaunt supports both recycling and preserving at least ship as a reef/diving attraction for tourism. The MoD prioritizes best financial return for the taxpayer, and the frigates were versatile combat ships with about 280 crew.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced persistent instability and international isolation due to racial and political tensions, marked by coups in 1987 and 2000 (which involved hostage-taking of ethnic Indian leaders) and a military takeover in 2006, damaging the economy and tourism industry and leading to a 2009 suspension from the Commonwealth, later lifted after elections in 2014. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with deep social segregation and a small majority now indigenous, alongside small minority communities. While relying heavily on sugar and tourism for foreign exchange, Fiji's diverse economy faces persistent trade and budget deficits, making it a major per capita aid recipient.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its entire chemical weapons stockpile, with Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad attributing delays to attacks on shipments, including one intercepted by "terrorist groups," and emphasizing the ongoing war. He condemned US Secretary of State John Kerry's remarks on barrel bombs as "absolutely unacceptable," denying government responsibility for civilian casualties in Aleppo reported by the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Aleppo Media Centre. The Syrian government also denied rebel seizure of Aleppo's central prison, contradicting reports from the Observatory and activist groups that rebels now control it. Despite delays, Syria stressed its commitment to destroying its declared 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons by the June deadline, with only about 4% (30 tonnes) having left the country so far, and blamed security concerns for the slowdown.

Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others" is the 5/2 favourite to win the Booker Prize, which this year is open to all authors writing in English regardless of nationality; the winner will be announced at London's Guildhall. The shortlist includes six authors: Mukherjee (set in 1960s Calcutta), Jacobson (futuristic love story "J"), Smith (dual-narrative "How To Be Both"), Ferris (atheism-themed novel), Fowler (best-selling "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves"), and Flanagan (WWII love story "The Narrow Road to the Deep North"). Fowler's novel is the best-selling with over 55,000 copies, followed by Ferris with just over 6,000; Mukherjee's sales spiked from 97 to 507 after the shortlist announcement. Professor David Brauner criticized the list as weak, suggesting Jacobson's book is strongest but might face reluctance to award a two-time winner soon after Mantel, and noted the debate over literary merit versus readability. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling, and the ceremony will be covered by the BBC.

PJS is appealing to the Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a media ban in England and Wales, with the Supreme Court deciding whether to hear the appeal and if it should be allowed or dismissed; an interim injunction preventing publication of his identity remains in place until the hearing concludes. The Sun on Sunday seeks to publish allegations of PJS's extra-marital activities, including a three-way sexual encounter, which PJS argues violates his privacy right; after a High Court judge initially refused an injunction, the Court of Appeal granted one, but later lifted it, ruling the story was too widespread online to maintain confidentiality despite efforts to remove breaches.

Fosse Park, near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was purchased for £345.5 million; the new owners are preparing plans to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units, viewing it as an investment gateway to the city, while Ernie White of Blaby District Council notes the need to improve the current view of shed backs, and Paul Clarke of Crown Estates specifically addresses concerns about parking, congestion, and the tired state of common areas, aiming to enhance the location's quality.

Disney's live-action "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia due to its "gay moment," leading to a delayed release for content review. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit to the scene, granting it a P13 parental guidance classification. Homosexual activity is illegal in the Muslim-majority country, though the tourism minister called banning the film "ridiculous." Local cinemas offered refunds to advance ticket holders. Director Bill Condon described the scene as an "exclusively gay moment" involving LeFou's feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film drew criticism from netizens who deemed it "stupid and laughable," contrasting it negatively with other local films.

Landlords letting properties to more than three unrelated people in Southampton require an HMO licence costing around £1,000, but many avoid this despite potential fines up to £20,000, with the council estimating 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area; tenants frequently report fear of eviction and poor living conditions, with Shelter receiving about five or six daily calls due to a shortage of affordable homes; nationally, mandatory licensing applies to three-storey houses occupied by five or more unrelated people, and in Southampton, specific areas (Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling since 2013; Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, Bassett since 2015) are designated; while most landlords cooperate, a minority resist, leading to prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to prevent a second election; Fianna Fáil will support a minority government but not a programme for government, with water charges being a major obstacle to agreement, including a proposal for a commission on Irish Water, as Fianna Fáil demands immediate removal of charges while Fine Gael sees a role for them; after the election almost two months ago, Fine Gael held 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour Party seven, but no party secured a majority and TDs have failed to elect a taoiseach.

The ferry Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire on a car deck approximately 27km from Mallorca, forcing the evacuation of all passengers and crew to lifeboats; they were rescued by the ferry Puglia, with at least three people injured (one seriously) airlifted to hospital. The fire's cause remains unknown, and the ship may sink in its current position; rescued passengers were returning to Palma de Mallorca, with psychologists arranged for support at the port.

The Electoral Commission reported 38 MPs highlighting potential double voting, a criminal offence, and stressed the need for better joined-up council electoral registers to identify duplicate entries, as the current disconnected systems cause significant administrative burdens and high duplicate application rates (30-70%), despite record voter registration (46.8 million) and turnout (68.7%) in the June election; Labour warned against making registration harder for young people, opposing a blanket ban on dual registrations which could exclude those needing it for work or study, while the Commission called for verification systems and requiring dual registrants to choose their voting constituency in advance.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, a former University of Nebraska star NFL player who faced persistent off-field troubles and legal issues after his career, is believed to have committed suicide early Wednesday; he played for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, was later convicted of assault for driving into teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend, was serving over 30 years in prison after being accused of killing his cellmate, and a judge found sufficient evidence to try him for that death, with his coach describing him as intelligent with good qualities but hampered by anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX was promoted to lance corporal by Brigadier Andrew Williams at an event marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment, awarded for "good behaviour"; he is the 30th mascot ram in a lineage dating back to 1858, officially classified as a soldier who joined the regiment in 2014, possesses an army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season on the Chatsworth Estate; additionally, he has switched on Ashbourne's Christmas lights and met Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in injury time through Dejan Lovren's goal, moving closer to Champions League qualification in the Europa League. The match featured an incredible atmosphere at Anfield, with Liverpool overcoming a 2-0 deficit inspired by manager Jurgen Klopp invoking the spirit of the 2005 Istanbul Champions League final win. Klopp's passionate touchline demeanour and the team's sheer force of will, epitomised by his philosophy of turning doubters into believers and the mantra "We decide when it's over," drove the comeback. Goals from Philippe Coutinho and Mamadou Sakho, alongside Divock Origi's early effort, sealed the win, which Klopp described as brilliant, outstanding, and emotional, leaving a lasting impression on the club's identity and prospects.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, Mr. Davis proposed monthly meetings with devolved administrations to share analysis and ensure a "two-way information flow" as the UK prepares Brexit talks with Brussels, aiming to get the best deal for the whole UK. However, Mr. Russell criticized the UK government for lacking transparency on its strategic intentions, particularly regarding EU market access, and emphasized that single market membership is essential for Scotland's economic prosperity. While the UK government hopes to overturn a High Court judgment on triggering Article 50 at the Supreme Court, the Scottish government intends to oppose it, with the Lord Advocate seeking to be heard in the case.

A flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four genetically identical to Dolly the sheep (Debbie, Denise, Diane, and Daisy), are being studied at the University of Nottingham to determine if cloned animals age normally and develop age-related diseases like osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes at the expected rate. This research follows concerns raised by Dolly's relatively early death at six-and-a-half years old, partly due to osteoarthritis, which suggested premature aging might be linked to the cloning process. The sheep undergo regular, extensive health assessments including joint examinations, X-rays, and full-body fMRI scans. While the study results are pending, the four Dolly clones, now approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays, currently appear to be in good health.

Shutter Speed won the Musidora Stakes under soft ground, beating Enable into third, and will be sent to the French Oaks at Chantilly instead of Epsom, where stablemates Enable and Coronet will run; trainer John Gosden expressed concern about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and may not run him in the Derby due to the short 16-day gap; Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas.

The pound initially fell against the dollar and euro before mid-afternoon recovery and subsequent decline, while the volatility index reached 2008 financial crisis levels; polling data showing the Leave campaign ahead and a drop in the implied probability of a Remain vote to 68.5% spooked investors, leading to heightened market uncertainty and further volatility, with analysts predicting more aggressive pound movement and heightened volatility if polls remain tight; this uncertainty caused significant falls in Asian stock markets (Japan's Nikkei down 3.5%, Hong Kong down 2.5%) and a 1.1% drop in London's FTSE 100, though the Leave campaign argued the pound had retreated only to March levels and a weaker pound benefited exporters, while official figures showed the UK trade deficit narrowed in April due to increased exports.

Braintree Town are sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-offs, after losing to Barrow who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games; manager Cowley acknowledged the difficulty of the long journey and conceding early but remained positive, calling their achievements remarkable and stating their part-time team will embrace the challenge despite their three-game losing streak.

From April 2015, planning decisions in Northern Ireland will shift from the Planning Service to local councils, giving elected politicians the authority to approve or reject developments in their areas, a move described by Michael Corr of PLACE as a democratic opportunity for community development but criticized by Friends of the Earth for potentially reviving discriminatory practices like those in the 1960s housing allocations, with concerns raised about transparency, developer-politician relationships, and the need for strict codes of conduct and donation disclosure rules to ensure fairness.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times—twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, which required amputation—by an airgun in Winchburgh; her owner found her injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA. The owner expressed distress over the severity of the injuries and the danger posed to children in the housing estate, while the Scottish SPCA condemned the incident and urged the Scottish government to implement airgun licensing despite last year's consultation facing opposition from 87% of respondents who deemed the proposal "draconian."

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke for a club-record fee via a release clause, making him their second most expensive player and seventh summer signing, on a long-term contract; the 24-year-old Belgian international scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa after joining from Genk in 2012. The move aimed to address Liverpool's goal-scoring struggles last season following Luis Suarez's sale and Daniel Sturridge's injuries, with manager Brendan Rodgers adding Benteke to revive the attack alongside other signings like Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino, while Divock Origi returned from loan. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert praised Benteke as a brilliant number nine who will get goals with service, and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge highlighted his presence, strength, and aggression as something the club lacked, expressing optimism for the forward line.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence of academic improvement from tablet use in schools, though tablets are increasingly prevalent, used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% providing one per pupil, particularly in academies. Despite this lack of proven academic benefit, head teachers reported positive impacts like motivating disengaged students and increasing family involvement, and Dr. Clarke noted technology's role will inevitably grow. A separate study suggested touch-screen computers help boys and poorer pupils learn to read, and the passage highlights how tablets reflect modern life, with concerns about internet addiction among students taking devices to bed.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs spanning 1887 to the 1990s, depicting children's lives and social history in Liverpool over more than a century, illustrating changes in childhood experiences and how special occasions were marked. Curator Kay Jones selected these images from hundreds in the museum's collections to capture both the good and bad aspects of childhood, including play and work, such as the Rollo children in costume for a mayor's ball and a young maid. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals, potentially facing his old club on 18 February after previous spells with Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy; striker Keating, 21, recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams, has moved from Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps pending international clearance, with Nicholson praising Anderson as a leader despite limited games and Keating as young but hungry, while the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone having won only one of their last six games.

Bolivia has passed a law allowing 12-year-olds to work with parental consent, reflecting the country's status as one of South America's poorest and acknowledging that over 500,000 children already work, often in difficult conditions like mines and agriculture, to supplement family income. The law also imposes harsh penalties, including 30 years in jail for child homicide, and was signed by Vice-President Garcia Linera while President Morales was abroad, who intervened to balance reality with international treaties. The government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty, despite conflicting with International Labour Organisation standards that prohibit work under 15 (or 14 for developing countries), as officials argue it aligns with Bolivia's specific needs and reality.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress, experienced a heart attack at her home near New York after helping a woman, suffering sudden chest pain, nausea, and feverishness; she recognized the symptoms by searching "women's heart attack symptoms" online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist the next day who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery, known as the "widow maker"; she did not call emergency services but warned others to know the symptoms and call 911, and her show, The Rosie Show, was recently cancelled due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was stabbed in an alleyway in Kenton around 00:30 GMT after a fight at a party in Belvedere Way where youths tried to gain entry; he was pronounced dead an hour later. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and hospitalized in stable condition. Police described the party as well-run with adults present, believing Che was not involved in the initial altercation but was targeted later. They appealed for witnesses near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate. A 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested on suspicion of murder, with the latter bailed until mid-December, and a 14-year-old was held for possessing an offensive weapon.

Denmark reorganized cancer diagnosis after poor survival statistics, focusing on reducing long waiting times for non-obvious cases through a three-route model: fast-tracking patients with alarm symptoms to specialists within strict time targets, establishing diagnosis centers for undiagnosed symptoms to provide rapid tests and scans, and creating "yes-no" centers for minor symptoms to quickly rule out serious conditions. This improved organization within existing resources led to better survival rates, with Denmark catching up to other Scandinavian countries, and experts from Wales noted the potential for similar reforms by breaking down barriers between GPs and specialists.

Powys Council won the contract to replace the disbanded OFT in regulating estate agents, receiving £170,000 annually to issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest agents or those breaching estate agent laws; complaints will still be handled by local trading standards departments, which will prosecute offenders but refer breaches of the Estate Agents Act to Powys, with James Munro stating he hopes this will demonstrate Powys's capability to take on more contracts in the future.

NHS Employers approved a plan after the Nuffield Trust found examples of nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs, highlighting workforce gaps in junior doctor rotas and GP capacity; the report suggests reshaping the 1.3 million-strong workforce to cover shortages and adapt to the increasing focus on long-term conditions, emphasizing opportunities for improving care and staff roles, though unions warned against using it as a quick fix and stressed the need for funding and avoiding compromise to doctor training.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot following a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour; the A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT, and investigations into the collision are ongoing. First stated that while parts of its services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take several hours for all services to return to normal, with Managing Director James Freeman expressing hope for full service restoration by the evening commute and thanking the public and staff for their support and efforts.

NRW estimates the Swansea tidal lagoon would cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout deaths annually during migration, figures TLP disputes as lacking clear scientific basis and claims NRW refused to share methodology; TLP's own modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of 2% fish mortality. The £1.3bn project is a test bed for larger versions, and the UK government is reviewing its viability, with Wales' Environment Secretary seeking clarity soon; NRW strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism, stating it shared extensive evidence and methodology with experts and has confidence in its findings.

Stormont's DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), highlighting the sector's importance with almost 100,000 jobs; Foster stated it would provide strategic leadership for marketing activities benefiting the entire sector, while Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the move as addressing the need for better marketing coordination but noted potential implications for other organizations and looked forward to discussing the plans with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a public tree planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, inviting people to plant 40,000 native trees as a tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who died in WW1; this project is part of a larger four-year UK initiative to plant "millions" of trees with the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." The charity provides saplings and advises volunteers to wear sturdy footwear, aiming to create a living memorial that will support wildlife and offer a space for reflection, located about seven miles outside Derry city with limited parking.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller tackling domestic violence and honor crime featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome, praised by judges as emotionally exhausting, powerful, finely written, and tightly plotted with well-handled subject matter and atmosphere. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution award for her 23-year career creating the groundbreaking female private investigator VI Warshawski, described as a game changer who revolutionized strong female protagonists in crime fiction and founded Sisters In Crime to support female writers. The accolades were presented at the start of Harrogate's annual crime writing festival, chaired by Ann Cleeves, who noted the strong shortlist.

Mitch Santner broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which director of cricket Steve Rhodes called a "massive blow" to their qualification hopes, expressing regret over the "unfinished business" with Santner. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, will rejoin the Rapids after the ICC Trophy in June, expressing frustration about the injury and excitement to return and make an impact. Worcestershire also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

Barry Pring, 47, was unlawfully killed in 2008 on a Kiev dual carriageway hard shoulder when hit by a speeding car with stolen plates that didn't stop, while he was intoxicated and hailing a taxi; his wife, Ganna Ziuzina (Anna), had briefly left to retrieve a glove. The coroner recorded unlawful killing based on overwhelming circumstantial evidence, noting Barry's lowered guard due to inebriation, and his family believes Anna was involved to inherit assets, as she sold his belongings, moved funds, and was having an affair; Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry but reopened it as a murder case in 2011, which remains active but not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns from Merseyside urgently needs experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital after his previous transplant failed and he suffered a third relapse in April, leaving no treatment options in the UK; his parents, Sophie and Rob, were heartbroken by the initial failure but are now "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed" by an anonymous donor who has paid for the treatment, providing financial clearance to start as soon as possible, with the expected date to be announced next week.

Apple is implementing security changes to prevent third-party tools like Elcomsoft's software from accessing iCloud backups after celebrity photo hacks; the two-step verification system, requiring a four-digit code sent to a trusted device, will now apply to iCloud backups, previously a vulnerability, and users can use a 14-character recovery key if their trusted device is lost, though experts debate whether this security should be opt-in or default, with concerns about recovery key management, while Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves noted that finer points of a potential deal where Wright could purchase 20% of Billericay Town are still pending, with The Sun reporting Wright will become a club director; Billericay currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from a play-off spot, and Wright has played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds; the club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who stated he is comfortable investing £10,000 a week, and signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, at the start of March.

Mr Ashley was invited to meet the BIS select committee chaired by MP Iain Wright to discuss the treatment of low-paid workers and national minimum wage enforcement at his Derbyshire company, following a BBC investigation; alternative dates were offered but not accepted, and Wright warned that failure to agree to attend could lead to further action including potential contempt proceedings; Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for comment, though the company previously pledged to review worker rights under Ashley's oversight.

Opposition politicians, led by Ilya Yashin, completed a report titled "Putin. War" compiling existing facts about Russia's involvement in Ukraine since 2014, arguing it presents compelling evidence that President Putin personally directed the war for his own ends; the report details how Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in rebel victories, with soldiers admitting they were sent to Ukraine, documents military spending and units, and notes challenges in publishing and distributing the limited print run due to publisher fears and public apathy, while acknowledging Putin successfully boosted his popularity through the conflict.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. The 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham died from head injuries, as determined by a post-mortem. South Yorkshire Police arrested a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman in Sheffield in connection with the death, and both remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones criticized the UK government for not consulting him on the Article 50 letter draft before publication, despite discussing it generally with Theresa May, and expressed frustration at the lack of respect shown to devolved administrations; Alun Cairns defended the government, stating it acts in the UK's interest and Wales was mentioned in the letter, where May promised increased devolved powers but did not specify which ones, leading to concerns about funding accompanying these powers after 2020, while the exact powers to be devolved remain unclear pending a white paper.

Two cars were damaged in an incident on Nursery Drive and Parkhead in Newry on Friday night; Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed being "appalled by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community," and a PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook post stated police were attacked while carrying out duties, also appealing to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.
