Mr. Charney, founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds; the board does not expect him to return. His lawyer denies the statements, accusing the company of privacy invasion and extortion. The court filing, responding to his defamation lawsuit, includes evidence of illicit emails to female employees and racial taunts. The company alleges Charney repeatedly violated sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies, making him too risky to hire as CEO or executive. A restraining order was recently granted preventing him from making negative statements about the company or trying to remove board members.

Great Britain will play Greece in a basketball rematch at London's Copper Box, broadcast live on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30-19:30 BST; Greece won the previous encounter 92-64 in Patras earlier this month, but three Greek players will be absent, offering GB a revenge opportunity. This is GB's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017, starting in September with a qualifying group in Istanbul; following this match, GB travels to Poland for a four-team tournament as their final warm-up before EuroBasket.

The iPhone revolutionized mobile phones from devices primarily for calls and texts into powerful computers, fundamentally changing daily activities like photography and enabling instant sharing, as demonstrated by the author's personal experience handling Phil Schiller's device for a news segment and comparing its impact to the Model T Ford; despite initial skepticism and hyperbole, the iPhone proved transformative, putting sophisticated technology in the hands of billions and disrupting industries, largely due to Steve Jobs' focus on an attractive user interface that made complex tasks accessible, marking the beginning of the mobile connected era.

Tests confirmed multiple cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, ingested a toxic substance, with seven-month-old Meereen recently dying after showing symptoms like shivering, foaming at the mouth, and vomiting; her owner Adria Pearce is devastated. Three other cats died in the last seven days, and another died two weeks ago. The RSPCA spokesman Andy Bostock expressed concern about whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and appealed for safe storage of chemicals like antifreeze, particularly during car maintenance.

Despite Syriza's previous opposition, the government is poised to implement further austerity and liberalization measures mandated by creditors, while Greece's tourism booms with 25 million expected arrivals this year. There is a notable absence of protests against announced VAT increases, pension cuts, and anticipated subsidy reductions, privatisations, and market openings, possibly because citizens await details of Tsipras's concessions for the €86bn third bailout. Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and causing monetary austerity through bank closures, which hinders lending and threatens businesses like retailers dependent on credit for seasonal orders. Greece faces a "vicious economic squeeze" impoverishing its people, and the new bailout's success hinges on creditors offering debt forgiveness to enable genuine recovery.

Ross Kemp is briefly returning to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for the final episodes of Peggy Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, who is dying from cancer; this reunion brings Grant back to Walford to be with his brother Phil and their mother during her final moments.

Lance Corporal Trimaan Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles last October; her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected him when police informed them of her death. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring Alice to ignore the stalker and dismissing her sister Emma's warning that he would kill her, while Prof. Ruggles noted they all failed to realize the situation's severity despite the signs. The couple established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking dangers, aiming to remember Alice for her vibrant personality. Dhillon, who denied murder, was convicted and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

EDDF approved £18bn funding for the Hinkley Point C nuclear project in Somerset, but the UK government launched a further review following this decision, prompting EDF's CEO to cancel a site visit. Critics warn of environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign government involvement, with Chinese investors providing one-third of the funding. The project faces internal EDF dissent, including resignations over financial risks, and is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity. Despite EDF describing it as a unique asset benefiting both countries and boosting employment, the project has been hindered by delays and uncertainties since its proposal in 2006, including a postponement of the UK government's final decision until autumn 2016.

The newly-designed divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the spouse committed adultery with, but family lawyers like Margaret Heathcote and Georgina Hamblin argue this increases conflict and complexity, despite the Ministry of Justice stating there is no obligation to name anyone. While the form was updated for user-friendliness and guidance says naming is "not normally necessary," Hamblin fears people will overlook this and fill in the box, making the third party part of the court case, potentially causing delays and extra costs. Statistics show adultery was cited in 12,148 divorces in 2015, compared to 46,815 for "unreasonable behaviour," and Hamblin notes many clients want to involve the new partner, though judges disapprove as it puts the petitioner in a bad light. The Ministry of Justice confirms naming has always been possible but is not required.

Britain is the world's third largest wood importer, and while conifer forests have historically supported Wales's timber industry, Confor reports that at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001, requiring replanting to meet demand; the industry is valued at over £450m annually to the Welsh economy, managed equally by Natural Resources Wales and private companies, but faces conflict with environmental policy favoring native broadleaf trees and public access, alongside challenges in remote forest access and timber transport causing local issues; the Welsh government seeks a balance through its Woodlands for Wales strategy and Glastir scheme, but Confor's Martin Bishop argues the emphasis on environmental aspects overshadows commercial forestry, criticizes bureaucracy, and states only 90 hectares were planted last year compared to the needed 20,000 annually to meet ministerial targets, despite a significant market for timber.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge; emergency crews responded to Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at approximately 16:40, and the boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoy veterans, including Able seaman Charles Lewis who expressed honour; the Foreign Office initially blocked the medals due to rules against foreign awards over five years old, but later made an exception, allowing President Putin to present the first medals in 2013; the Russian embassy emphasized the convoys' vital role in supplying the Soviet Union to defeat Germany on the Eastern Front, describing them as a material expression of the wartime alliance; the convoys involved dangerous journeys from Britain to northern Russia during WWII, facing constant threats from U-boats, aircraft, severe cold, storms, and ice, resulting in the loss of 104 merchant and 16 military vessels and thousands of Allied lives, a campaign Winston Churchill called "the worst journey in the world"; the British government created the Arctic Star in 2012 to recognize the veterans.

HM Inspectorate of Probation identified significant delays in starting offenders on community payback and excessive excusal for non-attendance, with one offender completing only 16 hours over 17 months; the Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's 15 recommendations, which followed an inspection of 100 cases and interviews with 86 offenders. Community payback involves 40-300 hours of unpaid work for offenses like theft or drug offences, with 70,000 offenders ordered to do such tasks in 2014; while inspectors noted high-quality work instances and positive offender attitudes, they criticized poor enforcement and management, with chief inspector Paul Wilson calling it a "wasted opportunity" treated merely as punishment and demanding urgent action, which the Ministry of Justice accepted and is implementing.

The comedian Russell Brand has been labeled a hypocrite by The Sun newspaper for advocating economic and political revolution to help poorer people while living in a luxury London home, an accusation he has faced before; viewers of his vlogs have seen his spacious home with wooden floors and exposed brickwork. When confronted by a Channel 4 News reporter about his rent while supporting a housing campaign, Brand called the journalist "snide" and walked off. Brand has previously responded to such criticism, acknowledging his wealth and past actions under capitalism but arguing that personal change and systemic reform are both necessary, claiming critics avoid discussing inequality and that his hypocrisy can be addressed incrementally.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated human genome mapping through a competitive approach that drew scientific criticism and vilification, despite his confidence and wealth; his work undeniably sped up the process. After the human genome project, he focused on creating synthetic life, leading to the organism Synthia. Born in 1946, his time as a naval orderly in Vietnam during the Tet offensive inspired his medical career and a conviction not to waste time. Excelling in research over practice at NIH, he developed faster gene sequencing methods by focusing on RNA instead of entire DNA blueprints, founding private institutes and companies like Celera Genomics when public funding failed. His controversial disregard for scientific conventions brought opprobrium but also financial independence, allowing him to pursue projects like sequencing marine microbes from his yacht and spearheading the J Craig Venter Institute's creation of synthetic life, which he believes could spark an industrial revolution and help the environment.

A survey of about 1,000 parents in England found that four out of five children eating school lunches had tried foods at school they hadn't tried at home, and half of parents reported their children asked for school foods to be cooked at home; the most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least popular. Commissioned by England's School Food Trust after concerns about fussy eaters, the research involved 628 parents whose children ate school lunches; experts like Rob Rees and Carrie Longton highlighted that school meals help children try new foods and benefit from peer pressure, with meals now adhering to strict nutritional guidelines, and about four in ten primary school children in England eat school lunches, compared to slightly fewer in secondary schools and about 46% in Scotland.

Ávaro Morata, a 23-year-old striker playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid, whose buy-back option for him was reportedly up to €30m. Previously linked to Arsenal and Chelsea, Morata scored three goals for Spain in France, 27 goals in two years for Juventus (winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias), and played in back-to-back Champions League finals, appearing as a substitute for Real's 2014 win and scoring for Juventus in their 2015 defeat. He came through Real's youth system, debuted at 18, and scored 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson rejoined Nottingham Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 but was released in May and is currently without a team. The 30-year-old made 51 appearances during his second spell at Forest, having previously spent four seasons there before moving to Celtic. He also has career history with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is selling its loss-making US chain Fresh & Easy to Los Angeles-based private equity company Yucaipa, run by billionaire Ron Burkle, as an "orderly and efficient exit from the US market"; around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, while the remaining 50 stores will close, and Tesco will loan the new business approximately £80m; disposing of the Fresh & Easy brand will cost Tesco £150m, though part is a loan that may be repaid, and if Yucaipa makes the business profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake; Fresh & Easy, operating 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona, has lost money since opening in 2007, and Tesco recently reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years.
The individual initially faced racial abuse but overcame it, briefly considered representing France, and is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

The ice fields of the French Alps, including Mont Blanc, covered approximately 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s but decreased to about 275 sq km by the late 2000s, representing a 26% loss over 40 years, as documented by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie using map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual verification to address debris cover and shadow issues; this retreat is not uniform, with southern sectors like Belledonne and Ecrins experiencing significantly greater losses than the northern Alps, which benefit from more precipitation and cloud cover, and the largest glacier, La Mer de Glace, has slightly shrunk from 31.5 to just over 30 sq km.

Scotland's women's team, having won all five qualifiers, hosts Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday needing victory to almost secure qualification; Rachel Evans expresses desperation to avoid another play-off heartbreak after previous near-misses for Euro 2013 and the World Cup. Iceland, ranked slightly higher but also unbeaten, presents a tough challenge, with the outcome of this match and the return fixture likely deciding the group; Scotland is in a strong position to qualify automatically as one of the best runners-up. Evans emphasizes the team's step-by-step approach and the importance of fan support, while noting the squad benefits significantly from having 12 players in top international leagues, including herself at Bayern Munich, which exposes them to different cultures and high-level competition that enhances the national team.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England following a harassment complaint from a woman in south London alleging incidents over two years; released on bail, he stated the concerns related to non-threatening tweets and accused the media of innuendo encouraging speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed an investigation into online harassment reported by a woman in her 30s, and Campbell later clarified on his website that the allegations pertained solely to publicly visible tweets, none of which were threatening in any way.

PETA wants Skegness to replace its Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish-friendly version featuring the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice," arguing the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty in fishing; the mayor welcomes suggestions but doesn't expect much support for removing Jolly, who is beloved and seen as harmless and has been synonymous with the resort since his 1908 poster commission; PETA claims their suggestion would rebrand Skegness as progressive, while the mayor insists Jolly is just a friendly symbol and "if it isn't broken we won't try and fix it."

Georgia opened the scoring with a try by Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland quickly took control, scoring tries through Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. After the break, Hamish Watson extended Scotland's lead, before Lobzhanidze scored a second try for Georgia from a scrum. Stuart Hogg then scored his second try for Scotland. Georgia scored another try via Lobzhanidze from a scrum, but Scotland finished strongly with tries from Ali Price and Rory Hughes, securing a 38-11 victory.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38-30, leading 14-6 at halftime through tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, with Cas loanee Paddy Flynn scoring against his parent club; Widnes extended their lead in the second half with tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (two), and Joe Mellor, making it 38-12, but Castleford scored three tries in four minutes through Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick, though Widnes held on; Mellor's try after a short kick-off had given Widnes a 26-point lead, and the victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat and remain sixth, one point above Widnes.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti held at Guantanamo Bay since 2002 after being arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of al-Qaeda and Taliban links (which he denies), was released after a US review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat," a decision made by the Periodic Review Board in July; his lawyer noted his lack of bitterness, and he boarded a Kuwaiti government plane, though he must now spend at least a year in a Kuwaiti militant rehabilitation center; the Kuwaiti government had pushed for his release, and he had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court, claiming he was in Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid; this was the first release since May 2014, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl, reducing Guantanamo's population to 148 inmates; the facility opened in January 2002 following the 9/11 attacks, and President Obama has repeatedly promised to shut it down.

DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional character played by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka, created the viral song "PPAP" (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen') with lyrics about fusing pens with fruits; its catchy beat, silly lyrics, and simple dance routine propelled it to massive popularity on Facebook, with the original video gaining over 4 million views and a 9GAG version surpassing 44 million, though it received mixed reactions from users finding it either addictive or irritating; the song inspired numerous tributes and covers from various artists and fans internationally, though it has not significantly trended in Japan.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle of Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, the Gallipoli landings, and was first commemorated in London in 1916 at Westminster Abbey attended by King George V. Thousands attended dawn services at Hyde Park Corner and Westminster Abbey, followed by a parade at the Cenotaph involving up to 400 people including veterans, service personnel, and their families, and wreath-laying ceremonies. The services featured prayers read by schoolchildren and the singing of national anthems from Australia, New Zealand, and the UK, honouring sacrifices in all wars. Alexander Downer, the Australian High Commissioner, reflected on the Gallipoli landings and the courage of the Anzac troops. The Gallipoli campaign was one of the war's bloodiest battles, an Allied attempt to force the Ottoman Empire out of the conflict.

Clarkson, 30, rejoined St Mirren in July and is set to make his debut against Alloa on Saturday after scoring nine goals at Dundee last season and mainly featuring as a substitute this term; he feels fit and match-ready, having played for the U20s and trained hard, and aims to help St Mirren climb the Championship table where they sit eighth, seven points above Alloa, having previously been capped twice for Scotland in 2008 with one international goal and made nearly 400 senior appearances for clubs including Bristol City and Brentford.

The turkey firm was sold to Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday, initially raising fears about the pension scheme, but Unite union received guarantees that all current agreements would be honored; Unite clarified the Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme closed in 2004 and members have an unaffected alternative, which Boparan's office confirmed would continue under new ownership; Unite's Steve Harley met Boparan representatives, who stated the goal is to restore profitability through investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken.

The council announced free crossings at Cowes until 2 July to address problems with the new chain ferry, which has experienced breakdowns, groundings, suspension due to training issues, and vehicle damage since launching on 14 May; an audit review has been ordered, and compensation for local businesses is under discussion, with a councillor citing teething problems for a prototype that are being resolved through ramp extensions and improved seamanship.

The House of Lords warns that UK fishing communities, which heavily voted for Brexit to regain control of waters and become a leading exporter like Norway, risk being marginalized in wider negotiations; while the industry is small (0.5% of GDP, 12,000 fishers), it must not be overlooked, and Brexit involves trade-offs where continued EU market access for UK fish exports may require allowing EU boats into UK waters; the Lords recommend retaining elements of the Common Fisheries Policy like science-based quotas and international cooperation, but note potential complications with separate management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland if the UK's unified CFP status ends; despite these risks, industry representatives express optimism about Brexit opportunities, citing recent EU quota increases as a positive sign for the future.

Timothy Geaney admitted taking or permitting images of young boys partially dressed in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014, resulting in a community payback order and placement on the sex offenders register; the General Teaching Council Scotland subsequently removed him from the teaching register after finding his conduct fundamentally incompatible with the profession, noting the lengthy duration demonstrated a pattern of behavior rather than an isolated incident, concluding there was a strong likelihood of recurrence due to the volume of images and lack of remedial action, and prohibiting him from re-registering for two years.

A fire on 2 March at a Duncan Street site operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited (run by Asset and Land Group) reduced train services and caused travel delays, requiring firefighters to spend several days at the scene; the Environment Agency suspended the company from accepting waste and later revoked its environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed, meaning the company cannot operate from the site after that date but must still remove all waste, though the fire service noted the operators were "broadly compliant" with fire safety law despite nine visits in the last 12 months and having raised concerns with the EA in February about potential fire impacts, and the cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its entire chemical weapons stockpile, blaming attacks on shipments, including one intercepted by "terrorist groups," and emphasizing the ongoing war; the government denied using barrel bombs in Aleppo despite reports of civilian casualties, accused the US of supporting terrorists, and disputed rebel claims of seizing Aleppo's central prison, with state media insisting the attack was thwarted while opposition sources reported rebel control; Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 4% removed so far, raising international concerns about the delayed destruction process, though Syria remains committed to its agreements.

England won the second Test against Pakistan by a large margin at Old Trafford to level the series, scoring 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared. Joe Root was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with his bowling contributions. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, while Root himself reflected on correcting errors from the first Test. Coach Trevor Bayliss noted Root's hard work. Commentators Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott lauded England's comprehensive victory, though Vaughan predicted a tight series. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment with his team's batting and confidence issues.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is calling on pensioners, their friends, and families to share their experiences of residential care to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies as part of her review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. This review will examine factors including physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, aiming to highlight both good care and the impact of poor care. Rochira emphasizes that the voices of older people and those who care for them are central to her work, and her team will also speak to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. While Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims, its chair, Mario Kreft, expresses disappointment that no care provider expert is represented on the main advisory panel, missing an opportunity for partnership working.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Dons midfielder who played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, winning a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s, has been player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, replacing Neil Cooper at Aberdeen; Arbroath were relegated to League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013-14, but Sheerin previously guided them to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011; Aberdeen CEO Duncan Fraser stated Sheerin was chosen after a comprehensive process, and despite Arbroath chairman John Christison wishing to retain him, he understood Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen.

Curtis and Paul Williams will temporarily manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking, with the club aiming to appoint Paul Clement as the new manager soon; Curtis expresses concern about the difficulty of Championship promotion if relegated, noting the league's strength and Swansea's potential inability to retain key players like Newcastle, while reflecting on the club's remarkable rise from bankruptcy near relegation in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011 under managers like Martinez, Rodgers, and Laudrup, believing the club has lost its way since Laudrup left in 2014 due to frequent management changes and diluted philosophy, though Curtis feels the current squad is strong enough to stay up and reminds new signings of the club's history using the documentary "Jack to a King" to emphasize the importance of avoiding relegation for the club and region.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated human genome mapping through a controversial commercial race, facing scientific vilification and criticism for his methods and lack of modesty, yet his efforts undeniably sped up the process; after the human genome project, he led the J Craig Venter Institute in creating the synthetic life form Synthia, published in Science; born in 1946, his early life included poor scholarship, surfing, military service in Vietnam during the Tet offensive which instilled a sense of urgency, and a shift from medical practice to research at NIH where he developed faster gene sequencing techniques by focusing on RNA rather than the entire genome; he founded private institutes including Celera Genomics to compete with the public human genome project, achieving significant milestones like sequencing the first free-living organism's genome, and used his wealth to pursue science independently; he also conducted oceanic research collecting microbial genomes and envisions synthetic microbes enabling a new industrial revolution by replacing oil and capturing carbon dioxide.

The Sutton Trust warns that many English apprenticeships are low quality and too short, citing that only 200,000 of 520,000 annual starts reach level three (A-level equivalent), compared to Germany where 51% of employers offer apprenticeships versus 20% in England, and Germany has 570,000 youth apprenticeships (90% level three) versus England's 61,000. The report notes England's vocational system has 18,000 qualifications versus Germany's 330, and since 2010, 58% of English apprenticeships were below level three and 75% targeted those over 25, with 11 young people competing per place. The Trust calls for expanding apprenticeships to 300,000 new starts yearly, prioritizing level three or higher for three to four years, with no more than 10% as two-year level two courses, arguing they are crucial for social mobility and economic competitiveness. The Association of Colleges agrees on the need for high-quality apprenticeships but highlights challenges in creating 300,000 places and preserving respected level two courses like construction. The Department for Education states it is reforming apprenticeships to drive up standards, ensuring they last at least a year, include English and maths, and are jobs.

Sarah Storey won a cycling race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska, and is targeting further Paralympic success at the Rio Games the following year; she is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) across both cycling and swimming in six Paralympics, won four golds at the 2012 London Games, has 21 world titles, and began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United was expelled from the Football Conference Premier after failing to meet multiple extended deadlines to pay £148,000 owed to football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle, players, staff, and other clubs, despite the Conference bending over backwards to help them; this expulsion came despite the players' efforts on the final day of the season keeping the club up, and resulted in Chester being reinstated in their place, with the Bulls' financial decline since relegation from the Football League in 2012, exacerbated by falling attendances, leading to debts of approximately £225,000 and an offer by the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club for £1 being rejected in favour of new owner Tommy Agombar.

The former Manchester City player, aged 30, earned 61 senior England caps after debuting in 2009, featuring in two World Cups and two European Championships but playing only three minutes at Euro 2016. He holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46, starting in 2004, and scored his only international goal against Moldova in the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. Milner stated a decision was "about common sense" regarding Sam Allardyce, wishing the players, staff, and supporters future success.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after an illness, with a private funeral and future memorial service; he was a highly influential conductor and leading figure in the early-music movement, founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directing it for 30 years across six continents, where the ensemble made over 200 CDs including the first complete Mozart symphonies cycle on period instruments and the acclaimed 1980 Handel's Messiah recording; he studied keyboard at Cambridge and with renowned teachers, held positions with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and the Early Music Consort of London, and served as artistic director for the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, while also teaching at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell; colleagues remembered him as extraordinarily generous, a great ambassador for historically informed music, a natural academic with an amazing capacity for information, and a genial person whose legacy will be greatly missed.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected, was removed from mainstream schooling in June as he was not coping; his mother gave up her job to care for him. The family requested a special school place but is still waiting, as all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are full with no timeframe for availability. The boy feels isolated as he cannot attend school like his siblings. An extra classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school, offering hope he can start soon, but his mother fears other families will face similar issues due to over-subscribed special needs schools. The Education Authority cannot comment on individual cases due to privacy concerns but is reviewing the profile of need for special school places to ensure availability closer to children's homes, with work ongoing to assist placements from 2016.

Newport County FC holds a lease agreement at Rodney Parade until 2023 with primacy of fixtures as long as they remain in the Football League, and they expect this contract to be honoured despite the Welsh Rugby Union's takeover bid for fellow tenants Newport Gwent Dragons, which will be voted on in early May; the WRU views the venue as a rugby ground and plans to install an artificial surface, conflicting with Football League rules, though both Newport County and the squash club are protected under their current agreements, which the WRU has been informed of; on the pitch, Newport County is battling to avoid League Two relegation, with their chairman stating that dropping out of the Football League would be devastating for the club and city.

The passage describes a man's traumatic experiences as a child soldier in Sierra Leone's civil war, including kidnapping by RUF rebels, forced drug use, committing atrocities, and escaping to Freetown where he met a preacher who helped rehabilitate him and instilled a vision to rebuild the nation. During the 2014 Ebola crisis, he and his organization, Lifeline Nehemiah, combated the outbreak through community education (reaching over 10,000 people in local languages), distributing food to 11,000 individuals, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit with community support, saving many lives. He now views his life as transformed, regrets his past actions, and believes investing in young people is crucial for building the future.

The Wedgwood Museum's collection of about 80,000 works faced auction to cover pension debts after the company's 2009 collapse, but a public fundraising campaign launched in September reached its target within a month, allowing the collection to remain on display at the Barlaston museum; the Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria & Albert Museum before it is loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum, with administrator Bob Young and others expressing satisfaction and emphasizing the collection's importance to Staffordshire and Britain's cultural heritage and national identity.

Dan Groves noted finer points of a potential deal where Wright could purchase 20% of the club, with The Sun reporting the 30-year-old will become a club director; Billericay currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points outside the play-off places; Wright, who finished runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds; the club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who stated he is "comfortable" investing £10,000 a week; and Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, at the start of March.

Mark Carney surprised many by extending his term as Governor of the Bank of England for only one year, until 2019, instead of leaving in 2018 or staying until 2021. This decision was driven primarily by personal family circumstances: two daughters would finish A-levels and GCSEs in 2018, making it the ideal time for the family to return to Canada for their education. While professionally he recognized the challenge of leaving during Brexit negotiations and understood the need for market stability, he felt unable to extend beyond 2018 due to his family's plans. He emphasized the decision was entirely personal and unrelated to government policy or criticism of the Bank's economic forecasts. By 2019, the Article 50 process should be complete, allowing a new governor to manage the UK's economic future.

Blackpool took the lead through Jamille Matt after Nathan Delfouneso's assist, but Colchester equalized via Kurtis Guthrie from a corner. Key moments included Sam Slocombe's saves for Blackpool and a missed header by Tom Aldred. The match ended 1-1, with Colchester reduced to 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health, aims to help P6 and P7 children cope with change, particularly the stressful transition to secondary school, through interactive workshops that promote emotional wellbeing, encourage seeking help, and identify support sources, while also providing teachers with basic training; following a successful pilot in five schools, the charity hopes to roll it out across Northern Ireland, addressing the need to strengthen young people's resilience as highlighted by the chief inspector of schools.

The disused Fawley power station chimney, which dominated the Solent skyline at 198 metres high after powering one million homes for over 40 years since its 1971 commissioning, is planned to become the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard as the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside. This development, acquired in 2016, includes a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth, with architects proposing a petal-shaped glass structure; developers argue keeping the existing chimney requires relatively little investment compared to building new attractions like Brighton's i360 or Portsmouth's Spinnaker Tower, and building could start in 2018 after outline planning permission is applied for later in the year.

At the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old Latham earned GB's second medal, bronze in the men's scratch race, after chasing down gold medallist Adrian Teklinski of Poland and silver medallist Lucass Liss of Germany; GB were then beaten to bronze in the men's team pursuit by Italy. Elsewhere, Joe Truman was eliminated in the men's keirin semi-final, the women's team pursuit squad finished fifth in the heats and missed the bronze-medal ride, and Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint. Latham expressed happiness with his medal, while analysts like Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised his final charge and sensible riding; Elinor Barker, who had won silver earlier, noted the young women's team's potential despite their fifth-place finish, and Joanna Rowsell Shand highlighted their bright future; Marchant expressed disappointment with her sprint exit but focused on the process leading to Tokyo.

Ross Kemp is briefly returning to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for the final episodes of Peggy Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, who is being killed off after her cancer returned; Kemp agreed to the return as he couldn't turn down the opportunity to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time, calling it the right thing to do for his close friend Barbara, and executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins states this will showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden (Phil) at their best as the brothers face losing their mother.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds as Tottenham disappointed at Anfield, with manager Pochettino criticizing their lack of desire and inability to cope with pressure, stating it's difficult to fight for the Premier League when starting games poorly; Spurs have won only twice on the road since 24 September and just once in their last 17 away matches against top-six sides, while former player Danny Murphy noted their defensive disarray, suggesting they should have stuck with their usual back three against big teams and highlighted a lack of pace and different mindset away from home.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts declared, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999, which lost the presidency last month and key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Adamawa, though it retained Rivers State and won eight governorships mostly in the south-east; the APC made historic gains, controlling most northern states and Lagos for the first time since 1999, but failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, raising concerns for President-elect Buhari regarding oil revenue and militant groups; elections saw 66 violent incidents, mostly in southern states, but were more peaceful than previous years, suggesting maturing democracy, while the PDP faces introspection after 16 years in power, plagued by corruption allegations, insurgency failures, and defections.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) takes place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, featuring acts including The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean; visitors can use an app to trigger online information from signs and posters, accessing videos and band interviews on their devices, allowing people globally to interact with the festival and capture its atmosphere, with messages updated before and during the event for instant access to information, interviews, ticket purchases, and a taste of the festival.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, have had their funding agreements terminated by the Secretary of State, while Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned their funding could be terminated unless concerns were addressed; Ofsted reports cited issues like inadequate safeguarding against extremism, improper vetting of external speakers, segregation of boys and girls, and failure to promote pupils' spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development, with Lord Nash demanding actions including ending less favourable treatment of non-Muslims and ensuring a broad curriculum; a head teacher described feeling undermined by parents during inspections, and school spokespeople indicated they would challenge the reports legally, while some parents disputed the findings.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was sentenced to five years in Iran for undisclosed charges related to allegedly plotting to topple the government; her appeal hearing was held secretly in Tehran. She has been imprisoned since her arrest at Tehran Airport, spending time in solitary confinement, while her two-year-old daughter Gabriella remains in Iran after her passport was confiscated and is cared for by grandparents. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, criticized the UK government for inaction, believes she is being used as a diplomatic bargaining chip, and described her emotional distress including suicidal thoughts and a hunger strike, though she has shown more resilience since moving out of solitary confinement. Their daughter has lost her English and become fluent in Farsi, and Richard is seeking a visa to visit them. Amnesty International declared her a "prisoner of conscience" and hopes the appeal will result in her immediate release.

Vincent Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich where eye specialist Honey Rose allegedly failed to detect his swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation; the prosecution claims this failure prevented treatment for a fluid buildup in his brain that increased skull pressure and caused his death, arguing her conduct was so negligent it constituted gross negligence manslaughter, though she denies the charge.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity with a man he found online between September 2013 and September 2014, filming the encounters, and sending a sexually explicit clip to the woman's sister on Christmas Day 2014; he was also convicted of causing the woman's sister and father to view sexual images and behaving abusively on that date. The victim stated she felt "blackmailed," and Sheriff George Way remitted the case to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its severity, noting the sentence must "reflect society's abhorrence" at the conduct; Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register, assessed as posing a "moderate risk" of re-offending despite being a first offender, and his defence counsel described his remand as a "dramatic shock."

Ireland scored 165-5 in Greater Noida, with Thompson (56), Wilson (41*), and Porterfield (39) contributing after Stirling fell early. Afghanistan chased down the target, winning by 6 wickets with 2 overs to spare, thanks to Shenwari (56) and Shahzad (47). Ireland felt they could have reached 180 but fell short with the ball, and they were further hampered by Rankin's back injury absence for the T20s, though he is expected back for the ODIs starting March 15.

Barcelona insists they committed no offense regarding Neymar's transfer, despite paying an initial £48.6m fee while the total cost including wages and fees reached £106.8m; former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid investigation allegations, a judge ruled there's sufficient evidence to continue investigations, and Barcelona made a complimentary tax payment of €13.5m to cover potential interpretations of their tax obligations, while Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a Koh Tao beach on 15 September; Metropolitan Police officers visited Thailand to review the investigation, where two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, potentially facing the death penalty, though the UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about DNA verification and alleged mistreatment; post-mortems showed Miller died from drowning and a head blow, while Witheridge died from head wounds, with Thai police stating DNA found on her matched the suspects.

Virtual reality is increasingly used across diverse sectors: the UK's National Autistic Society created a VR film to help the public understand autism by simulating sensory overload in a shopping centre, while Alzheimer's Research UK released "A Walk Through Dementia" to show daily challenges. Retailers like IKEA use VR for virtual kitchen design tours and Westfield showcases fashion; healthcare employs VR for surgical training (e.g., Dr. Shafi Ahmed's live surgery broadcast) and treating phobias (e.g., 83% improvement in spider tolerance in one study). Education benefits through Google Expeditions virtual field trips and Marcus Storm's language app for Mandarin, though hardware costs and engagement monitoring challenges exist.

The black box of the downed Su-24 jet was opened in Moscow, revealing missing flight data crucial to resolving the dispute over whether the jet was hit in Turkish or Syrian airspace; the jet was shot down by Turkish F-16s on November 24th, killing the pilot and a Russian marine sent to rescue the crew, while the navigator was rescued. The incident caused a major diplomatic crisis, leading Russia to impose sanctions including a ban on package holidays, demand an apology from Turkey, and accuse its government of subservience to the US and "creeping Islamisation," while Turkey insists the jet ignored warnings to leave its airspace. An analysis of the black box data is expected next week.

Scotland has won all five qualifiers and hosts Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, where victory would almost secure their place in the finals; Rachel Evans expresses desperation to avoid another play-off loss after previous near-misses for Euro 2013 and the World Cup, describing it as potentially more heartbreak than humiliation. Iceland, ranked slightly higher but also unbeaten, will likely decide the group winner with the outcome of these matches; Scotland is in a strong position to qualify automatically as one of the best six runners-up. Evans notes the team's step-by-step approach and the emotional significance of reaching finals, while highlighting the squad's significant international presence (players in England, Sweden, US) which benefits the national team through exposure to different playing styles and high-level competition. Evans herself recently won the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, describing the experience as "mind-blowing" and believing playing abroad improves the team's quality.

The Commission on Local Tax Reform, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, found no "magic bullet" to fix the council tax system's inherent defects, which were present from its inception and worsened by lack of modification. Prof Kenneth Gibb's review of international systems showed property tax is widely used, stable, and hard to avoid but is confusing and seen as unfair as it's not income-linked, while local income tax is perceived as fairer but creates revenue volatility for local authorities and limits rate variation. The commission concluded reform is always difficult due to past experiences and traumas, and despite the council tax's deficiencies, change is a major undertaking; it will now hold public consultation before reporting in autumn, awaited by the Scottish government which considers the current system unfair.

Apple implemented security changes to prevent third-party tools like Elcomsoft's software from accessing iCloud backups without authorization, requiring two-factor authentication (a four-digit code sent to a trusted device) for first-time logins and backup downloads, which previously bypassed this protection; while this now sends email notifications and blocks access without the code, the feature remains opt-in, with experts like Prof. Alan Woodward arguing it should be the default, and concerns exist about the 14-character recovery key being lost or stolen, though Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable it and use stronger passwords, as CEO Tim Cook emphasizes increased awareness.

UKIP won the election spending £2,956,737 (68p per vote), the Conservatives spent £2,980,815 (79p per vote), the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote) and lost 11 MEPs, Labour came second spending £1,027,339 (26p per vote), the Greens spent £534,249 (43p per vote), and the SNP spent £267,372; the six highest-spending parties totalled £9,347,087, with all except Labour spending more than in 2009.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has cancelled his Barrow contract by mutual consent to join their National League rivals, having previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, and could face his old club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams, has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, with his move subject to international clearance; Nicholson describes Anderson as a leader-type and Keating as young but hungry. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day; veterinary staff pronounced him dead, and the British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, an incident described as rare and not necessarily linked to underlying health issues. Although Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia symptoms like overheating and wobbling, he showed no such symptoms on the day of his death, and the report concluded his death was due to the rare haemorrhage, not his previous condition.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional during farewell speeches from Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, both stepping down before the May 5th election. Salmond emphasized Scotland's diversity and consensus, welcomed powers under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling referendum pledges, joked about the Cheltenham races overshadowing his speech, and declared serving the parliament the greatest honour in public life. McNeil warned Holyrood needed to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding accountability and scrutiny in its committee system. Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also stepped down, joking she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney's faux indignation. Marwick thanked Salmond for his distinguished service as both MSP and First Minister.

Emma Watson stars as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou in this live-action adaptation, with Kevin Kline cast as Maurice and an unnamed star playing Mrs. Potts; Bill Condon directs the film, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and is set for a US release on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will meet victims' relatives at 11:00 BST to reveal its decisions on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, which killed 96 football fans; new inquests last year found the fans were unlawfully killed, with 15 suspects linked to Operation Resolve investigating the disaster causes and 8 linked to an IPCC probe into police conduct afterwards; Margaret Aspinall, whose son died, expressed hope for closure and emphasized the families' long struggle and demand for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison reported numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its wall, with a local resident witnessing this four times in two weeks and the prison holding an evening meeting for residents; a former inmate described the jail as notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, though the Ministry of Justice denied evidence of drone use at the site; the Ministry acknowledged staff efforts to stop contraband but stated more must be done and that new laws impose up to two-year jail sentences for smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School when she stepped out to escort a woman and child across the road on a red light; Wright, who claims he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot recall the light color, admits hitting her but denies dangerous driving causing serious injury, and expressed deep remorse to the court, where the trial continues.

Laura Muir will miss next year's Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine exams in April, prioritizing her degree over the event despite her disappointment and love of running for Scotland. The 24-year-old, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the recent World Championships, is targeting the World Indoor Championships in March and hopes to run in Birmingham, feeling she's in reasonable shape and has significant future potential, including at least two or three more Olympics.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after walking home from a Christmas party; an ongoing search involving excavations in a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, near the River Liffey, is expected to take weeks. Earlier this year, detectives reviewed the case and enhanced CCTV footage showing Deely talking to a man in black outside his workplace on Baggot Street, where he had returned to get an umbrella; the same man was later seen following Deely on Haddington Road. Gardaí have appealed for this man to come forward but have not yet identified him.

Del Potro, ranked 165th after missing over two years due to wrist injuries and three surgeries, secured a 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 victory over Wawrinka, reaching his first Grand Slam since the 2014 Australian Open; he will next face Pouille or Young. Kyrgios, also in Murray's half, came back from two sets down to defeat Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 after rain delays and will play Lopez in the third round. Elsewhere, Berdych and Tsonga won routine matches, defeating Becker and Monaco respectively.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to CAF for complaints lodged after a controversial penalty in their 2015 quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, which they lost despite leading late. Morocco, banned from the 2017 qualifying draw after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, had their ban overturned and fine reduced by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Both teams qualified for the 2017 tournament, with Tunisia drawn in Group A against Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, and Morocco in Group F against Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome; Tunisia noted that reaching the finals would mark their 13th consecutive appearance, a record.

McLaren, a historically dominant F1 team with 182 wins, 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a significant slump, focusing on fourth-row grid positions and decent points despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso. Their decline began in 2013 with chassis design issues, though they now have a competitive car hampered by Honda engine problems, a stark contrast to their successful Honda partnership era (1988-1992) featuring Senna and Prost, and later successes with Hakkinen (1998-99) and Hamilton/Button (2012). McLaren's history is characterized by cycles of triumph and decline, including periods of struggle like the current one, punctuated by scandals such as the 2007 Ferrari information breach and 2009 'lie-gate'. Despite past setbacks and the recent lack of titles since 2008 (except Hamilton's 2008 driver title), Ron Dennis believes the team is turning the corner, with the car now strong and Honda improving, and he predicts McLaren will break Mercedes' hegemony and win future championships.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, with police finding people still present and till receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49 BST; the judge ordered the bar closed for three months, and license holder Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, with a defence solicitor noting licensing laws were not strictly adhered to and the premises ran improperly into the morning; the judge described Ms. O'Neill's record as appalling and expressed concern about lacking power for a custodial sentence, fining her £3,000 and Mr. Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA single-season three-point record by making eight three-pointers to finish with 45 points, leading the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers; Klay Thompson added 26 points. Elsewhere, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol recording 16 points and 15 rebounds, and Derrick Rose scoring 12 points; the Heat were outscored 57-27 after halftime.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised at Melwood when YouTube star Bas van Velzen, initially thought to be a competition winner, showcased impressive free-kick skills instead. Van Velzen, known for his free-kick exploits online, wowed the quartet with his ability, including scoring a top-corner strike, and Balotelli also executed a well-taken free-kick. Van Velzen described the experience as amazing, particularly enjoying the players' reactions and pretending not to be skilled, and he even referenced Balotelli's infamous slogan.

Carriers of the BRCA1 gene mutation who have been diagnosed with breast cancer can significantly reduce their risk of death by undergoing an oophorectomy (ovary removal), as demonstrated by a Canadian study of 676 gene carriers; this procedure was associated with a 62% reduction in breast cancer death specifically for BRCA1 carriers, a 73% reduction when performed within two years of diagnosis, and a 65% reduction in death from all causes, with the protective effect lasting up to 15 years and being particularly effective for women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer, though no significant reduction was observed for BRCA2 carriers.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were killed when an Amtrak train (The Carolinian, No. 80) hit them on the tracks in Durham, North Carolina, shortly before 10 am on Easter Sunday. The train was traveling from Charlotte to New York City on Norfolk-Southern property. None of the 166 passengers were injured, though one received treatment for illness during the delay. The train was delayed for approximately two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its route. The couple was pronounced dead at the scene.

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member who became a key DEA informant for 27 years after fleeing Colombia, faces deportation despite being promised US citizenship in exchange for his work, which aided in the prosecution of major figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega; now retired due to declining health and living illegally in the US, he fears for his life if sent back to Colombia, the DEA has refused to help him secure citizenship, and he remains in legal limbo unable to collect benefits while preparing to go into hiding if necessary.

The US internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for allegedly using the new ".sucks" domain names to extract exorbitant sums from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift, and major companies including YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo, who pay to have these domains removed. ICANN initially approved the domains but is backtracking after industry groups called the practice a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory," citing the high $2,499 annual fee charged by Vox Populi, which plans to lower it to $10 for the public later. ICANN has sent letters to US and Canadian regulators to determine if the actions are illegal, potentially breaching Vox Populi's contract.

A baby boy's body was found wrapped in a Sainsbury's bag in a Norfolk pond in 1988; the case remained unsolved for 27 years until police exhumed the body last year and used DNA from a leg bone matched against the national database to identify his mother. The woman, arrested on suspicion of infanticide, explained she concealed the pregnancy and the baby was stillborn, which police accepted after ruling out foul play; she remains on bail pending a decision on charges for failing to register the birth and preventing lawful burial. The baby was reburied at Weasenham St Peter church with a headstone named Peter after the church.

Kristopher Hicks, then 23, suffered severe brain injuries and developed epilepsy requiring 24/7 care after jumping from a taxi driven by Michael Young, who mistakenly believed Hicks planned to skip his fare and unlawfully drove him back to the rank; the High Court ruled Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to compensation set at approximately 50% of the family's requested amount (thought to be hundreds of thousands of pounds) plus £250, with both sides granted permission to appeal.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas Wednesday night as storms brought reported twisters, including one spotted near Goddard that moved northeast, missing Wichita but threatening other communities; CNN expert Chad Myers warned of dangerous nighttime tornadoes and additional sightings came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna, while in Missouri, a tornado reportedly touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and roof damage, with hail also reported near Farmington, and the National Weather Service forecast more storms for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold, aiming for a fourth consecutive victory and a title shot, plans to dominate Lyoto Machida by cutting off his movement, being aggressive like a bull against a matador, and exploiting Machida's perceived weaknesses in striking and ground game, believing he has multiple advantages. Machida, confident he can win by applying his technique and strategy, states the winner deserves a title shot and feels well-prepared after an eight-week camp. Both fighters express mutual respect while Rockhold emphasizes his diverse skills and Machida highlights his own preparation and readiness.

A light general aviation aircraft landed without deploying its landing gear at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, skidding on its belly and causing its propellers to strike the runway with a loud sound; the pilot, Chris Georgaklis, realized the error, re-engaged the engines, and took off again, managing to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely despite the damage; the FAA is investigating the incident, which was captured on video.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Touré's performances this season but pledged his support for the Manchester City midfielder until at least the end of the season, despite the club being willing to listen to offers for the Ivorian as part of an overhaul of an ageing squad following a faltering campaign; Touré, who has two years left on his contract, has faced criticism for his form, and City's poor league form is noted, with captain Vincent Kompany potentially missing the rest of the season due to injury, while goalkeeper Joe Hart admitted players have let the manager down but retain his backing, and separately, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has warned left-back Aaron Cresswell against moving to City, citing the lack of playing time experienced by other English players there.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive living in the UK for over 20 years under the name Marc Skinner, was convicted in absentia in Italy in 1999 for Cosa Nostra membership and received a seven-year sentence; after losing his extradition battle in February, it emerged his sentence expired last October under Italian law, which extinguishes sentences after double the penalty time has passed, leading to the withdrawal of his European arrest warrant and allowing him to remain in the UK, with the Crown Prosecution Service admitting an administrative error contributed to the outcome.

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury; this race marks McCoy's last ride in a Grade One event, with his final rides not confirmed until Friday morning, ironically occurring after he announced his retirement following a victory on Mr. Mole at Newbury in February; other runners include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, her body found 33 days later in a garage near her home; Ritter initially avoided seeing crime scene photos but viewed them last year, expressing regret and a desire for revenge after seeing her daughter's swollen, vomit-covered body with pulled-out hair and blood on her scalp; Barrett, arrested in 2006 after DNA matched his to the victim's clothing, was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years; the case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable he won't win the Masters to complete his career grand slam, considering it a career-long goal to join an elite group of only six players to win all four majors; he views his final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011 as the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons for future major leads, and despite having only one top-10 Masters finish in six appearances, he is focused on playing his best rather than fixating on the achievement, seeing the golf course as his sanctuary from the surrounding pressure and hype.

This week's trending stories include four rainbows appearing in the New York sky after heavy rain, captured by CEO Amanda Curtis; exotic dancers at wakes in rural China facing a vice crackdown; Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during a UK interview about his private life; the "Kylie Jenner Challenge" involving lip plumping to resemble Kylie Jenner; 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting her past with filmmakers; a prom-posal referencing bombs causing controversy with racism accusations; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp appearing nearly unrecognizable in the Black Mass trailer; a pregnancy announcement referencing Fresh Prince of Bel-Air; and a military dad photobombing his son.

Hundreds of children were hospitalized in England last year due to fetal alcohol syndrome, with 272 youngsters admitted, though experts warn the actual number affected could be far greater; research by the World Health Organisation suggests at least one in 100 UK babies, equating to about 7,500 annually, could suffer learning, behavioural, and physical problems from prenatal alcohol exposure, a condition described as an enormous, under-diagnosed problem by Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome; a specific case of 15-year-old Niamh Brown illustrates the lifelong impacts, including needing help with daily tasks and an inability to live independently; other medical issues associated with maternal drinking during pregnancy include problems with the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy; while government advice recommends pregnant women consume no more than two units of alcohol up to twice a week, Mitchell believes the guidance should advise complete abstinence.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, nicknamed "Boomerang Boy" for always returning home after crimes, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15 by waving an axe at assistant Andrea Brighty; however, owner Sab Dhillon rugby-tackled him, causing shelves to fall, and during the struggle, Dhillon's wife Sam hit McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him, before police arrived and arrested him; McKerry, who had a long criminal history starting at age 12 with 80 arrests by 15 and convictions for various crimes, pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was jailed for six years.

Four Royal Navy sailors charged with gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian barracks on April 10 must remain in Nova Scotia until trial, having been granted bail with conditions including surrendering passports, living at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax, continuing Royal Navy employment, not leaving the province, and not contacting the victim or witnesses. The alleged assault occurred after the sailors returned from a hockey tournament at Shearwater naval base. The men, aged 23 to 35, face charges of sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, punishable by up to 14 years in prison, with the investigation still ongoing.

Four-year-old RJ Jackson suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an incredibly rare congenital skin disease affecting only 70 people worldwide, causing his skin to appear red, inflamed, and scaly; his mother Valerie Jackson must regularly apply creams to manage his painful symptoms, but faces public ignorance and accusations of child abuse, including being surrounded by armed police after a stranger mistook his condition for abuse, and RJ is also denied access to play centers and subjected to cruel taunts from adults.

Protein World's controversial "beach body ready" posters featuring model Renee Somerfield on the London Underground are being removed by Transport for London (TFL) after their paid three-week advertising period ended, though TFL noted customer feedback; the campaign sparked significant backlash, including a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures, more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) for promoting unhealthy body image, and poster defacements, while Protein World defended the campaign aggressively on social media, reported receiving bomb threats, and stated sales of their protein powder are rising significantly in the UK market.

Rail firms faced criticism for planning fare hikes up to 87% shortly after the general election, despite party leaders pledging freezes; Prime Minister David Cameron personally intervened, writing to First Great Western to urgently review its plan to almost double fares on the London-Cotswolds route through his Witney constituency, where an off-peak return would rise from £33.30 to £62.40. Other significant increases included a 24.5% hike on a Stafford-Liverpool anytime return and a 22% rise on a Manchester-Stoke anytime first-class day return, with Virgin Trains defending its hikes by noting they affected cheaper Virgin-only fares and its overall increase was below the industry average.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in one eye after thugs threw a brick through his front door in Oldham when he confronted them about throwing stones at his property. The attack occurred three weeks after his wedding to Elaine, 54, while they were writing thank-you cards in their front room. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his left eye, leaving him with a permanent disability and feeling unsafe in his home. Police are investigating but have found no apparent motive, suggesting it may have been random vandalism by youths "messing around."

Tom Poynton, the 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension, rewarding his successful return from injury after missing the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident that killed his father Keith last April; he underwent ankle surgery and made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi, and the new contract commits him to the county until the end of the 2016 season, with elite performance director Graeme Welch praising his exceptional character and good form since his return.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw, diagnosed with neuroblastoma affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, underwent intensive treatments including chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, during which he decorated his protective mask like a Ninja Turtle to feel brave; after battling the aggressive cancer for a year, doctors declared him cancer-free, though he will require regular check-ups, and his story gained international attention leading to gifts from Nickelodeon and awards from Cancer Research UK.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to concentrate on his Aston Villa career rather than deciding between international offers from the Republic of Ireland and England, emphasizing that Grealish must first establish himself further with the club; Sherwood, impressed by Grealish's confident performances, states it's ultimately up to the player to choose his national team, comparing the situation to his advice for another player to follow his heart, while Grealish's father agrees his son should prioritize club football first, with the player currently split between the two nations and potentially playing for both in an upcoming friendly.

Private jet landing fees vary dramatically across airports, revealing unexpectedly popular hubs for the wealthy like Salzburg and Darwin, with fees reaching thousands per landing; private jet travel is a growing trend, with 2.5 million flights recorded in the US in 2013 and a market worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe, peaking during major events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix where costs can be extremely high; the most expensive airports for landing a 767-400 jet are Haneda in Tokyo (£4,559), Narita in Tokyo (£3,728), and Kansai in Osaka (£3,594), with other top-10 airports including Dublin (£2,729), Bristol (£2,929), Toronto (£3,461), Darwin (£3,059), LaGuardia (£2,630), and Salzburg (£2,530).

Katie Gallegos from Oregon took her dogs Cooper and Daisy to McDonald's for ice cream, where Cooper quickly devoured his entire cone in one bite while Daisy took smaller licks; Gallegos explained Cooper always eats fast, so Daisy is fed first, and she defended the weekly treat, noting Cooper is healthy and the video has been viewed over seven million times; the dogs also visited Starbucks for a non-coffee "pup-uccino," which Cooper also consumed rapidly.

Gary Locke has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock on a three-year deal after successfully serving as interim boss, having taken over when Allan Johnston resigned in February; the 41-year-old, who previously joined as assistant manager last summer, has lost only once in seven games since his appointment and will speak at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, accuses Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because she applies doTERRA essential oils to his head and neck to help him stay calm and focused; teachers claim the oils smell and distract other students, leading to a letter from the school board calling it a "problem," but Kemp plans to fight the decision, and later the Lake County School District clarified they would not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue."

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach was destroyed by fire on Wednesday afternoon, obliterating 90 condos; intense smoke was visible from three miles away and melted paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews deployed cranes to combat the flames but could not enter the building, which eventually collapsed. The fire, under investigation, reportedly started near a car parked by the complex. The Sandpiper complex, used as holiday homes between May and November, left residents and the building manager who lived there distraught, having lost everything.

The Queen, approaching her 89th birthday, continues to enjoy riding her fell pony Carltonlima Emma in Windsor Great Park, preferring a silk scarf over a helmet due to concerns about her hair. Despite a knee injury reducing her riding frequency, she remains an enthusiastic equestrienne who has ridden since age four, starting with a Shetland pony named Peggy. She breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court and Highland ponies at Balmoral, and her horses are now ridden by her grandchildren. Fell ponies, one of the oldest breeds originating in Cumbria, were developed by Romans and Vikings for pack work before becoming popular riding ponies in the 1950s.
