A fatal argument between Brisbane neighbors Leon Yeaman, 55, and Phillip Pama, 28, ended with Yeaman dead after Pama allegedly punched him once in the head during a confrontation over noise; Yeaman was making loud music in his yard while Pama, a shift worker sleeping before his 3 am job, confronted him, escalating the situation where Pama claimed he hit blindly while being pushed, paramedics could not revive Yeaman who was pronounced dead at the scene around 11 pm Thursday, Pama was charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail surrendering his passport, adhering to a 6 pm to 2 am curfew, and reporting to police twice weekly, with the case due back in court on May 18.

Jilted music teacher Yulia Simonova, 52, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship for a classmate; she offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) and specified she wanted him beaten, with arms and legs broken and kidneys damaged to cause slow bleeding, before she would "finish him" herself; police conducted a sting operation, sending an undercover officer posing as a hitman who filmed the exchange and arrested Simonova after she handed over expense money; she now faces 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder.

José Mourinho talks to God daily but never about football, only for personal matters, and he separates his professional and family life; he has strong faith, attends church regularly only in Portugal, considers himself a good person despite his competitive nature, works with the World Food Programme against hunger, and believes a person is more than their professional life.

Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years before retiring in 2007, returned to the show on its April 1st edition after an eight-year absence. At 91 years old, he looked energetic and hosted the first game, "Lucky Seven," before seamlessly handing hosting duties back to current host Drew Carey, demonstrating he hadn't missed a beat.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested at 12:30 AM on Friday in Washington D.C. on the 3200 block of D Street SE after allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight; he faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Metropolitan Police made the arrest when officers returned to the scene. The Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave; he is posted to the Foreign Missions branch, which handles diplomatic activities. Baldwin was scheduled for arraignment Friday afternoon, and no attorney was listed. This arrest follows another incident where a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave due to misconduct allegations under investigation by the Homeland Security Inspector General, and comes after a March 4 incident where two high-ranking agency officials were accused of driving into a secure White House area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life at a safari park by getting out of his car and creeping within 10 feet of a hungry male lion armed only with his camera to capture images; the lion, alerted by the camera shutter, aggressively jumped towards him, forcing Saeed to scramble back into his car, describing it as a close encounter he now wouldn't repeat.

New York City police released an image of a distinctive tattoo featuring the name "Monique" across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose on the right leg of an unidentified woman found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn's Gravesend section; paramedics were unable to revive her, and she was pronounced dead that evening, with no identification found on her body, and investigators are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death while seeking public assistance through NYPD Crime Stoppers.

Hannah and Alex, returning to New Zealand from the UK in 2009 unable to afford property, built a solar-powered, wood and steel two-bedroom home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck over a year and a half. Located on a lot in Nelson, New Zealand, the home features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and allows them to live almost self-sufficiently using solar panels for electricity (first bill $25), gas for the stove and hot water, and spring water. The project cost approximately $25,000 and the couple, along with their cat, love their home surrounded by nature.

Research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class significantly outperformed peers in classes with no iPads or where each student had their own device in early literacy tests, scoring around 30 points higher; the researcher attributes this to collaborative learning around the technology rather than just collaboration itself, suggesting schools should reconsider how tablets are used, especially in early grades, to maximize effectiveness, based on a study involving 352 students in a midwestern suburban school district.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters, as shown in a heartwarming video where it takes unsteady steps, wobbles, and forages with its snout to the ground; it belongs to farmer Ms. Duan in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, and mixes with its four-legged siblings, with villagers flocking to see it; nicknamed "Super Pig," it demonstrates remarkable balance and has captured thousands of hearts, similar to a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo that also became a star attraction.

Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dale Coyne Racing, was injured when struck by Francesco Dracone's car during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday; Dracone spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25 during a stop for tires and fuel, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg at the infield care center and was released. Many cars struggled with traction due to rain before the race, and Dracone did not finish, placing 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his dancer wife Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, four days after their wedding in Rio de Janeiro, as captured on horrific CCTV footage showing him dragging her limp body, smashing her head into concrete 11 times, punching her face 10 times, and then shooting her five times at point-blank range; he confessed to the brutal act driven by jealousy over men looking at her, having previously yelled at her calling her a slut and whore; neighbors heard the argument and subsequent gunshots; Sena performed with the dance group Jaula das Gostozuedas; after the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but crashed it during his getaway, and police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle; he now faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed her severe mental health battle, driven by anxiety, stress, thyroid disease, and isolation, which led her to feel life was not worth living and she couldn't see a way out; she now accepts being an anxious person and believes anxiety is becoming the "new depression," intrinsically linked to depression, and notes one in three Australian women will experience anxiety, while providing helpline information for those needing help.

Elena Curtin, a seven-months-pregnant Portland woman, was charged with second-degree assault after finding her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom in November 2014; when asked to leave, the ex refused, prompting Curtin to strike her in the head and arm with a crowbar. Prosecutors dropped the charge because Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage" under Oregon law allowing physical force against an intruder who won't leave. Curtin gave birth in January, and if convicted, she would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of nearly six years.

Gemma the pit bull, filmed at home in California, was fed treats but reacted with disgust when her owner tricked her by adding a broccoli spear; she chomped on it briefly before spitting it out on the floor, and the passage expresses hope that the two children she lives with do not follow her lead in disliking vegetables, noting that Gemma also enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page, specifically the defunct Young Entrepreneur Awards page which had its URL registration allowed to expire after the awards were scrapped in 2011, enabling a porn site to take over the address; the bank removed the hyperlink from its community projects webpage, denied any association with the external site, and assured the public its website remained secure while apologizing for the inconvenience.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 after smelling smoke when a fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah in a second-floor bedroom; during the 11-minute call, Marcus stayed calm, gave firefighters directions to their location, soothed his sister, and reminded her to stay low and breathe, allowing firefighters to rescue them by entering through the home and breaking a window, after which both siblings were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries while the other family members escaped on their own.

Blue fluorescent algae, specifically noctiluca scintillans, has been lighting up Australia's east coast, with images captured in Jervis Bay on the south coast of NSW by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who described the neon glow illuminating a popular beach as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar display occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, and according to Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales, this single-celled phytoplankton blooms in spring and autumn, usually due to natural causes, and is carnivorous, preying on diatoms while emitting light as a defense mechanism.

New tests like EndoPredict analyze tumor genetics after surgery to determine recurrence risk, allowing some women with as low as a five per cent chance of relapse to avoid chemotherapy's severe side effects like hair loss and nausea, as the test's accuracy matches or exceeds chemo's effectiveness; while currently private and costing about £2,500, experts argue NHS adoption could save money by reducing unnecessary chemo use, enabling informed patient choices and sparing many gruelling treatments.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious, with eighteen other ships like HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond also reporting emergency evacuations; the Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting pregnancies occurred before deployment or during leave, following the case of Commander Sarah West who was flown back after allegations of a relationship with a crew member, leading to an investigation; women have served in the Royal Navy since 1990, with around 9% female personnel in 2014 and three becoming the first female submariners in 2015; additionally, nearly 100 female soldiers were evacuated from Afghanistan between 2006-2013 due to pregnancy, and 102 from Iraq, as military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium, a small camera, and smoke flares was found on the rooftop of Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence, raising terrorism concerns; the discovery occurred on the same day a court approved restarting two nuclear reactors, a move unpopular with many Japanese citizens who fear nuclear dangers; police are investigating the drone's origin, and the government expressed worry about potential drone terrorism at future events like the Olympics and G7 summit, noting current laws lack drone flight restrictions around most government buildings in Tokyo, including the Prime Minister's residence, where Abe was not present as he was attending a conference in Indonesia.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer's disease to work daily on the back of his motorbike because he fears she would get lost if left alone; he ties a sash around both their waists for safety during the four-kilometer, hour-long journey, and his employers at the bank provide her with a room where he checks on her frequently, as his wife works in another city and his son is still in school, and he feels a duty to care for her after she devoted her life to raising him.

Heavy drinking among Americans increased 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, largely driven by rising rates among women, according to a University of Washington study published in the American Journal of Public Health. Defined as exceeding one drink per day for women or two for men on average, heavy drinking affected 8% of Americans in 2012. Binge drinking, defined as four or more drinks for women or five for men on a single occasion at least monthly, affected 18% in 2012 and saw a greater increase among women than men. The study, tracking county-level data, found significant variations, with Madison County, Idaho reporting the lowest binge drinking rate (6%) and Menominee, Wisconsin the highest (36%). Researchers attribute the increases to changing social norms making heavy drinking more acceptable for women, economic factors like cheaper alcohol due to stagnant taxes, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing too many caesarean sections unnecessarily, putting women and their babies at risk of infections, complications, disability, or death; the rate in England has more than doubled since the early 1990s to just over a quarter, including planned procedures for anxiety or other non-medical reasons, while the World Health Organization recommends the rate should ideally be between 10% and 15% due to the dangers and higher costs (£2,369 for a planned caesarean compared to £1,665 for a natural birth), contradicting current NHS guidelines that allow the procedure without medical justification.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into Mark Conklin's Martha's Vineyard home, living there for at least a week, and selling his belongings in a yard sale; she faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Conklin discovered her sitting in his living room, where she claimed ownership of the house before fleeing in a gray Nissan pickup truck; police later found a broken window covered by a blanket. Filkins was arrested hours later when she attempted to re-enter the home. Police, who believe she sold or gave away items including deck chairs, a grill, tables, lamps, posters, cookware, linens, and a painting, are asking anyone who received these items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department, as they are also victims eligible for restitution; Filkins is next scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

Bella Crooke lost her iPhone at a friend's birthday party, and after it was handed into Albury police station, officers used the unlocked device to post humorous selfies and puns on her Facebook page, advising her to collect it and suggesting she add a password; when Bella arrived, officers recognized her from the posts without needing her name, she found their antics hilarious, and she later secured her phone with a password.

In Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa, a five-day-old baby hippo was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult males; the mother had been protecting her calf from younger hippos but remained with her herd during the adult brawl, leading to one sub-adult grabbing the calf, and when the mother attacked, the sub-adult bit down harder and flung the calf into the air, dragging it along the water surface, causing it to die hours later.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is listed at £575,000, significantly cheaper than neighboring properties, due to having only three years left on its lease; the cost per year (£191,000) is comparable to local rental rates for similar flats. The unmodernised maisonette is described as bright and well-proportioned with 1,990 sq/ft, featuring three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. If a buyer extends the lease, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million, though lease extension costs are estimated at £3.35-£4.5 million for a 90-year lease. A second, larger maisonette on the same street is also for sale at £595,000 with a similar short lease, generating significant market interest from locals, developers, and end-users, though experts warn of the massive premium required for lease extension.

Starbucks resolved a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada (7,000 US, 1,000 Canada) that began Friday evening, preventing credit card transactions and prompting baristas to give away free drinks; the outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, led some stores to close early, but all stores were expected to open for "business as usual" Saturday.

Terrorists are undergoing training and radicalization in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, where they engage in seemingly ordinary activities with an ulterior motive, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Historical incidents include extremists sent by hate preacher Abu Hamza to train in the Brecon Beacons in Powys in 1998, the 7/7 bombers rafting at the National Whitewater Centre in Bala in 2005, and the arrest of three Cardiff-based plotters in 2010 planning Mumbai-style attacks; Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, set up by Iraqi clerics. DC Jones stressed terrorism is not confined to large cities and emphasized the vital importance of community intelligence.

An Omura's whale, a species feared extinct and rarely sighted, was discovered washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn, marking the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia; identification was challenging for authorities and required DNA profiling to confirm the 5.68 m juvenile female. Environment Minister Albert Jacob deemed the find "highly significant" for scientists, as the species was only first described in 2003 and is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan, possessing a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features including 53 vertebrae; the carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and potential public display in museums.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding arguments that women's hormones disqualify them from leadership, citing Cheryl Rios' claim that Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president due to potential irrationality from hormones, while countering that male hormones have historically impaired male leaders' decisions and studies show women take fewer unnecessary risks; it highlights the pervasive, often unrecognized, gender bias in the workplace as the real barrier to women's advancement, evidenced by examples like corporate board demographics and professor ratings, and argues that equality benefits everyone economically and socially, concluding that systemic bias, not biology, limits women's potential and makes female candidates like Clinton face a steeper path to office.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, is auctioning over 200 antiques from his collection for around £100,000 to downsize his home; notable items include a hand-painted diorama of the Battle of Agincourt (estimated £4,000-£6,000), a longbow with mother-of-pearl handle, furniture, paintings, weapons, books, and chandeliers, with the sale taking place this Saturday in Gloucestershire; Hardy, a military historian and Tolkien student, expressed sadness about selling but trusts the auctioneers.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, whose body was found at their shared Winter Garden home after a well-being check; he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day and has been on the run since Saturday. Police determined foul play, and Shemansky, who has a history of bipolar mental illness, was involuntarily committed for attempted suicide, and is on parole for battery on law enforcement, was reportedly helped by his mother through a divorce. Neighbors suggest his mother may have prevented the visit due to legal concerns and that divorce stress, including recent "bad news" paperwork, may have triggered him; authorities have the murder weapon but haven't confirmed the cause of death. Shemansky was last seen fleeing without provisions or medication, and his estranged wife is preparing for his possible arrival; anyone with information should contact authorities at 407-656-3636.

Eugene, USA, was awarded the 2021 IAAF World Championships by the IAAF Council, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a "unique strategic opportunity" to host the event in the USA for the first time; Eugene had previously failed in its bid for the 2019 championships, which went to Doha, but a recent presentation convinced the IAAF of the city's capability. IAAF President Lamine Diack highlighted the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and the public as a key factor, noting the decision departs from procedure but accesses a key market. The passage also states that the 2007 World Championships in Osaka were similarly awarded without bidding and mentions Mo Farah winning gold in the men's 10000 metres at the 2013 championships in Moscow.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, targeted 56-year-old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan after seeing him flash cash at a London casino; she befriended him using her looks, accepting gifts and money. One night, after Hassan took her to Nobu restaurant and the Palm Beach casino where he gave her £1,000, she left his Islington flat door unlocked so her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler could enter. They tied up Hassan in his bedroom, kicked him to death during a vicious and sustained attack while ransacking the flat to find his hidden winnings, leaving him with multiple broken bones drowning in his own blood. They stole £3,000, his TV, and mobile phone. Granger was found guilty of Hassan's manslaughter (not murder) by a 10-2 majority and sentenced to 16 years in prison by Judge William Kennedy, who described the attack as "pitiless and wicked". Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and robbery, jailed for life with a minimum term of 36 years.

Cesc Fabregas has experienced a significant decline in form since a brilliant start to the season at Chelsea, struggling particularly in the second half, as evidenced by his poor international performance and only one assist in five Premier League games since mid-January, down from 15 by then; his former club Barcelona noted his historical pattern of post-Christmas slumps, attributing it to fatigue from playing every minute, and while Chelsea are on course for the Premier League title, Fabregas's dip raises concerns about his durability and impact, with manager Jose Mourinho hoping his recent assist signals a late-season resurgence crucial for securing the title.

West Ham are discussing a deal for Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United who impressed during a two-week trial with the academy and has offers from Belgian clubs, while also revealing season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289, the cheapest in the Premier League, to fill the 54,000 capacity for the 2016-17 season.

Police dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, despite substantial evidence including video footage, a dossier with names and car registrations, and a suspect's photograph being provided to Wiltshire police. The attack, which occurred while the hunt was using an artificial scent, left Lane with concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss after being kicked in the head. Police shelved the inquiry citing insufficient evidence, a decision condemned by Lane and others as pathetic and disgraceful, with Lane feeling let down and losing trust in the police. Wiltshire police confirmed the case is undetected but could be reopened with further information.

Adam Gadahn, an American known as "Azzam the American" who converted to Islam in 1995 and joined al-Qaeda, became the group's chief English-language propagandist, appearing in numerous videos threatening attacks on the US and urging Muslims to commit violence, including lone-wolf attacks using easily obtained firearms; he was indicted for treason in 2006 and was among the FBI's most wanted terrorists before being killed in January in a U.S. counterterrorism operation that also resulted in the deaths of U.S. citizen Ahmed Farouq and U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein, though neither Gadahn nor Farouq was specifically targeted.

Chinese parents are passionate about raising child prodigies, and a new basketball sensation has emerged with five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, who started playing at two and a half. A viral video showcases his dazzling skills, including scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. His incredible talent has won him legions of fans across basketball-mad China, with netizens stunned and leaving thousands of comments; some disbelief it's real, others ask about his father, and many express shame comparing their own skills to his, with one wishing to reincarnate.

Tom O'Carroll, a former leading member of the notorious Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off; O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer and key PIE activist, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25th to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation, a move embarrassing to Hacked Off as PIE had formed an alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL) which lobbied to lower the age of consent and legalize incest, and O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals"; Hacked Off, formed after the phone-hacking scandal, campaigns against the "biased and unfair" Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants a statutory press regulator as recommended by the Leveson inquiry, and a spokesman noted the meeting was open to the public.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk for a Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia presentation by the brand ten pieces, run by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss. Models paraded through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall against an ocean backdrop, showcasing a monochrome, androgynous collection of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways for day or night. Guests enjoyed nibbles from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria under sunny 28°C weather, while passers-by and beachgoers stopped to watch the show.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a family day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California, where he fed a rare white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions, accompanied by his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. Earlier in the week, Khan ended speculation about his next opponent by announcing he will fight former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri at welterweight on May 30, having chosen this match over potential bouts against Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, and Keith Thurman.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name mistakenly placed on Jerusalem's Mount Herzl memorial wall, which honors soldiers and terrorism victims, during Memorial Day preparations; his father objected, stating no permission was given and refusing his son's name listed among "soldiers of the occupation," while the organization Almagor also opposed his inclusion, calling his death a "rogue attack" not terrorism-related and demanding removal, threatening to remove their own members' names if he stayed; following complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel removed Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial wall and its website, and a panel of judges began hearing evidence against the three suspects in January.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son repeatedly chasing the family cat around the garden to use it as a pillow; the footage shows the cat licking its fur before the boy lies on top, the cat then immediately gets up and moves to a new spot, the boy follows and repeats the action, this sequence happens twice before the cat wanders off indoors, but a later video shows them reconciling with the boy gently feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness testifying for the federal government in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his varsity coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after jurors learned about his past drug dealing; he testified that officers on trial stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana during his 2007 arrest, which had expunged charges, but he also acknowledged a 2011 arrest and a 2008 DUI conviction, leading to his dismissal despite his apology and claims of having moved past that phase of his life.

An explosion at an oil storage facility at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China, injured six people, five by broken glass, after an oil leak sparked a huge fire; no toxic chemical spill was reported, and over 600 firefighters brought the fire under control. Residents heard the blast and felt tremors, and the plant, which produces the carcinogenic chemical used in polyester, was relocated to its current remote location in 2007 after protests over pollution concerns when it was originally slated for Xiamen; it also experienced another explosion in July 2013 without casualties or leaks.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa player, refuses to pull up his low socks above his shinpads due to a lifelong superstition, ignoring referees' requests, and uses children's shinpads without having been kicked in the shin yet; he was pleased to make his first Premier League start against QPR, acknowledging the manager's faith in him despite the tough relegation battle.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage" according to her grandmother Cissy Houston, who stated the 22-year-old is out of a medically induced coma but remains unresponsive and could live in this condition for a lifetime; a source confirmed she has been in the same neurological state for nearly three months, not responding to visitors or familiar voices, with a tracheostomy, though her father Bobby Brown claimed she is awake and watching him, and the family attorney stated she has improved, is out of ICU, and starting long rehabilitation, with doctors indicating she will have a long life but the quality of her life remains unknown.

Russia secured a 2-0 lead in their Fed Cup tie against Germany after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, following Svetlana Kuznetsova's straight-sets win over Julia Goerges earlier. Pavlyuchenkova noted Lisicki's powerful "boom-boom" style caused rhythm issues, while both players struggled on serve, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. This result leaves Russia needing just one more win from Sunday's matches to reach the final and claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for more floods and damage from another storm predicted to hit later this week, specifically an east coast low bringing heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned this new weather will hamper ongoing clean-up efforts, as over 4,000 jobs from last week's 24,196 requests remain unfinished. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills highlighted particular worry for the Hunter region, which suffered severely in the last storm, and urged the community to prepare. Meteorologists note the system may differ from last week's, potentially impacting coastal areas in the state's northeast and southeast Queensland, with peak rainfall expected Thursday to Saturday.

Model Nina Moric collapsed due to low blood pressure and was hospitalized on Saturday night, leading to conflicting reports; Italian media claimed she attempted suicide and was found by her mother, but Moric denied this on Instagram, stating it was a domestic accident where she fell and injured herself due to low blood pressure. She shared photos of her injuries, reassured fans she was recovering well at home needing only rest, and expressed shock at the suicide claims. The passage also notes her past marriage to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

A YouGov poll reveals Diana is the favourite name for a girl at 12%, followed by Alice and Charlotte at 9% each; for a boy, James leads at 13%. While 25% of the 2,200 polled hope for a girl, only 3% want a boy. Social media users strongly favour naming a girl Diana. Additionally, 68% support William's six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, Afghanistan, on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon; the Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group claimed the attack; the protesters were en route to a rally against the provincial governor when the explosion occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer, as confirmed by his representative; the Brazilian right-back, who spent seven successful years at the club winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League titles, could not agree to a new deal, specifically rejecting a three-year extension dependent on him playing in 60% of matches, with his agent stating the negotiations are over.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club, believing they would be a perfect fit due to their South American-style play and that fans would adore them at La Bombonera; in an interview with Corriere dello Sport, Osvaldo specifically named Pirlo and Totti as his top choices, praising Pirlo as one of the world's best midfielders and Totti as a Roma legend who would be equally loved in Argentina.

Amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, 18, suffered a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square at Wincanton, an incident watched hundreds of thousands of times online, but returned to his usual stable duties the next morning with only a cut on his nose; he described the fall as a "blur" he couldn't avoid, felt lucky, received banter and gained Twitter followers, and joked about a possible gymnastics career after racing.

James Haskell, captain of London Wasps and England flanker, posted an Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man to promote the new Avengers movie, which premiered at Westfield London with fans queuing to see the cast including Robert Downey Jr. Haskell returned to Wasps in 2012 after playing for Stade Français in France, the Ricoh Black Rams in Japan, and the Highlanders in New Zealand following his initial departure from Wasps in 2009; since his return, he has surpassed 100 appearances for Wasps and earned 57 England caps.

The wide-leg trouser is a prominent SS15 trend, offering an effortless alternative to skinny jeans, which have dominated for years but remain timeless; this look has resurfaced since the 1970s and comes in various styles like denim, cropped, printed, or striped. Styling tips include pairing with high heels and simple tops (knits, shirts, tees) to balance the volume, choosing high-waisted and very long lengths for extra leg elongation, and avoiding being overwhelmed by fabric. Designers like Gucci (denim flares), Celine (colourful billowing bottoms), and Stella McCartney (dressier pants) showcased the trend on runways, while Topshop offers a high-street version called the Miller. Denim is noted as the easiest way to achieve the look, and it's a trend that updates the wardrobe regardless of weather.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with screening "American Sniper" for students despite objections from over 200 students who signed a petition against it, citing concerns the film negatively depicted the Middle East and its people; the film stars Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL sniper killed in 2013. After an initial cancellation prompted by the petition, a counter-petition emerged, and the university reversed its decision, stating the cancellation was inconsistent with its values of freedom of expression and student choice. The university will also screen "Paddington" as an alternative option, and the decision drew praise from head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter on April 3, causing a flame to singe a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia; the quokka survived. Detectives questioned the men (aged 18 and 24, living in Cockburn Central), seized video evidence, evicted them from the island, and charged them with animal cruelty; they will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are cat-sized and found on some small islands off the Western Australian coast, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a dancer at New York venues like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s-40s who performed alongside figures such as Bill Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen herself dancing due to lost films and memorabilia. Filmmakers Mark Cantor and volunteers showed her "soundies" (early music videos) at her nursing home, bringing her delight as she finally witnessed her performances.

Car washing is declining in Britain, with a third of men and three-quarters of women never washing their own cars, and only 5% involving children; reasons include Sunday shopping, more football, the rise of hand car washes, and larger vehicles being harder to clean, though more people wash their cars during holidays like Easter, sometimes just to get out of the house, with regional variations showing Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield as most frequent washers and Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh as least, and Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs most likely to be washed by owners compared to Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's significant impact on him since Gerrard's arrival at Liverpool in 2008, highlighting Gerrard's help in settling him at the club and considering him still one of the world's best players and synonymous with Liverpool; Gerrard is set to feature in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead Liverpool to the final against Arsenal on his birthday before departing for LA Galaxy, while Skrtel believes Liverpool can overcome the challenge of replacing Gerrard with existing players who will be supported by the team.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus achieved his first hole-in-one at Augusta National during the par-3 contest, sinking a 130-yard shot on the fourth hole that spun back into the cup while playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw; he later joked about predicting the ace, though Camilo Villegas tied a record with two aces that day, including one on the same hole. Nicklaus, a six-time Masters winner and career grand slam champion, became the youngest to win a green jacket in 1963.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas Wednesday night as storms brought multiple tornado reports, including one spotted about 6 miles northwest of Goddard (less than 17 miles west of Wichita) that moved northeast, and others near Aetta in southwestern Kansas; CNN expert Chad Myers warned nighttime tornadoes are especially deadly, while the National Weather Service indicated a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and roof damage as reported by CNN affiliate KMOV and social media users; additional storms are expected Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris, claiming he meant to use a taser but accidentally used his gun; the judge granted him permission to vacation in the Bahamas, prompting criticism from Harris's family who saw it as apathetic; Bates's preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2, where his lawyers plan to present facts in court; Bates apologized, as did Sheriff Stanley Glanz, but the Harris family's lawyer alleges Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff, while the sheriff's office denies allegations of forged records; Bates's lawyers released training records they say prove his qualifications, and two deputies involved in the arrest were reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas, where Aldo will make his eighth title defense; McGregor has unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, complementing his existing gorilla tattoo on his chest, and claims greater motivation to win the belt than Aldo has to defend it, a sentiment highlighted when he grabbed Aldo's belt during a fractious promotional tour in Dublin in front of 5,000 supporters.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a beer at an Australian Rules function, cheered on by players, but drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners who claimed he glorified binge drinking and associated masculinity with alcohol. Professor Julie Robert from UTS deemed it problematic, arguing the prime minister should advocate against binge drinking and that the act promoted drinking speed and quantity over socializing. The event took about six seconds, with chants of "skol" and "Tony," and Abbott was described as "proud as punch." Critics, including Robert, emphasized he should set an example against heavy drinking to avoid perpetuating stereotypes. Reactions varied: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten joked about Abbott's drinking habits, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended his fitness, and Robert noted attitudes towards heavy drinking have changed since former PM Bob Hawke's similar actions.

Indiana has experienced a significant HIV outbreak in Scott County, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positives, up from 106 the previous week, primarily among intravenous drug users using the painkiller Opana. Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, which has distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected 1,400 used ones, though health officials expect the case count to rise with increased testing. Pence is reviewing whether to extend the program beyond April 25, while legislation allowing needle exchanges in other high hepatitis C counties faces uncertainty due to Pence's opposition and funding concerns, as federal funding is banned and Pence's order provided no state money.

An obsessive Arsenal fan created a detailed test for his girlfriend Saskia, featuring multiple-choice questions, tables, and "in your own words" sections, with instructions like "calculators may be used"; she scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%), impressing him enough that he commented he wouldn't dump her, though he noted she could have performed better on specific questions and needed to learn player positions and that "Tottenham are scum"; the test covered Arsenal FC's meaning, fan nicknames, the manager, kit details, the starting squad (where she struggled with positions), player comparisons (she creatively wrote Sanchez was "buff" and Hazard was a "p***k"), top goalscorers, the 2014 FA Cup final scoreline and winning goal, and why Arsenal are the best team; public reaction on Twitter was mixed, with some calling the boyfriend a "legend" and Saskia "proper gf material," while others criticized him as a "biff-head" or "nuts."

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member who became a crucial DEA informant for 27 years after fleeing Colombia, faces deportation despite being promised US citizenship in exchange for his work; he provided vital information leading to the prosecution of major figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, was never paid, and now lives illegally in the US after retiring due to declining health, fearing death if returned to Colombia, while the DEA refuses to assist with his citizenship application and he struggles to secure necessary documentation.

A 14-year-old girl in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village set herself on fire using kerosene two days after the attack, reportedly after her family advised her to remain silent; she is now hospitalized in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70 per cent burns and fighting for her life, while the accused men have been arrested.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is preparing for his first Manchester derby at Old Trafford against rivals City on Sunday, dreaming of victory to secure a top-four finish, but will be without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw as he deems them not fit enough to play; van Gaal emphasized controlling aggression after their previous loss and stated a win is crucial for achieving third place or higher in the table, while acknowledging City's challenge and expressing appreciation for the fans' support.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against rising ticket prices by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Emirates Stadium match, with tickets starting at £64, some of the highest in the Premier League. Protesters displayed banners reading "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket" and "Football without fans is nothing," organized by groups like Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, who called the prices "extortionate" and warned authorities risk losing a generation of fans unless tangible reductions are made.

Baby Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth, characterized by persistent jaundice and blocked bile ducts; an initial surgery to unblock the ducts failed, necessitating a liver transplant for survival. Neither parent was a suitable donor match, but Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader (the mother's twin sister), volunteered and was deemed an ideal candidate. Shanell donated part of her liver to Star in November, and after six weeks in hospital, Star made a good recovery, though she requires weekly blood tests, liver function tests, and lifelong anti-rejection medication.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake participated in an Audi football challenge against teammates Loïc Remy and Willian, competing in three rounds: close-range shooting into car boots (won 5-3 by Hazard and Ake), tennis over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus (won by Hazard and Ake, giving them a 6-0 lead), and long-range shooting into convertible cars (won by Remy and Willian). Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror off one of the Audi cars during the final challenge, and later got to drive one of the vehicles.

Former Fortune 500 executive Robert Dellinger, 54, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide in the deaths of Vermont couple Jason Timmons, 29, and Amanda Murphy, 24, who was eight months pregnant, and assault for the death of their unborn baby, after driving his pickup truck over 100mph across a highway median in December 2013, causing a crash that killed the couple instantly. During sentencing, Dellinger denied being suicidal, contradicting prosecutors' claim he had previously admitted to trying to kill himself; his wife described him as a man of ethics and integrity devastated by the deaths. Dellinger faces 12 to 24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit, with his defense citing Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose effects, Prozac, and advanced multiple sclerosis as factors, while prosecutors noted he was depressed and loopy after an argument with his wife over medications.

Lacey Spears was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul Spears with salt and sentenced to 20 years to life in prison, showing no emotion during sentencing. The boy's father, Chris Hill, reacted angrily on Facebook, expressing his hope she would die in prison and calling her a "crazy a** woman." Prosecutors argued Spears caused her son's suffering and death to gain attention, while her lawyer claimed she was innocent, suffered from mental illness, and blamed hospital negligence, planning to appeal. The crime occurred in New York, though Spears lived in Kentucky, and her son endured repeated hospitalizations and procedures before his death.

Improved influenza vaccine stocks arriving in Australia a month late now include protection against new strains H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused increased deaths in Europe and the US as the previous vaccine was ineffective; the updated vaccine also covers H1N1. Free government-funded shots for high-risk groups like the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians begin April 20, and experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, recommend everyone get vaccinated to protect vulnerable populations, noting the modified vaccine is a better match for currently circulating strains.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are defending the site against criticism from National Geographic magazine, which described it as having "all the historical character of an office lobby," while also facing potential management threats due to Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner's proposal to eliminate the state historic preservation agency that oversees the tomb. Despite recent renovations costing over $2.5 million, including interior plaster, paint, bronze, marble work, and lighting upgrades, the caretakers are concerned about further budget cuts that have already reduced hours and staffing, and they disagree with the National Geographic assessment, noting the tomb is in excellent physical condition and many visitors find it impressive. The tomb, designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Grant in 1874, was reconstructed in 1899 and 1930, and remains a significant tourist site commemorating Lincoln's assassination in 1865.

Nineties fashion trends like chokers, berry lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts are currently popular, but the potential comeback of JNCO's huge wideleg "rave" jeans, featuring leg openings approaching 50 inches, horrifies many who wore them before. The passage highlights other retro trends that should be left in the past, including the bucket hat, camouflage print, excessive styling like double denim, shapeless Ugg boots, impractically short Daisy Dukes, garish Juicy Couture velour tracksuits, brightly coloured sunglasses, corsets worn as outerwear, and difficult-to-wear harem trousers.

This passage summarizes several trending stories: four rainbows appeared over New York after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis; China banned exotic dancers at wakes as part of a vice crackdown; Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during a UK interview about his private life; the Kylie Jenner lip plumping challenge involved sucking on jars; 102-year-old Alice Barker viewed old footage of herself; a prom-posal referencing bombs was rejected by a school, with the student accusing racism; Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'; Johnny Depp appeared nearly unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer; a pregnancy announcement referenced 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'; and a military dad photobombed his son.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career win with a cake at the Miami Open after defeating Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 to reach the semi-finals, following Andy Murray's 500th win and cake celebration the previous day; Williams's sister Venus was eliminated, and Williams will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals after Halep beat Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5.

Sabeen Mahmud ran a vibrant second-floor cafe in Karachi that served as a hub for discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship, promoting free speech and progressive values in a dangerous environment; she was shot dead at point-blank range after locking up the cafe, leaving her mother wounded, following her hosting of a controversial discussion on Balochistan that authorities had tried to shut down, despite her awareness of the risks and past death threats; her killing, for which no one claimed responsibility, deeply saddened those advocating for non-violence and tolerance, as she had become a prominent Pakistani figurehead for humanism and bravery, with widespread public grief and gratitude for her work expressed through social media and art.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu refugee who fled partition violence 70 years ago, and around 100,000 other West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) in India's Muslim-majority state of Kashmir have been denied basic citizenship rights like property ownership and voting in state elections for decades, trapping three generations in abject poverty despite Kashmir's overall prosperity; this denial stems from successive state governments' fear of upsetting the demographic balance, though the recent success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party in joining the state coalition offers hope for change, with activists like Labha Ram Gandhi warning the community will protest if their demands for state-subject rights are not met.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is still considering a move to Chelsea this summer, despite the club's reported £4 million offer, as he seeks a club where he can play regularly and develop; Chelsea may loan him to Vitesse Arnhem, but Muto prioritizes finding the right environment for his growth, while his former coach Ranko Popovic praises his intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence, and Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledges knowing about Muto but avoids discussing him directly, noting that transfers consider both football quality and financial aspects like the club's sponsorship deals and Financial Fair Play rules.

Australia has abandoned its policy of not selecting overseas players, allowing stars like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell to be considered for the Wallabies, while England's Stuart Lancaster persists with a similar stance, which is criticized as outdated and detrimental to World Cup chances. The passage argues that the World Cup demands the best players globally, citing examples like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon who improved significantly overseas, and insists England must select its strongest available squad regardless of location to avoid "what ifs" and give players the best chance to win, as club loyalty shouldn't override national team selection.

FireChat enables messaging without internet or mobile signals by creating wireless mesh networks using Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework or similar Android features, allowing users to chat anonymously and securely within proximity (up to 30 feet) or further through the "everyone" setting that relays messages between nodes; the app has been downloaded over five million times and is useful in areas like planes or undergrounds, but messages are limited to around 200 feet. To overcome this range limitation, Open Garden developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device acting as a beacon or booster to strengthen these mesh networks; currently in development, Greenstone works with FireChat at about 20 feet, has a one-year battery life, stores up to 1,000 messages, and Open Garden is partnering with manufacturers to bring it to market.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle embraces "fat" as an honest, body-positive self-descriptor alongside other neutral terms like "short" and "wife," challenging societal programming that equates "fat" with "ugly" and noting size discrimination has risen 66% in workplaces; she uses burlesque to expose audiences to "fat" bodies positively, citing studies showing increased exposure to body diversity fosters acceptance, and shares her personal journey of overcoming initial insecurity about her body through performance, recommending others find a "courage reference," while her 2014 TED talk, recently posted online, garnered nearly 38,000 views and mostly positive feedback, including messages of gratitude and stories of changed perspectives.

Theo Walcott, frequently benched this season with 17 Premier League appearances as a substitute, participated in a Lanvin photoshoot with Arsenal teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Özil, alongside model Olga Sherer, as Lanvin is the club's official tailor since 2013; the Arsenal first team will wear similar attire for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa at Wembley on May 30, and Walcott, who came on in the recent 0-0 draw with Chelsea, hopes to start against Hull.

A collection of props and puppets created by makeup artist Rick Baker, valued at approximately $746,100, will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on PropStore.com; the 417 items span over 50 productions from Baker's 30-year career, including notable pieces like the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black ($40,000), the Two-Face mask from Batman Forever ($1,500), the Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas ($8,000), the Mikey costume from Men in Black ($30,000), the Harry suit from Harry and the Hendersons ($6,000), the Bat Gremlin from Gremlins 2 ($8,000), the Mohawk Mogwai puppet from Gremlins 2 ($8,000), the Frozen Thug statue from Batman & Robin ($4,000), the Bat puppet from Batman Forever ($6,000), the Worm Guy from Men in Black II ($10,000), the Michael Jackson robotic transformation face from Moonwalker ($3,000), the Hero Joe head from Mighty Joe Young ($6,000), and the Daffy Gremlin puppet from Gremlins 2 ($6,000).

Seven-year-old British boy Carwyn Scott-Howell, described as daring, outgoing, and determined, died after falling 164 feet while skiing with his family in the French Alps; he became separated from his mother during the last run of the day, entered dense woodland, and was found dead by police following his footprints in the snow, with his family expressing utter devastation and a "vast void in their hearts" after their "most happy ski holiday" turned to tragedy.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after starting a diet at age 13 due to bullying about her weight and societal pressures to be "size zero." She became obsessed with her figure, hiding food, lying about eating, and consuming as little as 100 calories daily, sometimes just one piece of fruit. This extreme restriction caused her health to deteriorate, leading to dizziness, a slowing heart rate, and ultimately a collapse where her body began shutting down. After being hospitalized and placed on a heart monitor, she received support from eating disorder organizations and began her recovery. Now, her improved body image and confidence have led her to the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition promoting positive experiences away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool unveiled their new 2015/16 home kit, designed by New Balance under a record-breaking £300 million four-year deal, at Anfield, featuring players like Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet presenting it to fans. Despite Sterling having rejected a £100,000-a-week contract and being linked to Arsenal, Liverpool insisted he would not leave this summer, a message echoed by supporters who chanted for him to stay in the kit next season. The kit launch also served as a platform for players to discuss the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with Sturridge and Sterling emphasizing the importance of winning for the club and fans, while the shirt includes tributes to the Hillsborough disaster.

The University of Manchester has produced the largest high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky, using data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile; this map, the first in a series, shows dark matter distribution through gravitational lensing effects on galaxy shapes and aims to eventually map 12.5% of the sky over five years to study galaxy formation and probe dark energy, with the team analyzing 130 million galaxy images using supercomputers.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old Dutch winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him a summer signing; van Gaal previously worked with Depay during Holland's third-place finish at the 2014 World Cup. Depay enjoyed a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games to help PSV win the Dutch Eredivisie title for the first time in seven years. Tottenham's £15 million offer last summer was rejected, but now United, along with Paris Saint-Germain and another big European club, are interested in significantly higher bids. Depay, known for his pace, dribbling, and powerful right-footed shooting, is described as strong on the ball with good close control and an explosive shot, though he can sometimes make poor decisions.

Chelsea secured a commanding 3-1 victory over Manchester City's young side in Manchester, taking a strong lead back to London for the second leg. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half, with Dominic Solanke adding a late third goal to seal the win.

Marco Rubio asserts that people are born with their sexual preference but opposes same-sex marriage as a constitutional right, believing states should regulate marriage through their legislatures rather than courts. He states he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer despite disagreeing with the decision, comparing it to his Catholic view that divorce is wrong but not grounds to stop loving someone.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, who met in 2011, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue their dream of cycling around the world with no specific plans or agenda, doing it as cheaply as possible; in their first 356 days, they covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, living on less than three euros each daily by primarily camping (161 nights), using hosting websites like Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), and relying on minimal food expenses (2.74 euros each per day), with their journey starting in London and progressing through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and now Armenia, and they plan to continue cycling through Asia and the Americas.

A Texas couple discovered racial slurs printed on their wedding photo booth snapshots months after their 2012 celebration, allegedly by photographer James Evans of Premiere Photos; the bride's sister delayed informing them to avoid ruining the wedding day. When the groom confronted Evans, he reportedly refused to apologize and told them to "sue me." Represented by attorney Cathy Hale, the couple filed a lawsuit under the Texas deceptive trade practices act, claiming negligence and breach of contract, seeking an apology rather than money. Evans denies all allegations, stating no evidence links his company to the slur and that the couple showed no mental anguish; mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if unresolved.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from a concussion, unsure when he will return for Harlequins after pulling out of a match; he emphasizes not rushing back to avoid long-term injuries like Johnny Sexton (sidelined for 12 weeks) and George North, who suffered his fourth quick-fire concussion and has been advised not to play again this season. Brown credits increased awareness from World Rugby online modules for helping him recognize symptoms, such as a headache after the France game, and make responsible decisions like pulling out of the England-Ireland match, urging teammates to be honest and not play through concussions.

Smartphone and internet use are blamed for a decline in sexual frequency among British couples, with research showing a drop from five times monthly in 1990 to three times currently, compared to four times in 2000. Professor David Spiegelhalter attributes this to technology eroding boundaries between public and private lives, reducing "quiet empty time" and making people constantly check emails, thus squeezing out time for partners. Researcher Catherine Mercer adds that competing demands and constant connectivity mean sex falls down priority lists, preventing focus on partners at bedtime.

Tibetan mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, were once highly valued in China, with one puppy selling for £1.2 million, but their popularity has drastically declined due to the government's anti-corruption crackdown (reducing their use as gifts to officials) and bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in major cities. This has led to many being sent to slaughterhouses for meat in cheap hotpots, with some stolen or sold by breeders; rescuers found 20 crammed in cages, a third dead and others injured. The breed's quality has also suffered from cross-breeding for profit, creating a glut of poor-quality dogs unsuitable for urban living.

A survey of women in Paris found every respondent reported experiencing sexual harassment on public transport, with half first assaulted before age 18; harassment ranges from verbal insults and intimidation to sexual assault and rape, causing fear (60% of women vs. 30% of men) and forcing behavioral changes like altering routes or clothing; the problem is often unreported and limits women's freedom, excluding them from public spaces, leading to calls for campaigns to combat such behavior and educate women and the public that such acts are illegal and punishable.

Direct Line's #EverydayFix competition, following a survey identifying top everyday emergencies like not sleeping (46%), losing keys (37%), and phone battery issues (31%), tasked groups with designing prototypes; three shortlisted products are Snooze (an alarm silencing phone notifications for sleep), Forget Me Lock (a key-fob showing door lock status via color change), and Nipper (a tiny charger using household batteries); the public can vote via Twitter retweets for the winner, which will be developed through Kickstarter funding.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, faces a Ministry of Justice investigation after allocating over £500,000 of public money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity where she is a director and which also includes Chief Constable Sue Sim on its board. Critics, including Keith Vaz, have condemned the move as a conflict of interest and inappropriate, describing it as creating a "soap opera" within the force. Baird defends the decision, stating all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed, while Sim is retiring after facing misconduct allegations over bullying. The investigation will determine if any conflict of interest rules were broken.

Three people, including ringleader Corry Campbell, were imprisoned for their roles in a 42-hour assault on Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos after Campbell believed Valecce hurt his cat and stole money/weed; Campbell and Carl Halin received 20-year sentences, Sandra Ng received 23 months, while David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt await sentencing; Valecce suffered severe physical injuries and psychological trauma, stating he is scared to go outside and has nightmares.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old Dutch winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him a summer signing; van Gaal previously worked with Depay during Holland's third-place finish at the 2014 World Cup. Depay, who scored 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie games this season, helping PSV win their first league title in seven years, is attracting interest from major European clubs including Paris Saint-Germain, with PSV's technical director confirming contact and stating current bids involve larger sums than Tottenham's rebuffed £15 million offer last summer. Known for his pace, dribbling, powerful right-foot, and ability to cut in from the left, Depay is also noted for his potential, having been compared favorably to young Cristiano Ronaldo by a former United scout, though his manager Phillip Cocu cautions he is still developing.
Chelsea defeated Manchester City 3-1 in a youth cup match, taking a commanding lead back to London after Tammy Abraham scored twice with volleys and Dominic Solanke added a late third goal.

Marco Rubio asserts that people are born with their sexual preferences but opposes same-sex marriage as a constitutional right, believing the institution should be defined as between one man and one woman and regulated by state legislatures rather than courts. He states he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cares for despite disagreeing with the decision, drawing a parallel to his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong but not a reason to stop loving someone. Rubio announced his presidential campaign last week and has received significant monetary commitments.

Pablo Mandado, a 27-year-old Spaniard, and Ilze Zebolde, a 31-year-old Latvian, who met in 2011, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on an open-ended, plan-free cycling journey around the world, driven solely by their dream to explore "a pedal at a time." After 356 days, they have covered nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries, starting from London and traversing Western Europe, Eastern Europe, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia. They maintain an extremely frugal lifestyle, living on less than three euros per person per day (10 euro cents per kilometre), with food (2.74 euros each) being their primary expense; they keep costs down by camping most nights (161 nights), using hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers (110 nights total), and relying on the kindness of strangers. They carry approximately 130 kg of gear and plan to continue cycling through Asia and across the Americas for the foreseeable future.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from a concussion, unsure when he will return for Harlequins after pulling out of a match; he emphasizes the importance of not rushing back and learning about concussion symptoms through online modules, citing examples like George North, who has suffered four quick-fire concussions and won't play again this season, and Johnny Sexton, who was sidelined for 12 weeks. Brown, who was knocked out against Italy in February, advocates for players to be honest about symptoms and not play through injuries, stating it's not worth the risk.

Smartphone use is blamed for a decline in sexual frequency among couples, with research showing Britons now have sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter attributes this to technological connectivity eroding boundaries between work, home, and public life, leaving less "quiet empty time" and making people constantly check emails, which competes for time and reduces sex as a priority. Experts suggest being "too connected" prevents focusing solely on partners.

Tibetan mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, were once highly valued in China, with one puppy selling for £1.2 million, but their popularity has drastically declined due to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown (reducing their use as gifts to officials) and bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in major cities. This has led to many mastiffs being sent to slaughterhouses for meat in cheap hotpots, with some stolen or sold by breeders due to a glut of poor-quality dogs resulting from cross-breeding for profit; rescuers have found dead and injured dogs crammed in cages en route to abattoirs.

Direct Line's #EverydayFix competition, based on a survey of 2,000 people identifying top everyday emergencies like not sleeping (46%), losing keys (37%), and traffic jams (35%), resulted in three shortlisted prototype products: Snooze by Instruments, an alarm clock silencing phone notifications for better sleep; Forget Me Lock by Onn Studio, a key-fitting device that turns green when the door is open and red when locked; and Nipper by Impulse, the world's smallest mobile phone charger using any household battery. The public can vote for their favorite via Twitter retweets with the #everydayfix hashtag, and the winning product will be developed through a Kickstarter campaign.
